SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Mr S.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, I rise on a matter of privilege. I draw your attention to two newspaper articles which were published this morning. The first, headed `States Set to Gain Phone Tap Access', was in this morning's Melbourne Sun, published by Herald and Weekly Times Ltd. The second article, headed `State Police to Get Tap Power', was in the Brisbane Courier-Mail, published also by Herald and Weekly Times Ltd.

SPEECH.PARA: These articles purport to contain the views of members of the Joint Select Committee on Telecommunications Interception as allegedly expressed in the Committee's forthcoming report to the Parliament. I understand that similar articles may also have appeared in Tasmania, in today's Burnie Advocate and the Launceston Examiner, and I am checking this further.

Madam Speaker, the Committee is in the final stages of deliberation on its report. It appears to me that the publication of these two articles is evidence, prima facie, of a contempt of the Parliament. I ask you to give consideration as to whether, prima facie, a case of contempt of the Parliament exists.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! As is normal in these matters, I will take the matter on board and report back to the House at the earliest opportunity.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Health. I refer the Minister to his answer in the House last Friday when he said that eligible persons would be able to sign section 36 certificates of identity which could in turn be forwarded through the mail, and to his reference to the procedure covering the signing of passports as a possible method of determining eligibility for signing such certificates. How does the Government propose to guarantee the integrity of these section 36 certificates? Does the Minister propose that 1,500,000 Australians who are eligible to sign passports will be able to issue section 36 certificates? If not, when does the Minister propose to announce the eligibility criteria for signing the certificates?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —With reference to the question of the prescribed persons who can sign those particular eligibility certificates, I indicated in my answer the other day that they would include leading community individuals-that is, people who would not recognise the person making an application before them. I also indicate now that the exact definition of each of those categories of eligible persons who will be able to sign such certificates will be provided in regulations which, of course, will have to be laid before both Houses of Parliament.

ANSWER.PARA: At this point we are not able to identify completely all of the groups or categories of people who would, under the provisions of the Australia Card Bill, be prescribed persons in the sense of being able to authorise and verify those certifications. But the important thing is that there exists a major proposal within the Bill so that we might at least not have the nonsense that has gone on over the weekend whereby we have had these tales particularly spread amongst country people that they will have to come to the city every time to get themselves verified. There is a very adequate and full provision in the Bill for effective verification of Australia cards where people are not able to come into a major city.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Foreign Affairs inform the House of the situation with respect to the ratification of the Treaty of Rarotonga?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —To date, 10 of the 13 South Pacific Forum countries have signed the Treaty of Rarotonga-the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty-and seven have now deposited instruments of ratification. Eight ratifications are required for the Treaty to enter into force. The South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty Bill, to clear the way for Australia's ratification, is currently before Parliament. Having been cleared by this House it is now before the Senate.

ANSWER.PARA: The protocols to the Treaty which will be open for signature on 1 December provide for the United States of America, the United Kingdom and France to apply the provisions of the Treaty to their South Pacific territories and for the nuclear weapons states-the United States, United Kingdom, France, the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics and China-to undertake not to use or threaten to use nuclear weapons against parties to the Treaty, nor to conduct nuclear testing in the South Pacific.

We sincerely trust that all those eligible states will adhere to the protocols. The United States and the United Kingdom have advised us that they are still studying the Treaty. France has declared publicly that it will not sign. I sincerely trust that this is a view that will not prevail as its final position. The Soviet Union and China have responded positively. In all the circumstances it has been a very encouraging result. It is only the second such Treaty in existence, apart from the Antarctic area covering a substantial region of the globe. It is a very important contribution to arms control and disarmament measures.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Health. I remind the Minister that the Health Insurance Commission's submission to the Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card said that in the two years of Medicare's operation, 670,000 cards have been reported lost or stolen; that is 6 per cent of the cards issued. What reason is there to expect that the number of lost or stolen identity cards will be any less than the rate for the Medicare card? Given that or any other substantial rate of loss or theft of the identify card-and the techniques already available to alter and forge high security documents such as credit cards, passports and birth certificates-how will it be possible to maintain the integrity and the utility of this extraordinarily expensive system?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —In answer to the honourable member's question, first of all let me point out that the Medicare card was never designed as a high integrity card. It was never a card of the same importance to individuals as the Australia Card would be for one obvious reason; that is, that the Medicare card is not usable unless one has an actual doctor's bill in which to make a claim. So I do not think that to make integrity comparisons between the Medicare card, which never was intended to have--
—You got the question wrong.
—Let me deal with the integrity question. One would not expect, therefore, to have the same integrity comparisons between the Medicare card and the Australia Card.

ANSWER.PARA: Turning specifically to the integrity of the Australia Card, first of all, unlike the Medicare card and any credit card in this country, it will have a digitalised photograph and a signature of the same order on it. In addition, a security device will be attached to the backs of particular batches of cards, again to prevent forgery.

Let me just take the question of bank notes in this society. Of course there is some forgery of bank notes but, again, our system and the protections and security device built into our currency have gone a long way towards making that a relatively marginal problem. For all those reasons I think--

TALK.START.PARA: —We still have the currency.

—As the Prime Minister has pointed out, we still have a currency which is of high integrity. So I believe that, with these security devices and the form of the card, it will have a very high integrity in this society.

ANSWER.PARA: Returning to the original point I made about the comparative losses between systems, obviously some Australia Cards will be lost. If the honourable member reads the Bill again he will see that there is a whole series of protections in relation to those matters. In addition, I think a much greater valuation will be placed on that card by Australian citizens than on the Medicare card system which, as I have said, was never designed to be a system of high integrity.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Health aware of an advertisement which appeared in Saturday's Weekend Australian calling on people to oppose the Australia Card? Can the Minister inform the House whether his Department will collect detailed, personal information about individuals and, if so, whether there will be proper safeguards to prevent leaks of personal information?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the advertisement to which the honourable member referred. I must say that, as I have a considerable personal respect for many of those people on that list, I was extremely disappointed that they should lend their names to such a misleading and inaccurate advertisement. Indeed, I think when some of those people who signed that advertisement consider what they have signed, very clearly they will agree that they have lent themselves to a very sloppy document indeed.

ANSWER.PARA: Of course, I am not surprised at the Opposition displaying enthusiasm about the advertisement which plays up its scare-mongering tactic which is about the only response the Opposition has to any of this Government's tax proposals.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish!

—I want to go through each of the statements just to show how clearly inaccurate, misleading and scare-mongering they were. The advertisement claims: `The Government will collect detailed, personal information about you'--
—Written by a QC.
—Order! The honourable member for Barker will cease interjecting.
—I will just repeat what was written: `The Government will collect detailed, personal information about you'. That statement is simply wrong.
—Of course it is not.
—There is nothing on the Australia Card Register other than basic, identifying information.
—That's not true.
—Order!

—If honourable members opposite look at what is put on that Register they will find that, at least once every month, Australians fill in a document, either for a public or private bureaucracy, which at least covers that kind of identifying information. It is a very common process in this country to supply that kind of information.

ANSWER.PARA: The second allegation that is made is that the system will cost $1 billion and require 2,000 public servants to run it and, therefore, it will not save money. Again that is incorrect. The cost to government over the first 10 years will be $759m with savings to revenue of $5.4 billion, giving a net benefit to government of $4.7 billion.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish!
—The honourable member for Barker, who has twisted and turned on this issue in every possible way, is denying that accusation. But of course--
—What about your own members? They were on the Committee.
—The honourable member for Barker--
—What about the Committee?
—I warn the honourable member for Barker. If he does not heed the Chair, the Chair will deal with him.

—But the biggest component of those savings is in the tax area. The honourable member for Barker signed a report stating that we had grievously underestimated the amount of savings we will make in the taxation area. There was also the claim in this document that there were no proper safeguards to prevent leaks of personal details. But the people who signed that document should read the Australia Card Bill. There is provision for a Data Protection Agency in the Bill, which is in tandem with the privacy legislation. That will deliver the most broad-ranging, comprehensive and effective protection of privacy ever introduced in this country. The DPA will act as a watchdog and provide individuals with fast and efficient appeal mechanisms. In addition, every access to the Australia Card will be logged so that any access to it by departments will be logged. Every individual will have access to his or her identification information contained in the Australia Card Register; that is, every citizen will have the right once a year, free of cost, to check what is in the Australia Card Register. I refer all these so-called concerned people who signed that advertisement to a statement by somebody who is really worried by and has worked on the issue of privacy. I refer to Professor Douglas Whalan, who told the Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card--
—Who?
—He happens to be a professor of law at the Australian National University and also was Convenor of the Federal Government's Committee of Inquiry into the Protection of Privacy in 1973. He said:

ANSWER.PARA: If we do have an Australia Card, it is vital, I believe that we have both very carefully circumscribed limits on its use and a protective body with similar independence to that possessed by the Ombudsman.
Perhaps one irony would be that if we do have an Australia Card with all those protections . . . our privacy may be better protected than it is now.
Because we have done that, I think we can justify Professor Whalan's claim.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. Has his attention been drawn to similar articles in the Murdoch Sunday papers in at least Sydney and Brisbane on 9 November claiming that a person on a supporting parent benefit with one child is $70 a week better off than a single-income family on $39,000 a year with three children? Did the articles claim that these figures were allegedly supplied by the honourable member for Macquarie? Are they correct or are they based upon completely wrong premises?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I deplore the misrepresentation of the facts contained in the articles to which the honourable member for Prospect referred. The honourable member for Macquarie claimed that a family with an income of $39,000 per annum is worse off than a family on supporting parent benefit. This so-called research is riddled with inaccuracies and inconsistencies. It is an unbelievable claim that a person on the supporting parent benefit gets $72 a week more when one recognises that the current payment for supporting parent benefit is about $135 a week. The calculation in the article is wrong, first of all, in that it wrongly calculates the tax liability. Secondly, it overvalues pensioner concessions. Thirdly, it wrongly attributes the payment of rent assistance to people living in Housing Commission accommodation. Furthermore it also contains the assumption that a higher income family requires a generous standard of living, while it condemns a pensioner family to survival existence. What this does is to reflect a dual value system within the Opposition. It claims, on the one hand, that people with an annual income of $39,000 have a right to a certain standard of living whereas it claims, on the other hand, that people on a supporting parent benefit have a right only to a much lower standard of living.

ANSWER.PARA: This cooked up example has not been arrived at by comparing two like families. In the case of the $39,000 family, children of 16 and 17 years have been used whereas much younger children were used in the case of the supporting parent benefit family. If we compare two like families-namely, a couple on $39,000 with a four-year-old child and a supporting parent benefit family with a four-year-old child-the real result is that the couple with the $39,000 income has a free income of $350 a week compared to an amount for the sole parent family of $136 a week; that is, the first family has a free income nearly three times that of the second family. In relation to the motivation behind the use by the honourable member for Macquarie of the phrase `the new poor' in the article-a phrase coined by Katharine West and the New Right-we must understand that the Opposition's attitude is entirely punitive in terms of people on very low incomes. That is nowhere better reflected than in the record of the previous Government with respect to children in poverty. Under the Liberals the number of children in poverty more than doubled, from 9 per cent to 20 per cent, and payments for children in those circumstances declined by 35 per cent in real terms.

TALK.START.PARA: —What have you done about it?

—The honourable member asks what we have done about it. We have raised by 70 per cent per child additional pension and benefit payments for pensioner families. We have raised payment under the mothers/guardians allowance by more than 100 per cent and, in terms of the tax cuts that will be delivered in December and July of next year for families in middle income levels, the level of tax cuts will be in the order of $7, not only once but twice. For a family of the type mentioned in this article the level of tax cuts will be considerably higher. So let us not in this Parliament take seriously the kind of nonsense and misrepresentation being peddled by the honourable member for Macquarie. This Government has shown, by its policies with respect to the poor, compassion, and we are determined also to ensure that families on middle incomes are delivered equity, in terms of our taxation and social security systems. I wish the same could be said for the nascent policies of the Opposition.

—I inform the House that I called two members of the Government in succession because no one rose on my left. I shall now redress that and call two members on my left in succession. I call the Leader of the Opposition.

—I refer the Minister for Health to his answer to the first question asked of him by the Opposition and to his professed concern about the integrity of the proposed identity card. I ask the Minister, specifically: If a certificate under section 36 is signed by an eligible person and then sent through the post, how can such a certificate be treated as having the same integrity as the physical observation by the recipient of the original person holding his or her card?

—I think in the practical world in which we live we always have to make some compromises of this order. Let us take passports. There is a whole series of processes by which these very important and high integrity documents are certified by eligible persons, members of recognised groups in the community, who are entitled to do that to facilitate the issue of passports in this country. Where there is a real difficulty in somebody being able to present physically with their Australia Card, which I agree is our preference, it is encumbent upon government to provide an effective alternative. We believe that this system, which has been used by government in other areas in relation to high integrity documents, will be provided in relation to the Australia Card, as governments of all political persuasion have provided it in these kinds of areas before.

—I ask the Prime Minister: In the light of today's Australian Customs Service decision that Brazilian frozen orange juice concentrate is being imported at dumped prices, does the Government now accept that Australian citrus growers are in one of the worst ever cost-price crises? Does the Prime Minister accept that the Customs notice will be meaningless until its anti-dumping measures are given specific values, especially as the countervailing tariff applied to the dumped Brazilian product by United States authorities has been public knowledge for some weeks? Further, what complementary action will the Government take to reduce costs of production to Australian growers, including the present near record high interest rates, fuel excise, the Budget imposition of a 10 per cent sales tax on juice and juice products, and the fringe benefits and capital gains taxes?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —In relation to the question of the reduction of costs facing rural producers, I remind the honourable member of the fact that under this Government there has been a very significant reduction in the rate of growth of costs faced by rural producers. All we have come to expect in this Parliament when facts are put before this pathetic Opposition is a variation of oohs, aahs and confected giggles from the Leader of the Opposition. Despite that, I will put the facts before it. The fact is very simply this--
—Give us the facts.

—Do not confect your anger, old boy. You are too nice a fellow; do not do it. The facts are that when we came to office the rate of growth of farm costs faced by the honourable member's constituency, which his Government left them, was about 11 per cent per annum. We have very significantly reduced that. In fact, this year it will be less than half of that. That is because in the areas which really determine what will happen to costs in this country this Government has policies. It has policies in regard to bringing down the Budget deficit and policies in regard to having a sustainable level of wage increases. We do things; we do not just talk about things.

ANSWER.PARA: The honourable member for Riverina-Darling asks us what we will do. We have been cleaning up the mess that the Opposition left. Now the country is talking about the hopeless ineptitude of what the Opposition promises it. The problem for this country, including the citrus growers, is that people are looking at the honourable member and the Opposition and saying: `My God, will they ever learn?'. The Opposition is hopeless; it has nothing. The President of the Victorian Branch of the Liberal Party of Australia had something to say at the weekend. Mrs Ritchie is the very widely respected leader of the Liberal Party in Victoria. She said that it is a very trying time for the Liberals in Opposition. They are trying to find a leader; they are trying to find some policies; and they are trying to find some principles.

As distinct from the honourable member's colleagues who are trying to do something, this Government has put into place policies in regard to wages and policies in regard to bringing down the Opposition's $10 billion deficit to $3 1/2 billion, and in the event the people whom the honourable member purportedly represents have had their rate of cost increases more than halved from the preposterous levels that were achieved by his Government's lack of policies. So he should not talk to us about the citrus growers or anyone else because they know that under this Government they have had a significant improvement in their position. As to the actual details that were contained in the question of the honourable member, I will refer them to the Minister for Primary Industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Health aware of claims made by the Opposition that the introduction of the Australia Card will make detection of illegal immigrants more difficult? Can he advise the House whether in fact the Australia Card will have a deterrent effect on the entry of illegal immigrants into this country?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of allegations made by the Opposition that the Australia Card would make the detection of illegal immigrants more difficult. I must say that, in the kind of paper warfare over the weekend, this statement from the honourable member for Mitchell does qualify as the most asinine of the lot.

ANSWER.PARA: First of all, if citizens read that peculiar statement-I would advise them to do so-they would be quite unaware of the fact that people from overseas need a passport to come into this country. One would have thought that the shadow Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs would have been aware of that, but there is no sign of that in the statement whatsoever. In fact, he talked about how people would be popping in and out with these Australian cards that they had been granted as visitors. I point out that people need a passport every time they come into this country.

Secondly, the Australia Card for visitors does not confer any extra rights on any visitors, except those which are provided to them under the various laws of this country in relation, possibly, to Medicare or the ability to get a job. Moreover, as an identity document it is only valid for the period of the entry permit; that is, when the entry permit finishes the document is, of course, cancelled. Indeed, if the visitor departs earlier than the date on that person's entry permit, because there is a requirement that that information be fed from the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs to the Australia Card authority, it will be automatically cancelled as soon as the person leaves the country.

I have never claimed that the Australia Card will be prominent or significant simply in the detection of illegal immigrants. The real contribution it will make will be as a deterrent to illegal immigrants in this country because, if it is extremely difficult for people to get employment without an Australia Card, if it is difficult for them to get access to social security without an Australia Card, of course it will act as a major deterrent for people coming into this society on the basis of those things not being easily available to them. It is for this very reason that in the United States of America at this time there is major pressure amongst all political parties to raise the standard of the United States identification cards in order to deter illegal immigration into the United States. The Australia Card will have the same effect on illegal immigration into this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Health to section 49 of the Australia Card legislation whereby an employer faces a maximum fine of $20,000 for failure to sight and record details of an identity card and/or to pass on that information to the Commissioner of Taxation. Is it the Government's policy that a householder who employs home help one day a week is an employer and that such an employer, for example, an age pensioner, be subject to such a penalty if that person fails to meet the obligations of recording and reporting under this Act?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —First of all, let me just point out that there are already certain requirements in the taxation legislation in relation to those matters. This does not in any way alter those requirements that exist already in the taxation legislation for reporting such activities. If the honourable member reads the taxation legislation he will find that they are already there.

ANSWER.PARA: Could I just say to the Opposition that there have been a number of these nitpicking questions today on details of the Bill. This Government is very firmly committed to the principles of the Australia Card Bill because, unlike the Opposition, we are in fact genuinely interested in making our tax system one of high integrity, fair to all who participate in it. Secondly, we want to ensure a social security system that delivers its benefits to those in need and we want to deter the abuse of illegal immigration in this society. We would like to see the Opposition participate in that effort. We will not alter the principles of this Bill; but, if the point of these questions is to try to make the Bill better and to improve it in detail, we would welcome the Opposition's support.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Prime Minister. Are economic indicators continuing to demonstrate the success and soundness of the Government's economic strategy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question, of course, is in the affirmative. This is because the policies brought in by the Government in all areas are relevant to the needs of the economy. I refer, firstly, to the Budget, which was recognised not only in this country but also overseas as being courageous, very significantly reducing the level of deficit and thereby reducing the level of pressures upon interest rates in Australia. Also, our wages policy has produced a significant reduction in the levels of real unit labour costs in this country of between 7 and 8 per cent. That has played its part in ensuring that the very substantial improvement in the competitive position of the Australian economy, brought about by the massive depreciation, will not be dissipated but will become a real continuation of our competitive advantage. We will ensure in the submissions by the Government in the national wage case that the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission has clearly before it this Government's view that movements in wages should not be out of line with those proposed by the Treasurer in the Budget and, as we move into 1987-88, that these should also be relevant to the sorts of movements experienced by our major trading competitors.

ANSWER.PARA: As well as being able to refer to the statistics involved in the answer to this point, I point out that it is also significant to look at the anecdotal evidence which is increasingly coming before us from manufacturers in this country, who are now saying two things: That they, by their operations, are displacing imports that had previously come into the country; and, most encouragingly, that Australian manufacturers are now going into export markets which they previously could not contemplate. I believe that the analysis given by my colleague, the Treasurer, at the time of the Budget is being sustained and fulfilled. We made it clear that we would continue through the 1986 calendar year and into the beginning of 1987 to have difficulties on the external account, but that the fundamentals of the economy would move in a way that would at least sustain the outcomes that were put before the people of Australia in the August Budget.

I point out particularly to the honourable member for Lowe that I have been talking about the positive features of the Government's economic policies which are producing these results. As far as the people of Australia are concerned, not only are they applauding those positive policies, but increasingly they are contrasting the firmness, the relevance and the principled position of this Government with the continued expediency shown by the Opposition. This Question Time has blatantly shown again the expediency of the Opposition. If one looks back over the Opposition's record on important issues of economic policy, one sees that Opposition members are totally lacking in principle. Whenever they have the opportunity to take a position of principle or one of expediency, they take expediency every time. I refer to the assets test, the fringe benefits tax and the Australia Card. All these measures are calculated to ensure that this country, this community, will have the opportunity of having the revenue available to it fairly and equitably collected so that those in need will have the opportunity of having done for them those things that need to be done. The people of this country will continually make the judgment to come down on the side of the principled policies which are producing these results and against the continued expediency of this Opposition.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I remind the Minister for Health that the Prime Minister, in his policy speech for the last election, had this to say:

QUESTION.PARA: Over the term of the next Parliament we will remove legislation and regulation which is damaging to business and employment expansion and which is not justified.

Given that firm promise, how does the Government justify adding more than a projected $2,000m to the operation of all businesses by introducing the Australian Labor Party's identity card? Furthermore, I remind the Minister of the establishment last year of the Business Regulation Review Unit to examine the cost to business of proposed Government legislation and activities. I specifically ask the Minister: Has that group looked at the full cost of the identity card to business? If not, why not?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —First of all, let me point out that the figure that the Leader of the Opposition has cited, the fantasy figure of $2,000m being used by the Opposition, has never been documented anywhere or by anyone. It has been attributed, of course, to the Business Regulation Review Unit because it made a general comment that, on average, there was a tendency for private sector expenditure for particular programs to be about double that of government. The BRRU pointed out to the Government specifically that it did not find evidence of this in relation to the Australia Card. If the management expert on the Opposition benches, the honourable member for Mackellar, understood the kinds of costs involved in the Government's program, he would know that obviously this is not a typical change of regulation which then imposes costs on the business sector. It is a much more massive cost to government because of the operation we are putting into practice. Indeed, the Australian Bankers Association, the body which is going to be most affected by the reporting requirements under this measure, has established that to the banking industry it would cost $60.6m to introduce and that the annual operating cost would be $4.6m. I point out that, as that is the part of the financial sector which will be most involved in this activity, it is a long way indeed from the $2 billion figure. In fact, in a telex to the Prime Minister and the Treasurer last Thursday the Australian Bankers Association advised that it was incorrectly reported in the Australian Financial Review on 12 November 1986 as opposing the Australia Card. The Association went on to say:

ANSWER.PARA: While the Australian Bankers Association has improved its identification procedures the issues are much broader than the identification of bank transactions. Consequently the Australian Bankers Association does not oppose, nor does it support, the Australia Card because it has not been able to evaluate these wider matters.

On the matters raised by the Leader of the Opposition the Bankers Association made its position quite clear and its costings have been worked out and discussed with government. Moreover, the suggestion has been made that small business is somehow opposed to these proposals. In fact, the Council of Small Business Organisations of Australia stated early on that it saw the need for a colour photograph to maximise the effect of the Australia Card. COSBOA indicated its support for the concept of a national identity card complete with a colour photograph at the National Taxation Summit last year. In subsequent correspondence with the Government COSBOA stated that it saw `significant advantages in the introduction of a national ID card in numerous areas'. Because the Council of Small Business Organisations was obviously involved and interested, in further correspondence it said:
Any means to increase the efficiency with which taxation is collected and welfare funds dispersed is obviously in the interests of our 130,000 constituents.

I echo COSBOA on that point. I wonder whether these people opposite are really interested in the ordinary Australians. As was pointed out in the Sydney Morning Herald this morning, it is the pay as you earn taxpayers who have nothing to fear from the identity card because the tax evasion in this society does not occur amongst the small and ordinary, the PAYE, taxpayers; it takes place amongst the bigger groups in this society.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: QANTAS AIRWAYS LTD: AIR TRAFFIC RIGHTS

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Aviation. What progress has been made in negotiations with the United States of America Government on air traffic rights for Qantas Airways Ltd, Continental Airlines Inc. and United Airlines Inc.? What impact could these negotiations have on Australia's balance of payments?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Dobell for his question, which raises the very important issue of international aviation rights and our opportunities for export earnings. The honourable member is aware that the agreement that exists for air services between the United States and Australia is of some 40 years duration, drawn up as a consequence of World War II, and it is in effect an unequal agreement. There is a heavy advantage to the United States in the provisions of the agreement and the honourable member has discussed that matter with me on other occasions. The agreement provides the opportunity for United States airlines-giants such as Continental and United-to effectively swamp Australia's international carrier. They are major domestic operators in their own right and they have access to United States domestic markets that are not available to Qantas, but the access to Australia's market is of a much greater proportion than our operator has to the United States market in terms of entry points.

ANSWER.PARA: We have had two rounds of discussions and one could only term the approach of the United States in those discussions as being one of intransigence. We are determined that when these discussions proceed-I expect in some weeks time-we will put a view for Australia that will ultimately give Australia some equity in terms of the arrangement. We are not asking for any special arrangement, we are simply asking for a fair go. We are simply asking for an equitable arrangement that will give equal opportunity to operators both in Australia and in the United States.

We often overlook the fact that our air transport industry is a major export industry in its own right. Qantas is a major operator in terms of passengers and services, which alone earned some $2.2 billion this year, more than half of that from abroad. It employs some 12,000 Australians directly and it spends more than $100m abroad both on administrative services and on the promotion of Australia as a tourist destination. The industry spends in excess of $0.5 billion annually on goods and services within Australia. Payments to Commonwealth, State and local governments are just over $100m. More than half of its total earnings of some $2.2 billion are earned abroad. The operator contributes in net terms more than $100m to the positive side of the balance of payments of this nation. It does that in a climate in which it has no price protection; it simply has a share of the market. It is up to the operator to win what share of traffic it can from the capacity, but the market it wins is within the share of the capacity available. We are not asking for any special advantage for Australia. We are asking, in terms of the agreement, for a fair go for this nation and for equity in the arrangement for our operator. We hope to see that development occur in the talks about to take place.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Health to his evasion of the question asked by the Leader of the Opposition regarding the Business Regulation Review Unit. Is it a fact that the Business Regulation Review Unit advised the Government that it was against the introduction of the Australia Card? Will he table the report given to the Government by the Business Regulation Review Unit?

—At an earlier stage of the discussions on the Australia Card doubts were expressed by the Business Regulation Review Unit in relation to the Australia Card. It then advised us on the costing of the card and we wrote to a large number of private organisations regarding the costing. In fact, most organisations did not consider it to have a very high priority as they were not particularly worried about the cost. A number of major groups came back to us and had full discussions. The best figures, in terms of a complete assessment of the costs which have been provided to the Government, are the banking sector figures which I have already given.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BARRY JONES
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science and Minister Assisting the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

—Yes.

—The Minister for Health (Dr Blewett), in answer to a dorothy dix question today, led the House to believe that I had made a statement in regard to the use of the Australia Card to prove entry. I did make a statement over the weekend. The point of that statement was that there are far less costly and bureaucratic ways of achieving what the Government seeks to achieve with the identity card. The statement makes it perfectly clear that everybody is identified on entry by a passport. There is no need to use the ID card in the way in which the Government is proposing to do so.
—Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows and copies will be referred to the appropriate Ministers:

PETITION.PRESENTERS: BEALE; CADMAN; CAMERON; EDWARDS; HAWKER; HOWARD; RUDDOCK; SHIPTON
PETITION.TITLE: Closure of Post Office Agencies
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we strenuously object to the proposal that many Post Office Agencies are to be closed. They provide a network of offices with postal and agency services to residential areas and small communities.

They serve a community need and we would be seriously inconvenienced if forced to travel further to purchase postal items or collect parcels. It would be an unnecessary expense particularly for pensioners without their own transport.

We maintain that the purpose of Post Offices should be to serve the public for the variety of services they offer. They are a community centre particularly in country areas and if necessary they should be subsidised to retain them.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House should take all possible steps to prevent the closure of post office agencies and that the network should be extended, with the Agency services they offer expanded.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Beale,Mr Cadman,Mr Ian Cameron,Dr Harry Edwards,Mr Hawker,Mr Howard,Mr Ruddock and Mr Shipton.

PETITION.PRESENTERS: BLUNT; CADMAN; CARLTON; COWAN; EVERINGHAM; TICKNER
PETITION.TITLE: Anzac Rifle Range, Malabar
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth:
1. That over 67,000 men, women and students enjoy the pursuit of their sport and recreation every year at the Anzac Rifle Range at Malabar and have done so since 1967.

2. The people of Sydney through their membership of 41 clubs headquartered at the Anzac Rifle Range together with a number of other community, school and commercial groups, the police and armed forces will lose this community facility if the Federal Government proceeds to sell the Range to private developers.
3. The Australian Bicentenary Fullbore Rifle Championships are to be conducted at the Anzac Rifle Range in April 1988 as part of the celebration of Australia's Bicentenary.
Your petitioners therefore urge the House of Representatives and the Government of the Commonwealth to retain the Anzac Rifle Range for the continued use and enjoyment of the people of Australia.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Blunt,Mr Cadman,Mr Carlton,Mr Cowan,Mr Everingham and Mr Tickner.

PETITION.TITLE: Radioactive Substances
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth. We most strongly oppose the process of Food Irradiation by radioactive Cobalt 60 or any other radioactive substance.

We oppose the introduction of regulations that will facilitate the food irradiation process by State Governments. We express our deep concern at this attempt to extend the use of radioactive substances and exposure of workers to radiation.

We call on the Government to immediately ban the importation of radioactive Cobalt 60 or other radioactive substances and to immediately disallow the regulations that permit the irradiation of food here in Australia.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Ms Jakobsen,Mr Kent,Mr Milton and Mr Scott.

PETITION.TITLE: Superannuation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth:
That many Australian wage and salary earners and self-employed persons do not enjoy secure retirement incomes provided by superannuation; and

That the Government issued in December 1985 Guidelines for the implementation of the proposed productivity decision by the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and draft Operational Standards for Superannuation schemes.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government:
1. Guarantees to every employee the right and freedom to select the superannuation scheme of his/her choice.
2. Protects the individual exercising that freedom of choice from any coercion, influence or other pressure which may be applied by any employer, association or trade union.
3. Will recognise only those schemes which provide genuine superannuation and reject those schemes which do not provide for-
preservation of benefits to retirement
vesting of employer contributions
equal employer and employee Trusteeship control to ensure security of investment.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Cadman and Mr Tuckey.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth that whereas:
1. They are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian National Flag.
2. They are aware it properly reflects immutable characteristics of Australia, namely:
(a) The Union Jack, itself the creation of three Christian Crosses, represents the Nation's historical origin and the source of its language and law;
(b) The Southern Cross on an azure blue background signifying its geographical location on this planet Earth;
(c) The large star depicting the advent of Federation in 1901.
3. They know the Flag has been a source of inspiration to generations of Australians in peace and war.
4. They recall that millions of native-born Australians and newcomers to these shores from other parts of the world have become united under its proud symbolism.
5. They are certain that any change to the Flag will produce division in the Australian community.

Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House will: Propose and pass a motion that ``the existing Australian National Flag be changed only with the approval of the Nation as expressed in a Referendum''.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Hawker and Mr Shipton.

PETITION.TITLE: Tropical Rainforests: Queensland
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
We believe that the Australian Government has failed to properly ensure that the remaining rainforests of the Wet Tropics of Queensland are both conserved and protected as far as possible.

We note that the Australian Government has received a report that is completely in agreement that this relatively small area of land is in urgent need of protection and is particularly unusual for a special site of world significance in that each of the 4 qualities considered important for a World Heritage Area are fulfilled in this region. The referees for this Report have been simply glowing with superlatives when recording the scientific, cultural and aesthetic qualities of this area.

We therefore ask that immediate action be taken to conserve this area by way of nomination of this area for World Heritage inclusion over the selfish concerns of the Queensland Government and that a mechanism be developed that would take the future course of such action out of the hands of all Parliamentarians and that perhaps the Australian Heritage Commission be given powers of self-nomination on Australia's behalf as well as powers enabling enforcement of conservation.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Fringe Benefits Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth:
That the anomalous Fringe Benefits Tax is iniquitous, inequitable and unfair on the grounds that-
it adversely affects business throughout Australia, including farms,
by creating a further tax burden it destroys incentive,
it has caused unemployment,
it is costly to administer and its complexities have caused confusion and widespread anger.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled should immediately seek the repeal of Labor's Fringe Benefits Tax legislation.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Fringe Benefits Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
We, the undersigned, are deeply concerned at the impact of the new Fringe Benefits Tax on the following grounds:
1. Its severe and damaging effect on business confidence, investment and incentive, especially in the rural, mining and small business sectors.
2. Its capacity to seriously worsen unemployment through the additional costs it imposes.
3. Its extremely negative impact on the competitiveness of export industries at a time when the nation desperately needs to improve its trading performance.

4. In that it may compel many honest and decent citizens to defy the Tax in order to preserve their livelihoods, their businesses and the jobs of their employees, thus causing hardship, the breakdown of respect for the law and discord within the community.
5. We also feel it is morally wrong for one person to be forced to pay the taxes for another.
We therefore most earnestly petition you to repeal the Fringe Benefits Tax legislation forthwith.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Fringe Benefits Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
The Fringe Benefits Tax will cause hardship to business throughout Australia, especially in the already severely depressed rural sector and in the motor vehicle industry.
The Fringe Benefits Tax will be a disincentive to employment and worse, will result in additional unemployment.

The economy of this country would best be served by policies that lightened the tax burden, not increased it, that encouraged enterprise, not stifled it, and stimulated growth, development and jobs, not prevented it.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House will repeal this legislation, and your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Peaceful Relations with People
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled to petition of Peace, your petitioners therefore pray that the Government is more committed in establishing peaceful relations with the People within and outside of Australia.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Fringe Benefits Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned electors of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the Government should cancel the Fringe Benefits Tax they intend to impose on businesses throughout Australia because:
1. The tax discriminates against charitable organisations, sports clubs, private schools and religious organisations;
2. The tax will mean employees around Australia will suffer reductions in their remuneration packages;
3. The Bill places another impossible burden of paperwork on small business;
4. The Bill is absurd in its application to Government employees, who now constitute 32% of the workforce.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Extradition (Foreign States) Act 1966
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned residents of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the humble petitioners have grave concern about recent changes in the Extradition (Foreign States) Act of 1966 which deny basic rights which have been a cornerstone of the English and Australian law for over seven hundred years. We are speaking of the right to be presumed innocent until proven guilty and the right of an individual to defend himself against his accusers. This concern has come to light during recent extradition proceedings against Messrs, Hempel and Etheredge in Western Australia.

We are concerned that because judicial protection of these basic rights has been excluded from the Act refugees, migrants, Australian overseas travellers, and visitors are at risk when they have been to (or come from) countries where the norms and practices of human rights and civil liberties are below traditionally accepted Australian standards.

We, the undersigned petitioners, therefore urge the Government to re-examine the Extradition (Foreign States) Act as amended in 1985, and amend the current Act so that the rights of the accused are once again judicially protected in Australia.

In addition, we urge the Government to refrain from entering into any further extradition treaties or proceedings under the current Act until the process of re-examination and amendment of the Act has occurred.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Allowances and Spouse Rebate
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned shows:
Graduated family allowances are of important assistance to families with more than one child.
All family allowances, whether for one, two, three or more children, have not kept pace with inflation.
There are suggestions that all family allowances should be paid at the one flat rate. This would severely disadvantage families with more than one child.
There are also suggestions that the dependent spouse rebate be reduced or removed. This would represent another blow to the family unit.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, should:
ask the Federal Government to increase the value of existing family allowance payments, and
reject any moves to change the payments to a flat rate or to tamper with the spouse rebate;
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled. We the undersigned citizens call upon all Members to pay due respect to pensioners and concessional card holders and cease the constant erosion of our entitlements by the Hawke Government.
The humble petition of the undersigned showeth:

That we strenuously object to the Government's decision to delete 45 commonly prescribed drugs (including analgesics, anti-histamines, cough mixtures and expectorants) from the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme;

That we strenuously object to the Health Minister's assertion that the health problems for which these medications are prescribed (e.g. arthritis and allergic rhinitis) are ``relatively minor, self-limiting illnesses''.
That we beg the House to reconsider these deletions from the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Fuel Prices
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned shows:
That the Hawke Government should;
1. Pass on the full benefit of lower international oil prices;
2. Not increase or extend fuel taxes; and
3. Maintain its tax cut commitments.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Hawke Government honour its commitment to the Import Parity Pricing policy.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Bill of Rights Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
That the Bill of Rights is a dangerous piece of legislation which gives us no new legally enforceable rights;
That the Bill of Rights leaves out vital rights such as the right not to belong to a trade union, the right to own private property, the right to a private education;
That the Bill of Rights gives dangerous new powers to a Federal Government Commission to investigate in private, without legal representation and with criminal penalties for refusing to co-operate;
That the Bill of Rights deals with our rights; therefore we, the people, should say whether we want it by a referendum.
Your petitioners therefore pray that you will oppose the Bill of Rights, support Liberal amendments to improve it in case it is passed, and pledge to repeal it should it become law.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions: Assets Test
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That in the light of the Labor Government's failure to act to correct the many anomalies in the Assets Test on pensions brought to its notice, the Labor Government's legislation should be repealed before it has an unduly unfair impact on pensioners.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled should immediately seek the repeal of the Labor Government's iniquitous and unfair Assets Test.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Economic Justice for Families
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled:

Your petitioners call for Government intervention to provide economic justice for families and humbly pray that whatever action possible be taken to provide some price control in the following areas, which most directly affect the family budget:
food and other essential items
petrol
rent and bond levels
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Identity Cards
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

This petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that we strongly oppose the introduction of the `Australia Card' or any other form of National Identification Numbering System.

We believe that the introduction of a National Identification Numbering System is not only totally unnecessary but is a severe threat to our civil liberties and privacy. We condemn the Government's actions on this matter, particularly as no reasonable nor responsible justifications for the proposal have been forthcoming from the Government.
We humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, should reject any proposal for a National Identification Numbering System.

PETITION.TITLE: Matters Affecting the Ethnic Community
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled. The petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth opposition to cuts in English as a Second Language (ESL) teaching, the scrapping of the Multicultural Education Program, the amalgamation of the Special Broadcasting Service (SBS) with the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC), and the abolition of the Australian Institute of Multicultural Affairs (AIMA), as announced in the Federal Budget of August 19, 1986.
Your petitioners request that the Government will review and reverse its decision on these matters.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Test Ban
PETITION.PARA: To the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia shows that:
in this International Year of Peace, 1986, the world needs a Nuclear Test Moratorium by the United States, the Soviet Union, France and other nuclear-testing powers
that such a moratorium would create a favourable climate and basis for the negotiation of a Comprehensive Nuclear Test Ban Treaty
that such a Moratorium and Comprehensive Nuclear Test Ban Treaty would-
be the first vital step to nuclear disarmament
impede the development of new nuclear weapons
decrease the reliance upon an unstable nuclear strategy
inhibit the spread of nuclear weapons.
Your petitioners therefore ask that the Australian Government be urged to
1. Use its influence with the United States Government to encourage it to join the moratorium on nuclear testing begun by the Soviet Union on 6 August 1985.
2. Use its influence in all forums to encourage other nuclear nations to join the Nuclear Test Moratorium.
3. Use its influence in all forums to encourage non-nuclear nations to demand the establishment of a Nuclear Test Moratorium and Comprehensive Nuclear Test Ban Treaty.

PETITION.TITLE: Radio Station 3EA
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia of Albanian back-ground respectfully showeth:
We most strongly oppose the use of the `Special Broadcasting Service' and the taxpayers funds for nationalist political purposes.

We are deeply concerned that the existing Albanian program on Radio 3EA Melbourne is not meeting the needs of the community. It is being used against its interests, as well as the interests of the broader Australian society.
We respectfully believe that such use of public facilities undermines Australian principles of multi-culturalism and has a damaging effect on community relations.

Your petitioners therefore, strongly urge the Government to take immediate action to ensure that the present announcers of the Albanian program are removed and replaced with community representatives.

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Free Zones
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of citizens of Australia shows:

That the people of New Zealand and the New Zealand Government have given an example to the world in their efforts to achieve a nuclear free South Pacific, and such decision being endorsed by the people at a general election.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Australian Government support the principled stand taken by the New Zealand Government and urges it to condemn any efforts by the U.S. Government to impose economic or other sanctions on New Zealand in retaliation for their stand on nuclear vessels.
We further urge the Australian Government to urgently implement its policy to promote the development of zones of peace and nuclear free zones in the Indian and Pacific Oceans.

PETITION.TITLE: Summerland Point Post Office, New South Wales
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth:
1. That the Summerland Point Post Office recently closed at short notice by Australia Post should be reopened.
2. This Post Office has serviced a community consisting mainly of the aged and young families with small children who are now faced with a five kilometre journey to the nearest Post Office.

Your petitioners most humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled should ask the Minister for Communications not to deny the 800 permanent residents of Summerland Point on Lake Macquarie the use of a Post Office.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Test Ban
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
This Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that-

(1) A cessation of the testing of nuclear weapons would break the cycle of research, development and deployment of nuclear weapons and prevent the acquisition of new and ever more lethal weapons of mass destruction. It would thus be a major and significant step towards ending the arms race and beginning the disarmament process; and
(2) The Soviet Union has extended its unilateral moratorium on nuclear weapons testing until 6 August this year and has again invited the United States to cease its nuclear testing program.
Your petitioners therefore urge the Australian Government to put the strongest pressure on the United States Government to join the Soviet Union's nuclear test ban.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: English as a Second Language Program
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Australian Parliament Assembled. The petition of the undersigned residents of Australia respectfully showeth:

By cutting ESL funding and eliminating funding for community languages and multicultural education you have attacked tens of thousands of Australian children. You have condemned these children with limited English to gross educational inequality and very dim prospects for their future.
On behalf of these children we call on you to remove this new discrimination which your budget has guaranteed by immediately restoring ESL and Multicultural education funding.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that whereas:
They are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian National Flag.

Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House will: Give speedy passage to the Flags Act Amendment Bill which provides that the Australian National Flag can only be changed by a Referendum.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Australian Republic
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. We, the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth, do humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government:
Take the action necessary to create an Australian republic on or before 1st January 1988.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Overseas Students
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Parliament of Australia assembled.

We, the undersigned express our deepest concern over the government's discriminatory policies on overseas students which were contained in the 1986/87 Federal Budget. We register our strongest outrage and opposition to:
1. The introduction and subsequent increase of overseas students charge imposed on overseas students.
2. The proposed imposition of fees to secondary and TAFE overseas students.
3. The restrictive quota system on the tertiary institutions entry.
4. The heavy-handed deportation of overseas students who fail to pay their fees in time.

The overseas students program is an important education program to promote international goodwill and peace, especially among nations of Asia and Pacific region. The above mentioned policies have adverse effects on the objectives of overseas students program. Your petitioners therefore urge that the overseas students policies in the 1986-87 Budget be immediately reviewed.

PETITION.TITLE: Kangaroos
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, Parliament House, Canberra, A.C.T. 2600. We your petitioners, humbly showeth:

That the wildlife species, in this case-the kangaroo, have a right to exist and flourish independently of human needs. For this reason alone we should not regard the kangaroo as a human resource nor contemplate commercial exploitation simply because more offspring are born each generation than can hope to survive.
Permissible cropping rates are unknown and the means of enforcing controls or protective legislation is completely ineffective and inadequate due to the widespread nature of the industry.
All Australians have a responsibility to our already declining wildlife.
We your petitioners therefore humbly pray that you will:
1. Ban the exports of products made from kangaroos.
2. Take action to see that State Governments prohibit the commercial killing of kangaroos.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Corporation: Staff Elected Director
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:

The petition of the undersigned who are staff of the ABC and the SBS respectfully showeth that: The proposed legislation to amalgamate the ABC and the SBS, together with certain existing provisions of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation Act 1983 (as amended), would have the effect of removing the present Staff Elected Director of the ABC from office before the end of his elected term, and of barring him from standing for re-election. This offends basic democratic principle.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that: The Government will remedy this situation by either, continuing the current Staff Elected Director in office until the normal expiration of his term on 15 December 1987 or, making such amendments as are necessary to the Broadcasting and Television Legislation Amendment Act 1986, to enable the current Staff Elected Director to contest an early election after amalgamation, whilst preventing him from seeking a further term immediately following the one for which the early election is held.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Jenkins,Mr Milton and Mr Tickner.

PETITION.TITLE: Secondary Allowances
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

We, the undersigned citizens of Western Australia call on the Commonwealth Government to reverse recent decisions which deny Secondary Allowances to Year 11 Students under the age of 16 years and make such allowances directly payable to students on attaining the age of 16.
This request is made on the basis that:
(i) Education benefits as part of income support benefits generally are a Commonwealth responsibility under the constitution.

(ii) It is the right of parents with children in Year 11 in Western Australia to receive the same benefit as parents with children at the equivalent stage of their education in other parts of Australia irrespective of their age.
(iii) This decision by the Commonwealth Government will impact most unfairly or the capacity of low income families in Western Australia to keep their children at school in Years 11 and 12.

(iv) Direct payment of the allowance to 16 year olds will make it easier for young people to leave home and bring more pressure on State Authorities to find alternative accommodation for them at the community and taxpayers' expense.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that you will give this matter earnest consideration.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Western Sydney State University
PETITION.PARA: To the Right Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Commonwealth in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of New South Wales respectfully showeth:

That they strongly support the establishment of the Western Sydney State University as recommended in the Parry report and call upon the House to establish the Western Sydney State University in conjunction with the New South Wales Government.
And your petitioners, as is duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Corporation: Regional Stations
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the Federal Division of Maranoa respectfully showeth that:
The ABC proposes to abolish certain country programmes from regional stations.
