DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker has received a letter from the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The hidden dangers and costs of the Federal Labor Government's proposed identity card.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spender Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Labor Party Government's identity card is a direct and fundamental threat to Australian liberties. This is not just the view of the coalition parties; it is the view of a wide constituency of Australians. Within 24 hours of the Australia Card Bill passing through the House of Representatives an advertisement, which so wounded the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett), appeared in newspapers throughout this country. This was not an advertisement sponsored by the coalition-although if we had sponsored it, we could not have done better; it was an advertisement paid for by a cross-section of our people. What does it say? It calls upon Australians to oppose Canberra's ID card and seeks the support of Australians to defeat this anti-democratic proposal. What has the Minister said of these people? As I understand him, he has said that the people who sponsored this advertisement lent their names and did not understand what they were doing. I will come to some of their names in a minute. Let us see what they said. They say:

SPEECH.PARA: The people who paid for this ad disagree on many issues.
When one sees the names, one understands that that is certainly true. The advertisement then states:
But they are all opposed to the un-Australian Australia Card and they agree that a computerised ID register is wrong.
Here are some of their objections:
The Government will number every man, woman and child in Australia.
Well, is that not right? Is that not what is intended? It also states:
You will have to produce your card to open a bank account, get a job, get Government benefits and Medicare.
Is that not right? That names but a few of the many times when we will have to produce the card. It also states:
The Government will collect detailed information about you on a computer file.

That particularly struck the Minister as offensive. He said that that really is not intended. What is intended? This is the whole purpose of the exercise. The rationale behind the system is to amass information on each Australian and to be able to cross-reference and match that information by this unique system whereby a profile of unparalleled detail can be built up on each person in this country-job history, names of bankers, building societies, companies and solicitors with whom money is held, to name but a few. The advertisement also states:
To begin with, the law will permit four Government departments to have access to this private and personal information.
How many more will follow?

The Government's original submission to the Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card, which examined the proposal, proposed that the card number be used by 13 government agencies. All we have seen is a temporary retreat to disguise the extraordinary potential of this identification system and to mask the Government's determination to extend it as soon as it can. Those were not the only concerns expressed in this ad.

But who are the people who have paid for this advertisement? They include the Victorian branch of the Australian Journalists Association; Mr Frank Costigan, QC, who probably knows more about the capabilities of computers to sort and match information and build profiles than anyone else in this country and who is committed to the war against tax evasion; Joan Coxsedge, a Labor member of the Victorian Legislative Council; Norm Gallagher-we know that he is not a member of the Liberal Party of Australia; Peter Garrett, who nearly became a senator in this Parliament and who is a Government appointee to the Australian Constitutional Commission's Advisory Committee on Individual and Democratic Rights-the Government will have second thoughts about having appointed him; Bishop Michael Challen; Frank Moorhouse, the author; Hugh Morgan; Mr Justice Staples, who is well known and does not hide his political beliefs-we know that he does not come from this side of the House; Damien Murphy and John Howie of the Society of Labor Lawyers; and Jim McClelland, former judge and former Labor Minister. To those, let me add the names of a few other people who have objected to this identity card proposal. They are the New South Wales Privacy Committee, the Federated Clerks Union of Australia, the Victorian Teachers Union and Mr Justice Kirby.

The identity card is a product of that zealous, tidy-minded, anti-democratic strain so evident in this Government. It is the intellectual soulmate of the Australian Bill of Rights Bill. Against that backdrop, let us look at some of the Government's attacks-at the two attacks that the Government makes on the Opposition. First, we have the technique of the big lie-that Opposition members are the friends, supporters and co-conspirators of tax evaders. Second, we have the proposal that there is an Aladdin's cave of revenue to be got from the identity card and that the Opposition would wilfully frustrate that end.
Let us deal first of all with the technique of the big lie. I quote from the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) on 21 October 1986 when he said:

If it chooses not to support the Australia Card, two things will have been demonstrated. Firstly, the Opposition will continue in its role in the community as a friend of the tax-cheats and avoiders and its blatant hypocrisy on social security fraud will have been fully revealed.
That is typical of the Prime Minister. I turn now to some of the lesser members of that team-the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and the Minister for Health-who, in a recent joint statement, stated:
They are unconvincing grandstanders who prefer to allow tax evasion and welfare fraud to continue unabated rather than see this Government take effective action to tackle these scourges.

This is the spirit of McCarthyism so entrenched in this Labor Government. Dr Goebbels knew it all. It is a case of: Don't worry about the truth; the bigger the lie, the more it will astonish members of the public and they will say `Surely the Government wouldn't say something like that; surely it wouldn't tell such an extraordinary lie if it were not true'. Will the Minister now explain to us what possible reason the Opposition would have to align itself with tax evaders? Does he believe that tax evaders represent the vast majority of this community? There is no reason to believe that and he knows it. What the Opposition has done is to take a stand of principle, and he knows that too. What about these individuals and organisations and the many others who have protested against the Australia Card? Are they, to use the Prime Minister's words, friends of the tax cheats in the community? Do they, to use the words of the Treasurer and the Minister for Health, prefer to allow tax evasion and welfare fraud to continue unabated? Do they, to go back again to the words of the Prime Minister, show blatant hypocrisy on social security fraud or are they simply so stupid that they can be manipulated by the Opposition? Does he seriously suggest that the men and women of such eminence, in some of whom the Government has placed high trust, are so stupid that they can be manipulated by the Opposition, so socially corrupt that they would align themselves with tax evaders or so heedless of what they are doing that they would make themselves party to an advertisement which condemns this Government's identity card proposal, which is what it is? It is not the Australia Card; it is a debasement of the word `Australia' to apply it to this card.

In truth, once again the Government did not understand what it was doing. I hope the honourable member for Hotham (Mr Kent) returns to the chamber; he is on our side. The Government did not realise that it would stitch together a constituency across this country in opposition to its legislation-a constituency of extraordinary depth and breadth containing in it many people who must be deeply disillusioned supporters of this Government because they see one thing: They see the Government's actions as being on a collision course with the values that most Australians cherish. We do not cherish the notion of an internal identity card, of an internal passport, and that is what the Minister proposes.

Before moving on to this Aladdin's cave we are meant to have, this crock of gold at the end of the rainbow, let me say something about the Government's quoting of the Opposition. The Minister will remember that a report came down in March 1986 entitled `Report of the Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card'. He should read it; he would find it most interesting. He will understand that the statements that his side is so fond of quoting are statements made by Opposition members before this full inquiry into the card and before there was a full understanding of what was involved-what was involved in terms of costs, what was involved in terms of doubts and what was involved in terms of damage to the essential liberties of people in this country. So if the Minister is going to quote us, he should quote things we have said since that report, not before it. It he wants to do it honestly-we have somewhat different views from him as to the honesty of this Government, as do many people-he should look at what has been said since and not before the report came out.

Let us get to this Aladdin's cave. What will the cost be? The Government tells us that over 10 years the cost will be $759m. Is that not a nice precise figure? Imagine coming to a figure of $759m as the cost of installing a system that will enforce identity cards against all people permanently resident in this country and that will apply very rigorous procedures against people visiting it. What are the estimates of the numbers of public servants who will be involved? What is the estimate for technology? The truth of the matter is that that is the kind of figure that public servants and governments come up with when they want to say: `We have here a clear proposal and the figure is a precise one; it must be right because if it was not right, how could it be so precise?'. It is all part of the same technique. At all events, the Government says that it can tell us that over 10 years this will cost $759m. But what of the compliance costs and what of the views of the bureau that the Government has established? We have not heard from it. The Minister tells us today that the bureau has certain doubts. Why does he not put on the table the report it has given to him so that we can know just what those doubts are? But the Minister will not, just as he will not acknowledge the Opposition's reasons for opposing this card, just as he will not say, if we are supporters and friends of tax evaders, where that places the distinguished Australians who are wholly on our side and where it places the whole cross-section of the Australian community that believes that what the Government is doing now is wrong, un-Australian, objectionable and needs to be thrown out?

Before I go to some of the things that were said before the Joint Select Committee, I would like the Minister to tell us his estimates of compliance costs. We have a mere $60m, he says, establishment costs for the banks-that is neither here nor there-plus $4.6m a year, bagatelle. What about the employers, the small and large businesses, the share and futures brokers, solicitors and companies which receive deposits of money? What about the rest of it? Has the Minister worked it out? No, he has not. He has not worked it out, and he has not tried to. He has not the least idea of what the compliance costs will be. Neither he nor the Government cares a damn because, after all, those costs will be borne by the Australian taxpayers, and nobody on the other side of the table cares about them.

What of the cash economy? We have heard great things. Here the Government and the Australian Taxation Office enter the realm of fantasy land. Let me quote to honourable members from the report of the Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card referring to what Mr Douglas Meagher, QC, who assisted the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union, had to say. It said that he:
. . . was of the opinion that an identification system would have no effect in this area--
talking of the cash economy-

On his definition, all transactions within this economy are in cash and are applied towards paying of the week's groceries, mortgage, etc. He stated categorically that these moneys are not put in the bank and are never declared.

Would he not know? Was he not the man who was so closely involved with inquiries into tax evasion for literally years? What happens? People deal in cash and when they deal in cash they do not declare it. This is the whole problem about the cash economy. If the Minister understands that he must understand that he has one essential problem.
What of social security fraud? I will give just a few quotes. According to the second report of the Joint Committee of August 1985 the Department of Social Security stated:
The overall savings likely to accrue from the new system are impossible to estimate.
Evidence from that Department before the Joint Select Committee stated:
The fact is that in our experience the main problems within the departmental portfolio are not with identity as such, but a failure to notify change of circumstances.

What of the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs? We have heard some talk about that. What about illegal immigrants? It gets even better. These are some of the quotes of Mr McKinnon, the Secretary, in his evidence to the Joint Select Committee. He used phrases such as `We have presumed', `and that is a very rough estimate', `which I must say I would not dignify by describing as more than guesswork', `We have no real way of checking that', `We would describe it as only a guesstimate' and `We probably could not find the same crystal ball that was used then'. The poor sods have lost the crystal ball! Maybe it is somewhere between the Department and the Minister's office.

The conclusions of the Committee were that the evidence should be rejected, that the statistics were inadequate and that it had little difficulty in rejecting the DIEA estimates as being grossly exaggerated. It said:
On the basis of the available data and methodology, no reliance can be placed on the Department's estimates and consequently the Committee rejects its evidence.

Those are the conclusions against which this card is being introduced. Nobody believes that the estimates about which the Minister is talking are precise; nobody believes that they are anything more than estimates which have been plucked out of the air, and nobody in the community who understands what this card is about supports it. We will hunt this card around this country so that the people understand what it is about, and more and more they will be coming out and saying: `No, we do not want it. Throw it out'. The Minister will be coming back and trying to find a reason to crawl out from under the obligation that he has imposed on himself.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Unlike the Opposition speaker who has spoken on this issue today, the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender), I am not interested in establishing the argument based on the personalities who advance it. If one looks at that document which was presented in the paper at the weekend, one will see that it is the arguments themselves that can easily be refuted. I do not believe that anybody who honestly looks at that advertisement can but reject it on the grounds of the sloppy, unintellectual comments made in it. I refer to the suggestion that, because it is written by certain men, that validates the document. What we want in this debate is an argument about the arguments; not arguments that, because these persons signed the document, somehow it is the significant word on this issue. Indeed, the only interesting comment was the opening remark by the honourable member for North Sydney. He said: `If we had sponsored it we could not have done better'. I have no doubt that that does characterise the quality of the Opposition argument in this matter. The argument that cards have to be produced on all occasions is, of course, one of the classic furphies. Most people in this society do not buy houses or open bank accounts every year. Indeed, the only relatively regular use that might be made of the card by most Australians is in relation to Medicare. Even then, if one is bulk billed one will probably not have to produce the card, because the doctor already has the details on his own list. If one does not have to collect money actually at the office, again one does not need it. The notion that the card will have to be produced day after day just shows a complete ignorance of the requirements of the card. Most of the activities for which the card is required are not activities regularly performed by Australians. In respect of the notion that we are going to collect detailed information on every Australian individual, no additional information is being added to the banks of information that the Commonwealth Government already has. That is to say, all that is required for the Australia Card is the information in relation to identity. No additional information is required. So the notion that somehow additional information--
—That is just a lie; that is a big lie.
—Order! The honourable member for Barker has already been warned today. He shall cease interjecting.
—Well, they have it for deaths and marriages.
—The honourable member for Mitchell will not interject, either.

—Indeed, when one looks at what is required on the Australia Card Register one sees that it is the sort of thing that Australians fill in at least once a month and often more, both for bureaucratic government agencies and for bureaucratic private agencies; that is, things like name, address, date of birth, sex and matters such as this. So this notion that with this measure we are compiling some detailed personal dossier is, in fact, quite incorrect in light of the information.

SPEECH.PARA: Then, of course, there is the thin edge of the wedge argument; the argument that it is all right now but in the future it will be extended. In this legislation we have made it perfectly clear that the uses of the card cannot be extended by bureaucratic fiat. They cannot be extended by ministerial regulation. The only way the uses can be extended is by a vote of both Houses of this Parliament and that is the proper way in a democracy. That is to say, if there is to be any change whatsoever in the uses of this card, the proposal has to go through the parliamentary process. So, analysing each of the arguments presented in this advertisement, they are arguments that do not stand up to any worthwhile examination, as, of course, most of the arguments advanced by the Opposition do not stand up to any worthwhile examination.

It is said that the Opposition has been much abused, that somehow members of the Opposition are men of principle standing up against the gallup poll. Let us just look at the case of this collection of men of principle standing up against the gallup poll. That pose as men of principle was completely undermined by the Opposition's own leader, who, virtually salivating, said: `This can be the fringe benefits tax and the Bill of Rights rolled into one'. That was a simple opportunistic position. That is to say, the Opposition thought: `Here we have a marvellous issue-the FBT and the Bill of Rights rolled into one'. These people claim to be men and women of principle standing up against the gallup polls on this issue. Yet we have the Opposition's own leader quite clearly showing the basis of the Opposition's opportunistic position. But we do not need its statements. What the Opposition really has to explain is not just what it said 12 months ago, but what it said six months ago. We have a real problem with what the leading figures of the Opposition said only 12 months ago. When we were beginning to make plans and preparations we were looking at what the Opposition was saying about this issue. In fact, many of the leading front bench figures were enthusiastic about the proposal. I have to quote again the Leader of the Opposition himself--

TALK.START.PARA: —How many months ago was this?
—Twelve months ago. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: I personally see some merit--

TALK.START.PARA: —What is the date of that report?
—Let us take the issues. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: I personally see some merit in having an ID card, providing the civil liberties concerns that people have voiced can be looked after and provided the Government can satisfy the community that there is some cost benefit in it. I haven't gone overboard in supporting it but, as a matter of principle, I think there is some merit in giving it favourable consideration.
But, of course, he went on from there and, bearing in mind some of the questions that he asked today, this is even more relevant. Mr Laurie Oakes then said:
But what about on the grounds of deregulation? If you support deregulation how can you support an ID card?
The Leader of the Opposition replied:
I don't think there is any inconsistency. I mean, the United States has had a social security card for generations and yet the United States economy is the most deregulated economy in the world.

In effect he was saying that he did not think there was any conflict at all between an Australia Card and deregulation, and he quoted the American example. It may be said that that was 12 months ago, and the poor things have had a lot of opportunities to think about the matter and to recognise the sorts of opportunistic possibilities that are available. But they also have to explain their position six months ago. Our friends opposite are very keen on quoting the report of the Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card. I will now quote what leading Opposition figures on that Committee supported and said. This has not been mentioned in this debate. They said:
That the integrity of a tax file number be upgraded to that of the proposed Australia Card number based on the following premises:
(i) that taxpayers with a continuous tax record exceeding five years not be required to make an application;
(ii) that the file numbers of these taxpayers by verified by normal audit process over a period of time;
(iii) that all other taxpayers and persons who do not currently possess a tax file number verify their identity to the same level of integrity as proposed under the Australia Card program,

Six months ago the Opposition members on the Committee quite clearly supported the proposal that there be an identification system, of the same integrity as the Australia Card, covering all Australians. That was the position of the leading figures of the Opposition who signed this document. Now, of course, the Opposition is even in retreat from that position. Six months ago these leading figures were prepared to support a national identification system based on tax file numbers, but such are their twists and turns that they have now abandoned that.

One really must ask whether the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt) and the honourable member for Barker (Mr Porter)-two leading front bench members of the Opposition-simply signed that document in order to defeat the Australia Card. They could not care what they committed themselves to; they could not care what the position of the Opposition was. They were simply prepared to sign that document in support of an identity system in order to defeat the Australian Labor Party's proposal. As soon as that was finished they were prepared to take no further notice of the report. That is why people all around this country are questioning the motives of the Opposition in this matter. When one looks at the Opposition's record one sees that it is not just a matter of what various Opposition members said 12 months ago; it is what leading Opposition figures were prepared to sign only six months ago. Now even that has been abandoned.

We now come to the costs and benefits of the proposal, which was a prominent feature of the remarks of the honourable member for North Sydney. Detailed cost proposals were presented to the Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card and that Committee in its document did not significantly criticise the general thrust of the cost proposals to government in that detailed documentation. On the cost side, there is no significant criticism of the cost to government of the proposals in the report. As to the benefits, the Committee went even farther. This is what the honourable member for Richmond and the honourable member for Barker said about tax, which contributes the biggest part of the saving:
Overall, the Committee accepts the estimates made by the Australian Taxation Office and notes that they may be a substantial underestimation of final benefits obtainable under the proposal.

That is the most significant part of the saving and both the honourable member for Richmond and the honourable member for Barker were prepared to sign a document only six months ago saying that the benefits were probably underestimated. Taxation accounts for the great mass of savings being made by this proposal. When we look at how much money the card will save, we see that the greatest bulk comes from the tax area which, we were told by Opposition figures, had been underestimated. On that cost point, I stress that in many ways this is the essence of the argument. We believe that there is a cost benefit; that is, we spend some $759m and we save, primarily in the tax area but also to a lesser extent and often more indirectly in social security and immigration, a total of $5.4 billion, which gives us a net saving of about $4.7 billion. If we examine this report we see that there is no serious questioning of the broad reach of those figures.

I agree that on some of the revenue points there are some criticisms. We are now told that it does not affect the cash economy. Let me deal with the cash economy issue. We have never claimed that it directly affects the cash economy, but the point about the cash economy is that significant income in that cash area at some time has to get into the financial institutions. It might go into land, which seems to be one of the ways it has gone, according to some of the work that has been done. We will be able to provide a trail for much of the money in the cash economy-not all the money and not a lot of the little money in the cash economy. Much of the significant money in the cash economy has to come into the financial system and, therefore, gets identified at that point and facilitates the whole process of following this money through. Although it does not directly address the cash economy, there is no doubt that cash economy incomes of any significance will move into the financial institutions system and into the purchase of land and houses and, therefore, will be identified as we follow through.

It has also been suggested that there are these amazing costs in the private sector. All I have to say on that area-and I repeat what I said at Question Time-is that there is no support anywhere for the fantasy figure of $2 billion that has been advanced. It is said that the Government has made no effort to tackle private side compliance. I point out what the Government has done in an effort to get on top of this problem. In part of its attempt to consult widely with business, the Government invited 116 organisations to respond in writing by 18 April 1986. Only 25 were sufficiently concerned about the cost to them of the Australia Card to reply. We contacted all the other organisations by telephone. Some further responses were received and broadly the overall assessment was as follows: The estimates of costs between these organisations varied considerably.

Many of the responses saw merit in the Australia Card. Some respondents believed that costs and benefits would balance out. A large number of organisations did not respond at all. Where reasons for non-response could be ascertained, it was generally felt that the Australia Card program did not warrant analysis, given existing priorities and resources. That is fairly understandable for most of the business sector because the only additional requirement is that they add to the information they already provide to government simply the Australia Card number, and that is not a particularly expensive operation. It is true that in a number of the areas they will be reporting to the Taxation Office for the first time, but that will occur whether or not there is an Australia Card. Even members of the Opposition, in their sort of minimal response to the problems of tax evasion in this society, might agree that it is about time that areas such as real estate sales and rental arrangements in this country were reported to the Taxation Office because all the evidence of the various commissions is that that is where much of the money we are hunting in this society is laundered-into houses, into land and into rental arrangements that flow from them. Although it is going to impose some new costs, those costs will occur anyhow because, whether or not we have an Australia Card, we will have to broaden those reporting responsibilities in those areas.

Let me say in conclusion that, having examined all the options in detail over the last 12 months, I have concluded that, although one can do a lot of little bits, the Australia Card is one of the best and simplest ways to deal with this problem and is the most effective central method of doing it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blunt Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The identification card is in fact a licence to operate as an Australian citizen. The Minister for Health (Dr Blewett), who is at the table, may think his Government's legislation will provide that licence, but in practice it will be a public servant who will make the decision to license Australians to operate within their own country. I for one am quite concerned about the consequences of that. Having had some experience with the capacity of the Australian Public Service to manage detailed administration on a very broad scale, I am concerned about the potential for error and the consequences of error for the Australian population. If some public servant, who is protected by this legislation from legal recourse, gets it wrong, a person can become a non-citizen.

SPEECH.PARA: The consequences of not having an ID card in the Australia of the future, the Australia of the Minister for Health and his friends, will be quite serious. While people may not be required to carry this ID card, they will not be game to leave home without it. The card will be needed for just about every facet of daily life-transactions at banks, building societies, credit unions and stores; to get a new credit card; to make an investment, whether with a building society or finance company; to buy a new car or anything else substantial on credit; and to buy land or a house. It will even be needed to rent a house. People who employ a gardener, someone to cut their grass, or even a babysitter, will have a look at the ID card. Of course, plumbers, electricians, gas fitters, handymen and other providers of service will have to produce their ID cards. People will not be able to move very far in this country without having their ID card in the top pocket of their shirt or in their purse. Yet the Minister says that the ID card will not affect the quality of our lives.

Quite frankly, people have not thought about what the ID card will mean. Sure, lots of honest Australians are not worried about providing details of their name, address and date of birth. But what happens when the ID number is given to persons with whom transactions are conducted? They write it down. Why? Because reports will be prepared for the Government. That is when the paperwork will start and the cost to business will start to build up. The direct cost to business in terms of completing the compliance requirements will be about $2 billion, and estimates as high as $10 billion have been made for the ongoing administration and reporting requirements. It is interesting that the Minister and the Government have ducked the issue of private sector cost, but the cost of collecting the details of the many thousands of clients for big Australian institutions will be very high. The cost to industry of allowing each employee time off twice to go to a Medicare office to get an ID card will be very significant.

Can honourable members imagine the queues when something in the order of 10 million to 16 million ID cards will be issued? There are queues in Medicare offices and Department of Social Security offices now-the queues to issue 10 million or 16 million ID cards will be monumental. The Minister can be known as the Minister for queues. He has set up queues in the hospitals and the queues outside Medicare offices will extend for kilometres. The time which will have to be spent by people in going to Medicare offices to get their photograph taken, record their signature and get their number will be significant. As for the suggestion that people will be able to make an appointment, I defy the Government or anybody else to implement that. It will be impossible to issue 16 million cards efficiently and on time. The Government knows that and knows the chaos that has ensued when this procedure has been introduced in other places.

Many people are not worried about carrying a card, but perhaps they do not understand the consequences of the card. When a transaction is conducted the number will be recorded next to it and the details of that transaction will be reported upon. The Minister said that a few new reports will be sent to the Australian Taxation Office but that the reports will not contain any more information than the Tax Office is getting now. Well, it will do a lot with the information it is getting. The card will be attached to just about every transaction conducted in daily life. It might be needed only once to get a bank account, but that number will be indelibly attached to that bank account. Once a year the bank will send the Tax Office, and maybe some other government departments, details of that bank account. Details will be provided of every other transaction, major purchase or credit transaction which has been made. The information will be compiled using the number and computers will sort it into one neat little file for John Citizen. John Citizen's entire financial life will be revealed. There will be a comprehensive dossier of every move he makes in a financial sense. Of course, it does not stop there.

People who are office bearers in voluntary organisations-a football club or a gun club-and who sign cheques for that organisation will have their ID number recorded against the financial transactions of that institution. What happens with the accounts for that club at the end of the year? They will be sent to the Tax Office and that person's involvement with the football club, gun club, pigeon club or any other social institution will be recorded on a file. So we will have not only a complete dossier on a person's financial transactions but also a dossier on the pattern of that person's life. The information will be recorded on magnetic tape and will be available for those people in the Tax Office and anybody else specified by the legislation as having access to it. We are really compiling a super-file. The ID card seems to require fairly innocuous information about an individual, but that innocuous information will be used to compile a comprehensive file on every Australian-all 16 million men, women and children.

It is interesting to read the Australia Card Bill to see what it proposes. The ID card has to be provided for the most innocuous transactions. People have to sight the card before they employ someone, including babysitters and other people employed casually in the suburbs around Australia. Of course, if the person providing that babysitting service does not have an ID card-many babysitters will not have an ID card because many of them are under 16 years of age-whose ID card will be provided? A parent's ID card. The card will have to be produced for some financial transactions which are significant and on which tax is payable. I am waiting for the Government to explain which transactions will be caught by the ID card and which will not. The Government seems to be at pains to run for cover when we ask questions about which parts of the cash economy will be caught and which parts will not be reported upon. If a minor who is employed does not have an ID card, whose ID card will be provided? The parent's ID card will be used and the number associated with that, because people under 16 years are not required to have an ID card.

It is important for everybody to understand that this proposal will significantly change the nature of the Australian community. It has been introduced without due regard to the consequences for Australia. Many people believe that ID cards are worth while in terms of stopping fraud and tax abuse and they are prepared to have an ID card in order to stop social security fraud. Everybody knows that less than one per cent of social security fraud is related to identity and 61 per cent is related to changed circumstances. Everybody knows that there will be no net benefit to the Department of Social Security from the ID card. Everybody knows that the Department does not have enough confidence in the ID card system to use it alone for identification and that the Department will require other proof of identification.

It is interesting to note that in 1985 the Department of Social Security gave evidence to a sub-committee of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure that a card system of itself poses a threat to the integrity of the welfare system and opens the door for greater fraud. I wonder when the Government will quote that evidence from the Department of Social Security back to the members of this House. The Department of Social Security recognises that an ID card system, because of its apparent intrinsic credibility, will open the door for fraud. Perhaps the Department is aware of overseas experience where the perceived integrity of the card has been exploited by corrupt people in society to manipulate the system and open the floodgates to rorts and rip-offs.

This Government has not thought through what it proposes to do with the ID card. If I had more time I would detail the massive variations in expenses and revenue projections given to the Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card. The fact is that the ID card is a very poor idea and it will not work. Its costs are indefinite and the revenues associated with it cannot be quantified with any degree of precision. There are simpler and better ways of addressing the problem. This Government is hooked on an idea and does not know how to get off. It is worried that part of its back bench will cross the floor and vote with the Opposition to stop this legislation. The Minister himself has certain questions about the integrity of the whole proposal. The Government is hoping that the Opposition will get it off the hook and stop this proposal in the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lamb Mr A.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —When listening to the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt) talk about errors, I can only say that the public would think about another catalogue, another litany of errors. They were the errors carried out by members of the Opposition when in government in neglecting to crack down on tax avoidance. They went soft on tax avoidance. Another error while they were in government was to fail to support the Australian Taxation Office when it attempted to administer the very laws that it had put into operation. All that is required by the identification system is to match up information already available to the Tax Office and the Department of Social Security with the individual's records. Other errors which members of the Opposition are guilty of while in opposition are that repeatedly, time and time again, they have opposed every single tax reform that this Government has brought in and every single effort to crack down on tax avoidance. Another error by members of the Opposition has been that they have run away from the very report of the Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card which they agreed with only six months ago. I will mention that a little later in my contribution to this matter of public importance.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) quite adequately dealt with some of the misleading misrepresentations about the Australia Card-what it can do and what it cannot do. But one strongly suspects that the real danger from legislation on an Australia Card would be if members of the Opposition were ever to become the Government. Their imagination, as displayed during the debate on that card, and their imagination as displayed here today, is somewhat terrifying. I suggest that the dangers put forward by those opposite come from that source alone. But anyone who is reasonable, anybody who is clear headed and objective and looks at the legislation introduced by the Minister, who is at the table, would know that nothing that the Opposition has suggested can happen while the legislation is in its current form.

Let us just take one example given by the honourable member for Richmond. He said that the intimate details of bank accounts, of financial transactions of John Citizen would be available to the Tax Office. The Tax Office is interested only in the interest earnings which are already supplied by the banks, building societies and financial institutions to the Australian Tax Office and have been for some time. I was rather amused by the honourable member for Richmond's concern about those who might be members of pigeon clubs and pony clubs. After hearing him speak, I can only say that he is probably a fully paid up member or life member of the mushroom club. The dangers and costs associated with the Australia Card are not those of the system itself, but of the neglect in having an integral identification system that will assist the Australian Tax Office in carrying out current laws that were in existence under the Opposition when it was in government and to carry out the duties of that office.

Let us put the Australia Card and identification system in its proper context. An identity card is an integral part of this Government's tax reform package which restores fairness and equity to the tax system. When it does that it earns the respect of the community. On one side of the coin that package is a fight against avoidance and evasion; the other side of the spending coin is that when tax is collected it will prevent welfare fraud.

It is timely in this debate on this matter of public importance to put that national identification system in its proper context. This was brought starkly into sharp reality by the verification of the House or Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure that $2 billion is not being collected by the Australian Tax Office-the same $2 billion referred to in the Tax White Paper of last year; the same $2 billion which the new tax measures are aimed at; the same $2 billion in unpaid tax that the Opposition wishes to defend; the same $2 billion which is costing each honest taxpayer $7 per week and $350 per annum. They are the hidden dangers and costs associated with this legislation if an identification system is not passed by this Parliament.

Let us see it in context and let us get our focus and our spotlight on the correct path of what is costly and what are the benefits to society. After 3 1/2 years in opposition, all we hear is carping, cant criticism without one positive suggestion of a tax reform policy or any policy to overcome tax evasion. Time and time again those opposite come in here purely to oppose, for opposition's sake. A national identification system to attack tax fraud, cheating and welfare fraud is no exception. It is no wonder that those opposite are referred to outside this Parliament as the tax avoiders party.

Let us look at a few examples of how those opposite oppose certain tax reforms in this Parliament and yet have spoken earlier of their support. Let us take the fringe benefits tax which they now oppose. On 1 October 1986 the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt) said that the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) was not going to allow the fringe benefits issue to be a great tax avoidance device. Those opposite opposed a capital gains tax in this Parliament. Yet on 29 August, two years ago, commenting on the need for a capital gains tax, the honourable member for Bennelong, the Leader of the Opposition, said: `There are arguments for a total restructuring of the system for what you have said'. That is when there is a total tax reform, as this Government has brought in, there is a place for capital gains. Those opposite oppose the assets test and yet the honourable member for Bennelong, the Leader of the Opposition, on 27 November 1983, stated: `I'm personally in favour of a needs approach to the payment of welfare'.

Time and again those opposite oppose in this House, hopefully for some cheap political gain, and yet at a more rational moment when caught in debate, where they have to put up or shut up, the public finds out that they actually agree with the reforms of this Government.

I want to mention the difficulties that the Australian Tax Office has in matching up the legitimate information that it gets to ensure that every member of the public, every taxpayer pays his correct amount of tax-not too much and not too little, but his proper and fair amount of tax. Members of the Opposition, even when in government, would not support the Australian Tax Office in ways that protected the needy and got the greedy. They wanted the Australian Tax Office to go out there under-resourced and still carry out their own legislation. Let us just make two examples: When those opposite brought in the prescribed payments system and it was impossible to carry that out effectively and quickly, they did nothing to assist-with greater manpower or even updated computer technology-the resources of the Australian Tax Office. When the Commissioner of Taxation, Mr Boucher, comes out with a simple non-partisan statement and says `If there is to be an effective attack on evasion practices throughout the community, there must be in some form a high integrity identification system', we find him being attacked by the Leader of the Opposition. At the time Mr Boucher was a Second Commissioner of the Australian Tax Office and, when made the Commissioner, the Leader of the Opposition stated: `I think his word can be very greatly relied on'. How the Opposition Leader and the Opposition change when they feel there is cheap political gain to be made.

The honourable member for Richmond, along with the honourable member for Barker (Mr Porter) from this House, who were members of the Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card, put their signatures to this statement:
That the integrity of the tax file number be upgraded to that of the proposed Australia Card number.
As the Minister, who is at the table, outlined, there are a few qualifications which did not greatly change the situation. The same statement those two honourable members signed stated:
. . . recognises that there is a serious problem in Australia with losses in tax revenue. The majority--
they were amongst them-

believes that this is best solved by attacking the problems within the current system. The majority has therefore opted for an extension of the tax file number system in order to reduce tax evasion as well as to assist in attacking social security fraud.

In their alternative proposal, which is counter to the Australia Card proposal, we see no sign of that upgraded or increased integrity of the tax file system. They have run away from the report that they signed only six months ago to which they gave such noble argument. Within six short months they are now prepared to turn their back on that report. They have a lot of explaining to do to the public and to other members of that Committee as to why they have changed their minds. They have not done so. They have a lot of explaining to do to the many different witnesses who appeared before that inquiry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macphee The Hon I.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Essentially the Opposition is opposed to the amalgamation of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation and the Special Broadcasting Service because it believes that multicultural broadcasting will suffer as a consequence. There is already evidence that the philosophy of multiculturalism is under threat. This threat comes from several quarters and is due largely to ignorance of what multicultural means.

SPEECH.PARA: During the debate on the abolition of the Australian Institute of Multicultural Affairs, several Opposition speakers demonstrated how the 1986-87 Budget cut expenditure on multicultural programs disproportionately from cuts to other programs. As was amply illustrated in that debate, the Opposition felt both anger and disquiet at that disproportionate action but, as the abolition of the Institute and the cuts in the English as a second language program were part of the Budget, we did not seek to defeat them. The Opposition is committed to the principle of not defeating Budget Bills. Rather, it believes that it is proper to analyse and, where necessary, criticise those Bills, but not to vote against them. A government must be judged on its Budget when elections are held.

The ABC/SBS Amalgamation Bill now before the House, however, is not a Budget Bill. I set out the reasons for the Opposition's approach in that regard in my speech on the estimates of expenditure of the Department of Communications on 20 October 1986, which is to be found on pages 2366 to 2368 of Hansard. The Government decided last year that a merger of the two organisations was inappropriate. The Opposition agreed with the Government. In this Budget, the Government took $1m off both the ABC and the SBS-again a massively disproportionate cut when one considers the large and demonstrably inefficient ABC and the small and efficient SBS. As this was part of the Budget, we allowed the cuts to pass. But the Bill before us is not a Budget measure. Its passage will not reduce government expenditure by one cent and its defeat will not increase expenditure by one cent. The Bill is expenditure neutral.

It is true that, in theory, one national broadcaster ought to deliver services more efficiently than two. But that is not the case at present. The real question is what type of service the Parliament believes should be provided. The SBS was created by the Parliament because it and the Fraser Government believed that multicultural broadcasting was needed and that the ABC was both unwilling and unable to provide it. The report of the Dix Committee of Review of the Australian Broadcasting Commission had shown that, and the report of the Connor Review of the Special Broadcasting Service told the Hawke Government last year that that was still the case. The Government, correctly, accepted those reports, as did the Opposition. Now the Government has had a sudden and unexplained reversal which the Opposition finds mystifying. Nothing advanced by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) or the Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy) has justified this reversal.

The Government's decision looks like a gimmick. To those who might not give the matter a second thought, it might look as though there will be inevitable savings. But to the Opposition and others who have given the matter considerable thought, it is clear that the Government is trying to create the impression that it is expenditure conscious. Once its Budget was finalised and thought likely to look less tough than the community was expecting, this gesture was announced prior to the presentation of the Budget. It was a confidence trick that has worked to some extent; for many media commentators were critical of the Opposition's consistency, rather than the Government's inconsistency. I really find that hard to understand. From the creation of the SBS by the coalition to the acceptance by the Opposition of the Connor report, we have been quite consistent. We have always favoured one national broadcaster and lamented the fact that problems within the ABC prevented it from delivering a choice of programs for all Australians of a kind which would never be catered for on the commercial radio and television stations.

Parliament has properly denied itself and the Government the right to interfere with programs. Thus, no government can or should tell the ABC to broadcast multicultural or any other programs. Members and senators may always express their views on programs, but no direction should flow from that. Consequently, there are two options open to Parliament: To continue with two national broadcasters until the ABC has become a cost-effective body willing and able to do multicultural broadcasting; or to recast the two so that one broadcaster provides the services now provided by the two. The less drastic option is the former and this was preferred by the Connor report. I gave evidence before the Connor committee and the burden of my evidence was consistent with its findings.

The Connor report thought that the question of creating one national broadcaster, whether by merger or otherwise should wait until about 1990. The committee based that view partly on the ABC's admission that it had its own problems in improving operations, and that it did not want further change before it had completed its own restructuring. In evidence to the Connor committee, the ABC said that it was particularly concerned to see that there was stability in the key areas of budgeting, financial management, corporate planning and programming. The subsequent hearings of the Senate Estimates committees of the last two years and the devastating findings of the Auditor-General would most certainly have confirmed, in the minds of the Connor committee, that 1990 was the earliest possible date for a re-examination of the situation. Moreover, I am sure that many members of the Connor committee would feel that the ultimate formation of one national broadcaster might now be best obtained by the creation of a new one rather than a merger of the ABC and the SBS.

If any more confirmation of this view were needed, it would be found in the words of the former Chairman, Mr David Hill, who became Managing Director by most undesirable means. Mr Hill said recently that the ABC has more problems than any other organisation with which he has been involved. Mr Hill also said that what the ABC needs most of all is a period of consolidation. I would agree with that. At the end of a period of consolidation one would need to assess whether the ABC, as such, had a future, or whether an entirely new national broadcasting structure was required.

Australia is one of only a handful of countries with a commitment to national broadcasting in conjunction with commercial broadcasting. Our two national broadcasters, logically, should be ultimately one. The questions are: When and how? Certainly with the ABC suffering from indigestion, it would be irresponsible to ask the ABC to devour the rich fare of the SBS, yet that is what the Government has asked, and that is what the Opposition refuses to support. The three key areas in the ABC at present are the positions of Managing Director, Finance Director and Director of Television. The position of Managing Director has been filled in a disgraceful way, the Finance Director has resigned and the Director of Television has been sacked. A new ABC Board was appointed two months before the merger with the SBS was proposed. The new SBS Board was appointed only three weeks before that announcement.

The Government clearly does not know what it is doing. If the Government gets its way, next January will see the fourth ABC Board in four years. By contrast, the Opposition has been absolutely consistent. When the Minister for Communications announced the merger, I was interviewed on the ABC's AM program on 14 August 1986. The transcript of that interview reads as follows:

Mr MACPHEE: I'm convinced that there is great virtue in the two continuing. I do believe very strongly that the SBS is fulfilling a need which the ABC has not fulfilled and if it's facing Budget cuts would most certainly not fulfil. The SBS would be totally subsumed within the ABC and that in fact would be a loss culturally and in terms of alternative programming for the Australian Public.

But there's a further point. The Government might think it's going to save money this way, But the Connor Report which the Government itself commissioned, showed that money would not be saved and indeed the work practices and staff structure of the ABC are more expensive than those of the SBS and if the SBS services were to continue it would actually cost the merged organisation more.
Mr Mark Llewellyn: But wouldn't it lead possibly though to economies of scale, more efficient use of resources?

Mr MACPHEE: No, it wouldn't. As it is the SBS operates on a shoestring budget and it does so magnificently. The ABC could do with some more economies, I believe. And I believe the management is well aware of that and on the way to achieving those. I don't believe they'd be achieved by virtue of this merger. On the contrary, it would only confuse the administrative reforms that are going on within the ABC itself.
Mark Llewellyn: But there are people who would argue it's totally extravagant to have in Australia two Government-funded public broadcasting systems.

Mr Macphee: Well, I know that that might appear to be so from the outside, but when you examine the administration of both of them you will see it's not an extravagance and I believe that the continued existence of the SBS represents a very important discipline on the ABC. And I'm convinced that for the time being Australia would be well served by having two national broadcasters, especially in television, where the programs can be complementary, each of them catering for slightly different audiences and each of them again different from those served by the commercial television stations.

The Opposition view and the reasons for it which I expressed then on 14 August, before the Budget, were precisely the same as those I expressed on the ABC programs The World Today and PM on Tuesday of last week, 11 November, when the Opposition's position was reconfirmed. The transcripts of my remarks are available to anyone who wishes to confirm that. The harsh, and grossly unfair, criticism of the Opposition's view by many in the media is matched by the overlooking by the media of the Government's lack of consistency.

TALK.START.PARA: —A total misrepresentation of us.

—Indeed, it is a serious misrepresentation of the Opposition's position. The Opposition has long since faced the fact that the SBS as an independent organisation, has proved to be a valuable discipline on the ABC, particularly in the area of what can be done with scarce resources and imaginative management. This discipline will be lost if the two organisations are amalgamated. Many of the most creative people in the ABC have had their creativity greatly curbed by the bureaucracy of the ABC, and many of the finest have left the organisation. It would be a tragedy if the same fate befell the innovators currently employed by and associated with the SBS.

SPEECH.PARA: There is evidence to suggest that the majority of Australians support the continuance of the SBS as a separate organisation. Over 65 per cent of people who made submissions to the Connor Committee of Review into the Special Broadcasting Service supported the continuation of national multicultural broadcasting services provided by a separate broadcasting authority. For many reasons, therefore, the Opposition has remained convinced that the two national broadcasters must remain. That was our policy in the last election campaign and remains so.

Under the Government's proposed administrative arrangements, SBS television will become ABC One and ABC television will become ABC Two. This sounds attractive, but there are problems because the channels do not have the same transmission coverage. The current ABC channel is transmitted in many areas where the SBS is not, and even in areas where both are transmitted SBS cannot be received by over half the audience, who do not have equipment for UHF reception. So moving programs from the current ABC channel to SBS is to disenfranchise a major part of the audience. We still believe that the Minister was wrong to take SBS off the VHF channel before the Government had made a decision about what to do with that part of the spectrum and had asked the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal to allocate a licence for it.

It is a fact that the SBS has been successful at holding its program acquisition costs on overseas markets at a constant price for the last four years. This has been achieved because overseas suppliers saw the SBS as a small organisation struggling to meet a specific broadcasting need. However, the same organisations, in dealings with the ABC, have a quite different perception of that organisation and believe that they should get fairer commercial prices from the larger organisation. Where possible, the SBS commissions local productions via independent producers. In contrast, the ABC has a philosophy of in-house production. Already some independent producers have indicated to the SBS that they will not give the same preferential pricing treatment to the ABC as they have done for a separate SBS. Prices paid for the same types of programs will, in all likelihood, increase once there is a single national broadcaster.

Moreover, no doubt SBS employees will expect the same terms and conditions as those of the ABC, and that will substantially increase costs. At present the SBS is a very lean and efficient organisation compared with the ABC. As the Peat Marwick study for the Connor report found, there would be `significant cost implications of imposing ABC employment structures, the progressive abandoning of contracting out and its replacement by fully staffed production and technical services in the ABC mode'. As an example, most SBS staff work a 40-hour week and most ABC staff work a 38-hour week. Moreover, it is doubtful whether meaningful savings can be made in shared accommodation in the short term. Both organisations have existing leases for their current premises in Sydney, where both headquarters are situated, and the SBS leases run for between three and five years. There would be massive costs in relocating the SBS Sydney operation even if there were space available.

The recent lack of consultation by the ABC with the SBS over the appointment of Mr Hill as Managing Director highlighted the ABC's lack of readiness in terms of the amalgamation. The SBS Board should have been fully involved with the decision to appoint Mr Hill, as the two organisations are, on the Government's plans, to be merged on 1 January next year and the Minister had set up discussions between the two boards. If the ABC were sensitive to SBS concerns and fears, it should have consulted SBS management. It is already obvious that the SBS would become submerged within an organisation as large as the ABC, removing the identity, efficiency and unique qualities currently provided by the SBS.

In those circumstances this Parliament cannot be sure that any legislation it passes will be respected by the ABC in its present state of desperation or management control. Therefore, we believe that it would not be responsible to merge the two organisations at this stage. Despite what the legislation says, we do not believe the integrity of the SBS programming would be maintained if the amalgamation went ahead now. We therefore hold the same view as we held when we responded to the Connor Committee of Review. We oppose the merger and are mystified about the Government's motives and reasons to proceed with the merger at this time.

I should add that we think there is virtue in formal consultation between the two boards. If, as a leak in today's papers suggests, Sir Nicholas Shehadie is made Chairman of the ABC, I hope, in the event that this legislation is defeated, that he will be chairman of both organisations and that the two boards will think of meeting once or twice a year in a joint board arrangement to try to make sure that the two organisations work in maximum harmony while maintaining their separate identity.

In opposing this Bill, the Opposition recommits itself to the SBS for the next several years and to a continuation of multicultural programs for as long as any thoughtful Australian adult could now contemplate.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has now become several years?
—Quite. For the reasons I indicated earlier--

—I indicated earlier that I believed the Connor inquiry would now look at a date beyond 1990 and I think that is the time scale at which this Parliament should be looking. I believe that the Senate might usefully explore the possibility of conferring corporation status upon the SBS so that it is not in limbo.

SPEECH.PARA: Furthermore, we would like to see the SBS expand its capacity to make local programs. We urge it to make more programs about Australia and to enter into arrangements with the Australian Film Commission and with Australian film-makers individually so that it provides more insights for Australians into themselves than does the ABC or the American-oriented commercial stations. We would like SBS radio to be more multicultural in character. At present it is too ethnic in character, although none of us would deny the entitlement of elderly Australians, in particular, to hear programs in the language of their birth. Some extra programs about multicultural Australia would be beneficial, however. SBS television already does this to a greater degree than does SBS radio, but even more is needed if its essential purpose is to be achieved. In short, SBS has to be even more about multicultural Australia than about ethnic broadcasting or being a presenter of foreign films.

In addition, SBS has, or should have, an increased educational role. We believe that SBS should be encouraged to present programs of the kind identified with the open university concept. We are confident that the loyal SBS viewing audience would grow as a result. If those and other Australian productions such as films, documentaries and other programs were shown on SBS in addition to rare screenings at esoteric, hard to reach cinemas, we are sure that the SBS audience would grow constantly. We are sure also that an increasing number of Australians will consequently accept the judgment of Melbourne's Age when it stated of SBS in an editorial on 8 November 1986:

The service enables ethnic people to maintain links with the culture of their origin while adapting to the country of their adaption. To them, its programs must be what `A Country Practice', `Sons and Daughters', or films of a VFL grand final would be to Australians living abroad among unfamiliar customs and people speaking a strange language.

Apart from the channel's service to our ethnic population, it also offers at least three values for viewers of Australian Birth. It provides opportunity for those learning a new language to hear it spoken as nationals speak it. In a typical week they may listen to dialogue in Portuguese, Armenian, French, Bengali, Italian, Russian, Japanese and German.
Its programs are refreshing because they are set against exotic scenes and unfamiliar backgrounds.

Furthermore, it gives us a deepening insight into human nature. Because of our geographical isolation, many Australians are strangers to ways of life in other countries. Some have discovered that, notwithstanding differences of nationality and language, people everywhere are the same at heart. They all experience sorrow and joy, despair and hope, pain and pleasure. Young people in Lisbon fall in love like their peers in Lima or Leongatha. Chinese and Latvian mothers feel the same agony and ecstasy when their babies are born. A Dutch or Chilean husband suffers the same grief as a man in this country when his wife dies. Criminals commit similar crimes in France, Finland and Fitzroy.

This insight into human nature, which SBS-TV provides, confirms what archaeologists discover about people in ancient civilisations. Egyptians in the days of the Pharaohs felt the same need for sex, security, significance and a sense of meaning in life as the Babylonians, the Greeks and the Aztecs-as people everywhere do today.

Although people the Bible depicts lived in circumstances different from ours, they experienced hate and love, fear and hope, awe and wonder as those whom Channel 28 portrays. A Hebrew king's pangs of guilt 3,000 years ago correspond with those of a conscience-stricken Australian. The same joy that accompanied St Paul's conversion is still felt by people who resolve to follow the Way.
Our community is richer for the distinctive programs SBS-TV provides-and especially for the better understanding of our neighbours on a planet that has become a cosmic village.
On 13 November the Age editorial added:

The Government miscalculated badly when it decided that the SBS would no longer have an existence in its own right. The SBS audience may be a small one, numerically speaking. But it is also a loyal one, and the ethnic communities identify with it. Unlike the ABC, it speaks to them in their native languages; it caters for their special interests. It gives them a measure of recognition. In such a climate, merging the SBS with the ABC-which up to that point had shown no particular interest in ethnic broadcasting-was seen by many as an act of provocation.

Politically, it makes good sense for the Liberals to oppose the merger. We have opposed it, too, for other non-political reasons. Chief among those reasons is the Government's failure to explain in detail just what it hopes to achieve by linking the two national broadcasters.

We expect, in this House and in the Senate, answers from the Government about what its reasons are and what it really believes it can achieve. Those thoughtful editorials in the Age were absolutely negated by that newspaper's senior Canberra correspondent, Michelle Grattan, when she decreed last Saturday, 15 November, that the Opposition's policy against the merger of the ABC and the SBS was `bad'. Unlike her editor, Ms Grattan feels no need to advance reasons for her judgment. Her word, to her anyway, is definitive. The Government will no doubt be pleased with Ms Grattan's pronouncement, but many Australians will be relieved to know that the Opposition is not and agrees with her editor. Thus, the Opposition coalition maintains the view which it held in government. This was summarised by the members of the Galbally Committee of Review of Post-arrival Programs and Services to Migrants-Mr Frank Galbally, Ms Francesca Merenda, Mr Nick Polites and Mr Carlo Stransky-when they said:
Every person should be able to maintain his or her culture without prejudice or disadvantage and should be encouraged to understand and embrace other cultures.

The SBS is of critical importance in achieving that objective. The SBS can do even more than it now is to combat racism. Like the ABC, it needs a period of consolidation before the creation of one national broadcaster is again contemplated.

The Opposition, therefore, stands unequivocally by its commitment to a philosophy of multiculturalism-a philosophy which the Government has abandoned in the 1986-87 Budget. In my three years as the coalition's Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, I spoke of our commitment to that philosophy on many occasions. No matter how much longer my political career might last, I cannot imagine being involved in anything more enriching, more exciting or more significant for Australia than my role in bringing to its culmination the expression of the philosophy of multiculturalism and its practical application. I am, therefore, appalled by the Government's retreat from multiculturalism in this year's Budget.

That Budget set back multiculturalism by abolishing the Australian Institute of Multicultural Affairs, led so outstandingly by that great Australian, the Anglican Archbishop of Melbourne, Dr David Penman. It also attacked the most vital multicultural educational program of all, that concerned with the teaching of English as a second language, and, after the Budget was prepared, the Government-three weeks after the new SBS Board was created and eight weeks after that of the ABC was created-decided to merge those two bodies without any practical regard for the consequences for multiculturalism.

The definitive statement of multiculturalism was that prepared at my request by the Australian Council on Population and Ethnic Affairs in May 1982. The booklet was the product of a committee led by another distinguished Australian, Professor Jerzy Zubrzycki, Professor of Sociology at the Australian National University. The booklet was entitled `Multiculturalism for all Australians: Our developing nationhood'. The report was adamant that `to make multiculturalism successful minority groups with a non-English-speaking background must not flourish on the margin and at the expense of the total society, but must be oriented towards it and be given the necessary incentive to belong to it'. To stress ethnic differences is to divide Australians from Australians. To ignore those differences is to handicap some Australians as they strive for equality of opportunity, compared with the more advantaged, and many people are more advantaged because they have the English language. Recognising differences, by way of both programs of positive discrimination and compensatory measures in the short term, can make successive generations of individuals more equal than would otherwise be the case, thereby adding to both their quality of life and their capacity to contribute to Australia for many years thereafter. A few weeks ago, Professor Zubrzycki, who first outlined his concept for a multicultural Australia in 1968, examined the current state of social policy in multicultural Australia in a lecture to Deakin University. I agree with his analysis and his model of multiculturalism, which requires `a range of programs and services that provide government grants in support of limited and largely short term projects in the area of welfare, education, language training and cultural maintenance services'.

These services include multicultural broadcasting. Multicultural broadcasting, along with all the post-arrival programs introduced by the Fraser Government, help cater for equality of opportunity, evolving Australian cultural identity and social cohesion. It is a policy of integration, not assimilation. We have rejected hitherto the melting pot theory which characterised the United States and left every successive wave of migrants at the bottom of the pile.

The core culture of modern Australia came from England, but other strands of our culture came from the Aborigines as well as from Scotland, Ireland, Wales and the rest of the world. It is significant that the core culture of our language, our parliamentary system and our judicial system came from England, not from the United Kingdom. The United Kingdom itself is a multicultural society and it is important for us to recognise that. So, indeed, are many societies around the world, some more successful than others. It is integration around that core culture that is far more just to the individual and beneficial to the nation than are policies of assimilation in which disadvantaged people suffer very severely because of their lack of introduction to the language or culture.

As an illustration of what I say, the Minister has slipped across a note saying: `What about the O'Macphees?'. It is a fact that the Duffys and the McDuffys were not far apart and the McDuffys were part of the same clan as the Macphees, who came from the little island of Colonsay, in the Irish sea, from which on a clear day one can see the coast of Ireland and the coast of Scotland. They disliked the English as much as the Irish did. The fact is that a reasonably harmonious multicultural society was forged from the arrival of Celts such as the Irish, the Scots and the Welsh, and they have been added to in this multicultural society of ours until, more recently, we have had the enrichment of people from Indo-China and other parts of Asia. Integration around that core culture is the key to social harmony, cohesion and equality of opportunity. The Government must rethink its direction in the area of multiculturalism, for it is that concept which faces the issue of getting the minority ethnic groups into the gradually maturing mainstream. Other policies lead to friction and division, not social cohesion. A further consolidation period for the SBS will greatly assist the process of integration and ultimately help us to have one national broadcaster catering for all Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charles Mr D.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am glad that at last we have a definitive approach from the Opposition. We now know that it agrees with an amalgamation of the two national broadcasting networks at some stage-however, not just now. It is a little like when one says: `Yes, I would love it, but not just now, Henry'. One cannot have it both ways. One cannot say that one would like it somewhere down the track when things get a little better as one perceives them but that one does not want it just now. That is absolute nonsense. When does the Opposition perceive that the national broadcaster or broadcasters will be in such a position? I maintain that the Opposition is going in completely the wrong direction because in another five to ten years it may be virtually impossible to merge the two broadcasters as they grow from strength to strength and as the Special Broadcasting Service as it exists now expands and acquires more facilities. At that time the government of the day, whichever that may be, would say `thus far and no more' when faced with a budgetary situation of maintaining two national broadcasters, both at that time having budgets in the hundreds of millions of dollars. One would go.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has moved this as one of its reasons, on which I will elaborate in a moment, for the continuation of multicultural broadcasting. If multicultural broadcasting were allowed to stand alone, in time, whether it be 10, 15 or 20 years, it would wither on the vine and disappear.
