This will strengthen multicultural broadcasting in the long run. It will cement it into our national network. The honourable member for Goldstein (Mr Macphee) said that he wants some answers. I am sure it will be like a birthday for the Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy) to give him those answers in his summing up. If I can jump the queue, one of the reasons that this Government has introduced the ABC/SBS Amalgamation Bill is that in the next decade it will save tens of millions of dollars. I am not talking about the saving of $2m this year-I admit that is nothing in itself-but we will save vast sums of money in the long term. As I have already said, SBS will want to expand its services, equipment, et cetera. Human beings being what they are, we would see the two networks expanding independently. Whilst they stand alone that will occur. They must be brought together to save the costs of services, manpower, equipment and facilities in the next decade, and that will amount to some tens of millions of dollars. That is one of the answers that I am sure the Minister will give.

As I have already mentioned, it will cement multicultural broadcasting into our society. It is not there at present. Indeed, the Opposition is saying that it wants to take away the charter that is in this legislation for multicultural broadcasting and diversity and replace it with nothing. Virtually, that is what exists at present-nothing. There are no guarantees now. There is no great wad of legislation relating to multicultural broadcasting, what it has to do for the country and what the SBS can or cannot do. In some respects that is being written into this charter. Indeed, in a private conversation with the Minister the other day, in relation to this charter I said: `People have attacked you from both sides, saying that the charter did not go far enough or that it has gone too far'. I am sure the honourable member for Wide Bay (Mr Millar), a long-standing and experienced member of this House would know that when one has reached that point one knows that one must have done a good job by steering the ship somewhere down that delicate middle line if both sides are not 101 per cent happy with what one has done. The charter specifies the nature of multicultural broadcasting, and the new corporation has to take note of it. That is clearly spelt out in the charter, and I think it is on that middle line.

The extension of multicultural broadcasting is another asset of this legislation. At present and in the foreseeable future multicultural broadcasting will not extend. What government would come forward in the economic circumstances which exist and which will be reasonably tight for a number of years and say that it wants multicultural broadcasting in Darwin, for example? It would not spend tens of millions of dollars in Darwin, Albury, Ballarat or Bendigo-one could name a number of regional centres-or Wide Bay. That will not occur, but it will be able to occur under the new corporations, Australian Broadcasting Corporation 1 and Australian Broadcasting Corporation 2. Quite obviously the new broadcaster would be negligent, if there were only the one service-for example, in Darwin-if it did not carry some multicultural broadcasting after this legislation has passed through this House. In many areas of Australia we will see, as a result of this legislation, an extension of multicultural broadcasting that would not have occurred for a long, long time under the existing arrangements.

The honourable member for Goldstein talked about increased local program production for the SBS. He also talked about more education programs in regard to the open university concept. From where would SBS get the money to expand greatly, if it were to do it properly, its education programs or local programs if it were allowed to stand alone? In the six years since I became a member of this House I have spoken about a combined network-it has happened a little sooner than I thought-an ABC 1 and an ABC 2 which will incorporate multicultural broadcasting. In time to come on the new network we may see an extension of education programs, open university programs, and so on, which I would support. We will get that only if we have an integrated network. If we have two separate networks they will go off in different directions. We cannot make them take note of each other's programming if they are totally separate organisations; it is absolutely impossible.

People say that the ABC has not done anything about multicultural broadcasting in the last few years anyway and that it should be made to do something. I put the point that, whilst I agree that the ABC has not been good at multicultural broadcasting for a long time, since the introduction of the SBS in the last six or seven years it would have been a dereliction of its duty if it had gone into multicultural broadcasting because at present there is a whole network for it. Why would the ABC provide any multicultural broadcasting if there is already a total network for it? I am sure one could ask the same question of the Channel 9, Channel 7 or Channel 10 networks. They would come back with the same answer: `Why should we be doing it? There is a whole network for it.' The ABC has a perfect comeback at present. With the integration that will occur, with the new Board, with the new Managing Director and the Chairman who will be appointed in the not too distant future, we will see a vibrant network of ABC 1 and ABC 2. One cannot say that we will set it up somewhere down the track when we think things will be better; we have to look at doing it now and give the organisations time to combine together. Sure, there will be a little bit of a rocky period while they work things out and get their act together. But they have a few years to do that and we will then have a good and genuine dual national broadcaster.

I mention one other thing: Very few countries in the world have a national broadcaster funded out of Budget. That is another point that may have to be taken up at some other time. But, from my research, no other country has two. I could put it another way: Only one country in the entire world has two-Australia. It is nonsense to say that this measure will not save money and that multicultural broadcasting will suffer. I have had discussions on this matter. Not only myself, but also the Government, particularly the Minister, have had numerous discussions with the groups within the ABC, the SBS and the ethnic communities at large over the last few months. As many guarantees as possible are provided, either in the legislation or else they are guaranteed with the co-operation of the people at the existing organisation. Some of the guarantees, such as those regarding programming, cannot, from a practical viewpoint, be put into the legislation. One cannot guarantee that Yes, Prime Minister will be on at 7.30 every Monday night or some such nonsense as that. Some people are saying all sorts of silly things like that. That cannot be guaranteed. One cannot get into programming. One has to leave that to the managing body, the management of the Corporation. I am sure that that will occur.

Unfortunately my time has just about run out. It is worth noting that radio stations 2EA and 3EA will continue to exist. There is absolutely no thought of tampering with them at all. The multilingual position in those radio stations will continue. They have been of great service to our ethnic communities, and that will continue absolutely. The new charter guarantees that. The Minister for Communications will, I believe, relate some extracts from an editorial in today's Il Globo, which is one of the more famous ethnic newspapers, the Italian language newspaper in Victoria. That editorial supports the Government's position. Today's Il Globo slams the position of the Opposition and shows it up for what it is. I think that is worthy of note, and the Minister will elaborate on it. It comes from one of the most famous and long running ethnic newspapers in this country. For all the reasons that I have outlined, and many more that members on this side, including the Minister, will outline, I support the legislation before the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jull Mr D.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Isaacs (Mr Charles) and I share quite a deal in common, and it is not uncommon for one of us to follow the other in debates in this House on broadcasting legislation. In fact, one of the things that we share in common is that we both cut our teeth in the world of commercial television. I am absolutely amazed-or even, perhaps, horrified-if the honourable member for Isaacs believes some of his own rhetoric such as he has given this afternoon in terms of the capacity of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation to adapt at this stage to taking over and working in conjunction with the Special Broadcasting Service, because certainly I do not share that sense of optimism that he has at a time when the ABC is probably going through the most difficult period in its history. I will come back to that a little later on, because I think there are some very real difficulties in the ABC at the moment that must be addressed before we can ask it to take over an organisation such as the SBS. I was interested in the speech of the honourable member for Isaacs because he referred to this morning's editorial in the Italian newspaper. I would like to quote from the editorial in the Greek newspaper Neos Kosmos dated Monday, 8 September, in which it is said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Labor MPs, who are elected in seats with big migrant population, would err if they tried to `explain' to migrants the merger of SBS and ABC. The decision was both silly and dishonest. The migrant communities will not be convinced by excuses. Migrants feel like being victims of `rape'. They are enraged because the rapists are persons who they trusted.
Instead of trying to convince migrants, these `likable' MPs should try to convince Hawke, Keating and Duffy that the merger of SBS and ABC is not acceptable to migrant communities.
I quote another statement, this time from the Melbourne Age of 15 September. The report is about a rally that was held in the Melbourne suburb of Brunswick over the SBS-ABC merger. The report stated:

Dr Andrew Theophanous, the federal member for Calwell, said the SBS was a symbol which the migrants could not and would not do without. He stressed that the decision was the fault of the Government, not the Australian Labor Party.
`We've heard a lot about uranium but merging the SBS and ABC is a breach of Labor policy too and we're going to hear a lot more'.

To let honourable members know the concern that is in the community, I will read just one more quotation. On 15 August the Premier of New South Wales issued a Press release expressing his concern over the ABC-SBS amalgamation. It said:
The Premier . . . would be making the strongest possible representations to the Prime Minister clearly defining his objections to any amalgamation of SBS and the ABC.

I would contend that there is some very real concern within our ethnic community about just what the future might be for the SBS. The SBS proved itself in its early years to be a very lean and efficient operation. I was a member of the then Government's committee on communications, which went through some rather difficult periods deciding whether or not we should go ahead with the SBS as a separate entity or whether in fact at that stage we should put it in with the ABC as part of its operation. I am sure that honourable members will recall the debate that, for every day for weeks on end, was broadcast over such ABC programs as AM and PM, and the objections that were being put up regarding the capacity of the ABC to provide this particular service. Could one ever forget the fact that the ABC, when it came to the Government, said that to establish an SBS network within the ABC would require some $50m in capital costs, and a similar figure for its operating costs. I suppose that this is really at the heart of what is wrong with the ABC today. What happened? Private consultants came in. Ron Fowles, who was an established figure within the commercial organisation, came up with establishment costs of $4.3m-not $50m, but $4.3m-with an annual operating cost of some $6m.

That was the argument then. Unfortunately, I do not think that things have changed terribly much at the ABC even now. At a time when there are difficulties with the Board and the General Manager, when we find that the Finance Director of the ABC has just walked out and the Director of Television has been sacked-while we have this turmoil within the ABC-we expect it to take on the added responsibility of this merger with SBS. I do not really see how it can be done.

The honourable member for Goldstein (Mr Macphee), the shadow Minister for Communications, pointed out some of the difficulties in terms of the two organisations working side by side because of their different conditions of employment. It is a fact that the SBS personnel work a 40-hour week; it is a fact that the ABC staff work 38 hours a week. Do we honestly expect at this stage that the ABC Staff Association and the other unions involved with the ABC will allow the SBS personnel to work under any lesser conditions than those under which they themselves presently work? I think that really this merger will create a monster for the Government. I think it is absolutely critical at this stage that we let the whole of the ABC process settle down and let the organisation work itself out before we force this particular merger on it, because there is no doubt that the problems facing the ABC are widespread and very deep seated.

I know that in the newspapers at the moment there is the continuing controversy about the future of the ABC orchestras around the country. What exactly will happen to the ABC orchestras? Does the Minister know? We know that the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment (Mr Cohen) has been meeting the State Ministers for the arts for about 12 months to determine what will happen. We know that at this stage there is all sorts of talk about hiving off various operations of the orchestras, in terms of bookings and promotion, to private organisations. That is probably not a bad thing anyway. But we do not know whether there will be any sort of privatisation of the ABC orchestras. I doubt very much whether that would happen-I certainly hope that it would not-because basically that would mean that ABC orchestras would be left in only Sydney and Melbourne. We must find out from the Minister exactly what is happening in that area, because already people in the ABC concerts departments have lost their jobs or have left. This is just another typical example of the turmoil that is facing the ABC at the moment.

Mr David Hill, who has recently taken on the ABC, has a huge job in trying to sort out the mess that is the ABC. I am not going to stand here and denigrate the ABC. I hope that we will be reasonably constructive because I think that one of the very real difficulties with the ABC is that over the years, like Topsy, it just `growed'. There has never really been the sort of management structure in the ABC that can give it any sort of positive direction, that can introduce proper managerial techniques to put it on the right track and ensure that we get efficiency for the ABC dollar. If Mr Hill does nothing more than put the ABC on the right track, well good luck to him and I am sure that the whole of Australia will congratulate him.

The ABC has the potential to be the greatest broadcasting organisation in the world. There is no doubt about that. Much of the program that the ABC transmits is fine material indeed. But when one looks at $480m as the annual budget for that organisation, one realises that we as taxpayers must ask whether we are getting full value for money. It is a lot of money. If we think that ABC techniques which are presently employed will not extend into the SBS networks, then we have another think coming. That is the aspect that worries me. While the SBS is a lean, efficient organisation providing a tremendous alternative service, we do not want to pollute it at this stage with the difficulties that are embracing the ABC. In the interests of efficiency and the future of the tremendous job that the SBS has been doing and its future growth, I suggest that we should let things settle down now. We should let the SBS go on as a continuing entity until such time as we get on top of the ABC managerial difficulties, until such time as we have a settlement of all the internal problems that are afflicting the national broadcaster. Then we might be able to look at a situation in which the SBS can most sensibly go into that ABC operation.

There is concern in the ethnic communities right throughout Australia about what is presently happening. We should never forget that 40 per cent of the population of Australia either were born overseas or have at least one parent who was born overseas. We should never forget either that 25 per cent of the population of Australia have ethnic roots in non-Anglo-Celtic countries. That is the real basis of what the SBS is all about in enhancing that multicultural community that we have in Australia. Rather than restrict the future of the SBS, as may happen under the Government's plans as indicated by the honourable member for Isaacs I believe that it would be a relatively simple operation to expand the SBS.

The question that I would like to ask the Minister is: Why are SBS signals encoded outside the metropolitan area? Why should it happen? Is it because there are certain commercial television operators who are scared that the variety and quality of the programs being transmitted by the SBS will provide greater competition with those commercial networks? That is one question that we want answered. What is the technical reason for the encoding of those signals? I cannot see any. In fact, there would be a very great capacity to spread the whole SBS signal around Australia. There is another point as well: Even though we tend to think that the ethnic communities of Australia congregate in capital cities, there are other areas of Australia that have very big ethnic populations and for relatively cheap outlays we could extend that SBS signal extensively. My request to the Government is: Think again. Do not ruin the future of SBS while the ABC is in turmoil. Let us try to get the ABC right before we look at that sort of amalgamation and then we will really have a capacity to expand the SBS and let it reach its full potential.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Milton Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking on the ABC/SBS Amalgamation Bill 1986, I take the opportunity to express my misgivings about the legislation. I have listened carefully to the Government's view that the amalgamation of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation and the Special Broadcasting Service is necessary because Australia can no longer afford to support two separately funded government national broadcasting networks. I must admit that I had concerns that funding problems might inhibit the future growth of SBS. However, one problem as I see it is that nowhere in the amended Bill is there any real guarantee that the ABC will, as the Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy) stressed in his second reading speech, maintain and enhance the existing multicultural programs.

SPEECH.PARA: It is true that in Part II of the Bill amendments are included in clause 4, which sets out the functions of the Corporation, to include multicultural broadcasting and television programs. The trouble is that the broadcasting and television needs of Australians from non-English speaking backgrounds are dependent upon the opinions and understandings of the multicultural character of the Australian community held by the members of the Board of the Corporation. In consequence, it is understandable that the leaders of the ethnic communities are unhappy about the amalgamation because they have no faith in a Corporation which, in the past, showed itself to be so unsympathetic to Australians from non-English speaking backgrounds that it was found necessary to create the SBS to meet the broadcasting and television service needs of ethnic communities.

I am pleased to see that clause 5 of the Bill provides for amendments in relation to the Australian Broadcasting Corporation Advisory Council to include persons from non-English speaking backgrounds, and time alone will tell whether the councils-whether they be national, state, Territory or regional-will have sufficient clout to ensure that the Corporation does indeed uphold its obligations to the ethnic communities of Australia.

Clause 6 of the Bill amends the structure of the Board of the Corporation, and it is in relation to the appointment of the new Board that I wish to address the remainder of my remarks on the legislation. The Minister has pointed out that increasing the number of Board members from seven to 10 non-executive members, plus the managing director and the staff-elected director, strengthens the Board to enable it to carry out its wider responsibilities in relation to ethnic broadcasting. He has also indicated that, as the new Board will operate from 1 January 1987, the appointments of all the existing non-executive directors will cease and new appointments will be necessary from 1 January 1987. In amalgamating the ABC and the SBS, the Government will of course need to ensure that the staffs of the two organisations are given the opportunity to take part in the elections of the staff-elected director at the earliest practicable opportunity. The present holder of the office is Tom Molomby, who has performed exemplary work, in my view, in his capacity as staff-elected director and who is in his second term of office-a two-year term which is due to expire on 15 December 1987.

It is also important to note that staff-elected directors are not allowed to hold office for more than two terms, which, I understand, was at the express wish of staff members when the position was created. The Bill accordingly provides in clause 29 (3):

The Board shall, as soon as practicable after the amalgamation day, cause elections of a person as the staff-elected Director and of a person as a deputy of the staff-elected Director to be held and, if those elections are held before regulations are made for the purposes of sections 13a and 13b of the ABC Act, those elections shall be held in such manner as is approved by the Board.

I should mention at this point that I have taken a particular interest in the position of staff-elected directors in all organisations, as I believe it is an essential first step in the process of workers' decision-making which is so important for industrial democracy, of which I am a strong supporter. Also from a practical point of view, as a staff-elected Council member of the University of Melbourne from 1978 to 1980 before I became a member of this House, I am aware of the vital importance of staff being properly represented on the governing bodies of the organisations in which they work. In this respect it caused me great concern to find that the ABC Staff Association is most unhappy with the proposed election processes for the new staff-elected director, as indicated to me in a letter from the Federal President, John Cleary. I and other members of the House have over the past few days lodged in the House petitions containing more than 1,200 signatures from the staff of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation and the Special Broadcasting Service, and more are arriving day by day. The petition reads as follows:

The proposed legislation to amalgamate the ABC and the SBS, together with certain existing provisions of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation Act 1983 (as amended), would have the effect of removing the present Staff Elected Director of the ABC from office before the end of his elected term, and of barring him from standing for re-election. This offends basic democratic principle.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that: The Government will remedy this situation by either, continuing the current Staff Elected Director in office until the normal expiration of his term on 15 December 1987 or, making such amendments as are necessary to the Broadcasting and Television Legislation Amendment Act 1986, to enable the current Staff Elected Director to contest an early election after amalgamation, whilst preventing him from seeking a further term immediately following the one for which the early election is held.

In addition to the requests from the staff, the Chairman, David Hill, soon to become the Managing Director of the Corporation, also expressed his concern. In a letter dated 14 October 1986 addressed to the Minister for Communications in which he outlined the problem he ended as follows:

I believe that it is essential to avoid the unanticipated result that Mr Molomby's term is both cut short and that he is excluded from contesting the early election, and I seek your support for legislation that will prevent this.
Because of the short time remaining before legislation must be introduced, I have also arranged for a copy of this letter to be tabled at the 15 October meeting of the Steering Committee.

As I mentioned previously in my speech, I appreciate that the Government had two important considerations to take into account in framing the legislation in relation to the staff-elected director. First, it was necessary to take into account the initially expressed view of the ABC staff that the staff-elected director not hold office for longer than two consecutive two-year terms. Second was the need for the SBS staff to have the earliest opportunity to participate in determining who the staff-elected director should be. Unfortunately in framing the legislation the Government has alienated an important section of the staff. I accept the Minister's personal assurance that there was no intention of alienating the staff, but the plain fact is that it has occurred and the petitions are an eloquent testimony. My examination of sub-clause 3 of clause 29 of the Bill has led me to the view that there is one particular part of the clause which would engender suspicion on the part of the staff. The part of the sub-clause I am referring to reads:
. . . and, if those elections are held before regulations are made for the purposes of section 13a and 13b of the ABC Act, those elections shall be held in such manner as is approved by the Board.

It would appear to me that, if I were an ABC staff member, reading that phrase would lead me to believe that the intention of the Government was to encourage the Board to initiate the election with undue haste before the necessary regulations have been compiled. The Minister has assured me that the Government has no intention of attempting to cut short Tom Molomby's term of office in a hasty manner. It is the view of the Government, as expressed to me, that when all the necessary election formalities are concluded and the newly-elected director is able to take office it will for all practical purposes be very close to 15 December 1987, which is the date of expiry of Mr Molomby's term of office. I had hoped to persuade the Minister to delete from the sub-clause the phrase which would circumvent the regulations, but unfortunately I was not able to persuade him or sufficient of my colleagues to provide an amendment to the legislation. One has to look at the numbers.

My main purpose in bringing this matter before the House today is to seek an assurance from the Minister, and hopefully to signal to the new Board, that there is no wish on the part of the Government that Mr Molomby's term of office as the staff-elected director be deliberately cut short. I should perhaps add that the circulation of the petition signed by the 1,200 staff members, and more, was authorised by a number of well-known radio and television personalities known to ABC listeners and viewers as people of integrity who are concerned to provide radio and television programs which meet the needs of the diverse Australian population. In addition I understand that, apart from the staff union itself, other unions such as the Australian Journalists Association, Actors and Announcers Equity Association of Australia, the Australian Theatrical and Amusement Employees Association, the Musicians Union of Australia and the Senior Executive Association have also expressed concern over the matter. I am not quite clear regarding the position of the Australian Clerical Workers Association although I believe that it too is not happy with the situation.

Bearing in mind the circumstances which I have outlined, I hope that the Minister can give the assurance I am seeking, as I believe that there is a strong chance that a few reassuring words from him could allay the suspicions of the staff members concerned and would help to smooth the path towards an amalgamation which, for the sake of all the ethnic communities concerned, should not begin on a sour note.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cowan Mr D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that all members of this chamber and their ancestors could say that we are all from ethnic origins. Therefore, we are certainly interested in the progress that has been made with respect to the Special Broadcasting Service. It is of particular interest to note the legislation before the House and to see that the Government intends to combine the SBS with the Australian Broadcasting Corporation. My reason for speaking today is to join with the honourable member for Fadden (Mr Jull) in what he said with regard to the ability of the ABC to engage itself in and address itself to its added role. I can recall reading for years now almost week by week about the problems being determined with the ABC Board, within the administration, and also within the staff, and it is only normal that one should question the ability of the ABC to look after its expanded role.

SPEECH.PARA: I represent a country electorate in which many ethnic people reside. The other day I opened the centenary celebrations of a German family where people of German origin from Newcastle were dancing and entertaining us. It made us appreciate that many people in this country have a realisation of their birth place and want to keep the culture and the ways they were taught in those early days. It is always interesting to look at the development of people within any country. It takes some years before people of ethnic origin are able to assimilate properly into the way of life we have in Australia. We term it multiculturalism, and it is, but we often see families in which the parents came directly from Europe or Asia. The children are reared basically on the culture of the two parents, but in the next generation there is a change and they become more accustomed to our Australian way of life. So I think we have to be a tolerant population. We as a parliament have to be very tolerant and accept that there is a period before a person becomes-I will not say a `true' Australian, because that is the wrong word-an assimilated Australian, accustomed to our way of life, to the Constitution, to the way we live under the Crown and to every other aspect of our Australian way of life.

I believe, with the knowledge I have of the Special Broadcasting Service, that it has done a particularly good job. Before we criticise it in any way or attempt to change its modes, we should look at the reasons why it was formed. It was formed to provide an outlet and a form of education, a form of information generally, for the ethnic people in Australia which would allow them to know more about Australia and what is happening in the native lands they have left. It has fulfilled a very purposeful role so far as we are concerned.

Like the honourable member for Goldstein (Mr Macphee) I have no great objection to the amalgamation of the SBS with the ABC in time. That is the important fact-in time. I ask the Government whether now is the opportune time, after all the problems we have seen within the ABC, to thrust upon the ABC this greater responsibility which will be given to it. I do not know whether there will be a saving in funds. The Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy) has said that there will be, otherwise he would not have brought the matter before Cabinet.

TALK.START.PARA: —We will.

—The Minister signifies that there will be. From past experience, we do not know exactly whether there will be a saving of funds until we see things in reality and until we see the operation of the new system of the ABC. I would love to see a greater consolidation of the new role of the ABC, covering its present responsibilities, before we give it the greater responsibility we are about to. We do not want to see any reduction in the service that is available to ethnic people now.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me say a little about the service which is available. It is a service of education, so far as ethnic people are concerned, as they are able to understand the language, they are able to find out some information about the countries they have left and news of what is happening there, and so they are able to know what is happening to the relations that they have left behind. I believe that more English language programs should be available, particularly programs about the Australian way of life. More programs should be shown about agriculture, the mining industry, commerce and industry generally, schooling, and what goes on in the very large cities compared with the life we lead in the country districts of Australia. More programs should be shown about the north of Australia, our desert country and marginal country. It is important that we get this message across to the ethnic people about or ancestors who founded the Riverina, the Cowper area and other areas of Australia-the people who went out and pioneered and settled those areas. Our country needs more settlers and pioneers of the calibre of the people who bred us.

None of us can criticise the qualities of the great majority of migrants who have come to Australia. I do not care where they come from-they come here eager to work and to participate in the way of life that our forefathers have won for us. That is the foundation of things I want to say about this. I do not want to see destroyed a system which is providing education and information for the betterment of those people who are listening to ethnic radio. The network is a good one, but it does not cover the whole width and breadth of Australia. I suppose that the ABC would hope to do that, but from what the honourable member for Goldstein said there is doubt about whether this can be done, even in the foreseeable future.

I am anxious that ethnic radio should be expanded so that migrants can tell their relations and friends who will come here of the great values and safeguards that we have under the Australian Constitution. People have come here from countries where they have had personal threats against their way of life. They want to come to Australia and we want to welcome them here, but we want to be able to give them the information to take them along that long road before they become the same as we are in our English speaking way. These matters are very important.

I am sure that the Government and the Minister-he is a sensible man-realise that this legislation will integrate the SBS with the ABC, an organisation which is in doubt. It is in doubt because of its administration. A previous speaker spoke about electing staff to the new board and the method of election. I am doubtful whether the staff should have a representative on the new board of the ABC. The Minister may be creating a precedent with this, but I will say something about that in the television debate. I know of State organisations where a government has given the staff one, two or three representatives upon a committee of 12 or 15 and all they do is fight amongst themselves. The staff of the ABC are doing it now. A Government member said that he wants certain undertakings from the Minister about the election of a representative of the staff to the ABC board. This should not be the case. The staff are divided because of political reasons, which will divide the board of the ABC. It has just happened-I am sure it has. It has been mentioned by the media that the staff of the ABC are divided. The Minister does not want that, I do not want that, the Government does not want that and the Australian people do not want that. Sir Nicholas Shehadie was the Chairman of the SBS-a tremendous man. I hope that the rumours are correct, because he is a man of ethnic origin.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are.

—The Minister assures me they are correct. I am delighted because Sir Nicholas Shehadie is a great sportsman and a great Australian and I know that he will contribute to the board of the ABC. If the Minister keeps the appointments up to that calibre, there will be no trouble with the future of the ABC because we will have people of ability who will be able to handle the ABC and the board will not be divided.

SPEECH.PARA: To sum up, I want to say something about my concern as to the ABC being able to absorb the SBS and to do it the duty to which it is entitled after the way it has been built up over the years and the excellent service it has given to assist the ethnic people of Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Saunderson Mr J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the ABC/SBS Amalgamation Bill. I have supported the amalgamation of the Special Broadcasting Service and the Australian Broadcasting Corporation for some time, even before the Budget decision. It is an absolutely rational situation to introduce. Whilst there may have been-I think there probably was-a justification for the creation of an independent organisation to begin multicultural radio and television programs, that justification has long since disappeared. We have heard honourable members saying in the House that there should be an amalgamation, but not now. Frankly, I think that is just an excuse. The Opposition spokesperson, the honourable member for Goldstein (Mr Macphee), said we should not do it now, but some time in the future perhaps. All that does is leave the matter in doubt. How can anybody plan on what the Opposition would do? Why would people invest millions and millions of dollars in capital works and the purchase of expensive equipment on the basis that maybe at some time in the future there would be a united organisation and therefore all the additional facilities that have been created would not be needed?

SPEECH.PARA: It is quite clear that we are at a stage where amalgamation is absolutely justified and ought to happen, as we are proposing. SBS television reaches virtually all the capital cities except Darwin and does not reach most of rural Australia. With this proposition there will be, for the first time, an opportunity for people in the country to see some of the better programs because the amalgamated organisation will have flexibility of greater program variety. Within its charter it also has a much more strengthened requirement to ensure that it recognises multiculturalism in our society and provides programs to achieve that. I do not see any reason why we would not have some of the better programs on the ABC, which would replace some of the not so good programs that are shown on the ABC at the moment. It provides that sort of flexibility.

We have a look to what we want when we start talking about having multiculturalism in our broadcasting programs. Do we simply want to achieve a situation where we have a television station in every capital city and in every rural area so that people can watch foreign programs? Is that what we want to achieve? Do we want to achieve this so that we can see the cultures of other countries? Is it a fact that we are trying to raise in everybody's mind that our society is more than simply a white Anglo-Saxon society-that it is a society which has many people from different countries who have given us a diverse culture? We want to portray that on our normal television programs. But, first of all, we have to raise people's consciousness about what our society consists of and what it is watching on television generally. I think the SBS has achieved that in its first few years. People are quite aware now that there is a difference in our society as compared with other societies. There is a need to reflect multiculturalism right through our programs on television.

Having done that, I think we have to be careful that we do not create a second rate station which continues to show programs from overseas and does not take the next step towards really developing a multicultural television industry. I think the amalgamation will achieve what we want to achieve; that is, it will open up the whole of the national ABC television system to allow proper multicultural programming throughout Australia. It will ensure that the money that is saved by the fact that we will not duplicate facilities in the long term will be able to be used for the development of programming. The ABC is now required to put greater emphasis on the multicultural side of affairs. That will mean that, within the new programs that will be developed, the ABC will be putting emphasis on multiculturalism in Australia. I think there is a lot going for it.

Some questions have been raised about whether we would have any savings at all. I do not think one has to be a Rhodes scholar to be able to sit down and look at what is happening and see the long term costs that will be saved. It is quite clear that we should save in the rationalisation of leased properties throughout Australia. I know in Melbourne SBS leases expensive office buildings in St Kilda Road. I know the ABC is leasing property in the city. When the new television facilities are built for the ABC they will be able to be used by both organisations. This will save the duplication that would have occurred. Television facilities are not provided cheaply and many millions of dollars will be saved. The purchase of equipment for television production will also be saved. It is clear that the rationalisation of administration by having only one administration instead of two will also mean savings in the long term. We have recognised that there will not be any great instant savings-that is why in the first year the savings are very small-but in the long term it is essential that the amalgamation take place so that greater benefits can be achieved over a period of years.

People have already expressed their view on the size of the ABC and SBS budgets. It is quite clear that no country can afford to fund in the order of $900m to $1 billion for public broadcasting. If we really want to achieve SBS on a national basis, the same as the ABC, that would be the cost we would be looking at. That is because it would have to duplicate all its television facilities, its links to regional areas, transmitters, translators-the whole range of facilities. It would have to extend the radio service which currently goes only to Melbourne and Sydney. To ensure that the ethnic groups in each of the States had representation, it would have to duplicate the community groups that provide programming and servicing for the radio stations.

As previous speakers from this side of the chamber have already indicated, virtually no countries actually provide free public broadcasting fully funded from the Budget. Broadcasting in England is paid for by licences issued to people who have televisions. But nowhere in the world are two public television networks being funded totally out of the Budget. Any rational person would realise that we will not get the funds we need. Already members of the community are saying: `Are we getting value for money out of that ABC?'. They are not going to sit back and say: `We don't mind you spending more money so that we can have two public broadcasters both providing programs, one for multiculturalism and the other for the community at large'. It is quite obvious that Budget restraints that would be applied in the future would mean that we would really not get what we want to achieve. We would not have either organisation working effectively. If these organisations remain separate, they will have to duplicate facilities and will have to draw from their budgets for new equipment and expansion. This would mean that amalgamation certainly would not occur. I think that amalgamation is basically the only rational thing that can take place.

We have to look at the stand of members of the Opposition on the issue because they are obviously very opportunistic. They have seen that there has been some unrest in the ethnic community and some concern about amalgamation. They believe that simply saying `We will oppose the amalgamation now', will put the ethnic communities on side and that they will all rush across and support the Opposition parties. What they fail to realise is that the members of the ethnic community are much more intelligent than that. They are not so silly as to believe that just because the Opposition is going to reject it now it is not going to amalgamate in the future. Those opposite have given no hint about what they would do or whether they would even maintain these organisations in the future. They have said simply that the merger would be on some time in the future. There are no guarantees. Members of the ethnic community have far greater concerns than simply about what is happening on television and radio. They are concerned because they see programs are provided which help them to keep in touch. They are also worried about Australia as a community, the economy and taxes, and all those issues. They will make up their minds about whether they will vote for us on our policies. They will still support us on our policies because they have seen the policies of those opposite in aciton and they know what those opposite are like. They will not vote for the Opposition anyway, whether or not it rejects this amalgamation. The reality is that they have seen through the Opposition's fraudulent stand on this anyway. As has been said in the Il Globo newspaper and other newspapers in Melbourne, it is just a fraud and a farce. The Opposition will amalgamate the ABC and the SBS in the future, yet it is not prepared to stand up now and accept it. It is not even prepared to stand up and argue for what might be perceived as better conditions.

The Opposition spokesperson, the honourable member for Goldstein made two comments which I would like to address. The first was his reference to the Managing Director of the ABC. He said that the new Managing Director had been appointed by unfortunate means. I really must take him to task because the Managing Director was appointed in the same manner as every other managing director. He was appointed by the Board, which considered the people available and decided that Mr Hill was the person with the capacity to bring about this amalgamation, to put the ABC back on a strong footing and to take it into the 1990s and the year 2000. That is what the Board perceived and it has appointed Mr Hill. The inference of the honourable member for Goldstein was that there was some collusion by this Government and that we made some effort to have him appointed. That is not correct and it is being denied by all sources and all people involved. The Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy) has denied that and so has the Board. The Board made its decision by itself.

I think the other comment that the honour- able member for Goldstein made, which referred to ethnic radio, highlighted how out of touch the Opposition is with the ethnic communities. The honourable member for Goldstein said that the radio stations 2EA and 3EA should provide more multicultural programs rather than the present multilingual service. If he had been in touch with the ethnic communities or knew of their concerns in relation to ethnic radio he would know what they want-to leave it exactly the way it is. They do not want it touched by anybody. We have given an undertaking that that is how it will operate. The Board and the new Managing Director have made it clear that they see ethnic radio operating in exactly the same way as it is now. That has allayed the greatest fear that existed during the campaign that was taking place within the ethnic communities. So there is no question that the Opposition is totally out of touch. It has missed the point that the ethnic communities were raising and it has been seen instantly by the ethnic communities for what it is-absolutely opportunistic and with no policies of its own.

I would like to make some comments about Mr Molomby. There has been a bit of a campaign by union staff who, quite rightly, are concerned about the fact that their appointee may have his term cut short. The reality is that it would be wrong for us to have a specific part in the legislation which would virtually be a Molomby clause which would give him special conditions. When we look at the reality of what is going to happen in terms of the election of a new union representative on the Board we see that it is extremely likely that Mr Molomby will go for his whole period. There is a requirement for legislative processes to be introduced. The Board has to draw up the regulations. There will be a requirement for people to determine absolutely who is eligible to be nominated and who is eligible to participate in the election. There will be a need to organise with the Australian Electoral Commission, which will run the election. There is also a need to consider that, with an amalgamated organisation where we will have some 700 full time and maybe some 300 part time staff from the SBS coming to an organisation where there are 6,000 staff, where we will have restructuring within the organisation and people working in different divisions, the ABC Board will have to take into account that there will be a need for a settling down period so that people can find out exactly how they are operating within the new structure, can get to know who are likely candidates, and can get to know other people with whom they have not actually had any great involvement. All those things will need to occur and there will have to be a settling down period within the new organisation. It would be very wrong to run instantly to an election when people have just been drawn together.

Of course, the other thing that will complicate the matter even further is that there is a possibility that unions, which currently have some coverage of staff within the SBS, may find themselves being excluded by the fact that the SBS is going in under new ABC legislation. They may wish to challenge the continuity of employment of the people they currently cover. If that occurs it means that there will be a delay whilst that challenge is taken up. In the past the Board has always consulted with the relevant unions in the ABC and I think it would want to maintain that relationship. So it would not want to exclude a union from the negotiations if ultimately that union has the right of coverage. I believe that all those things will mean that Mr Molomby will probably go to what would have been his full term anyway. If it is cut short, it will only be marginally short in reality.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just a few weeks.

—Just a few weeks, if anything. In conclusion, I support the legislation. I think this is probably the best thing that could happen to our public broadcasting. I have no fears that the ABC will simply swallow the SBS, use it resources and not maintain the multicultural programs that it has developed. I am sure that we will see a better organisation overall, one with much more flexibility in its programming capacity. I think we will be seeing a greater viewing audience going to the new organisation as it develops and provides better programs for the whole of Australia and the multicultural society that we live in.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to read a quote which may interest honourable members:

SPEECH.PARA: If the SBS were amalgamated with the ABC it would be lost. It would be like pouring a bottle of good wine into the Yarra.

I imagine that one bottle of good wine might not improve it very much. That comment was made by Al Grassby, a former Labor Minister. I picked that up because, surprisingly, I thought that the Australian Labor Party would have relished Al Grassby going around the electorate in one form or another drumming up support for it. I would not have agreed with Al Grassby on everything but, on this matter, he has put a view which I think fairly represents the view of a large number of people who have settled in Australia, who were not necessarily born in Australia, who have a concern, not that they want to change Australia but that they are acknowledged, in a liberal and tolerant community, as having a real place and a contribution to make in which their background is as much respected as the background of those who have lived here for a lot longer or who were born in this country. In essence, that embodies the concept of multiculturalism which we, on this side of the Parliament, see as so important.

The honourable member for Aston (Mr Saunderson), who preceded me in this debate, demonstrated by his remarks the very real concern that is evident in the community about a large number of decisions taken by this Government which will impact very adversely upon migrant communities generally within Australia and those people who see the concept of multiculturalism as being important for maintaining our society's growth and its unique identity in which we are all truly Australians. I think it needs to be said over and over again that Australia is not a European enclave living in Asia. In fact, it is a dynamic nation of people who have settled from all parts of the world, all of whom have brought to Australia different aspects of their way of life, which has enabled us to obtain considerable benefits and has given us our unique Australian character.

Any of us who travel abroad are able to say quite truthfully and genuinely that we are not British, we are not Irish, we are not European, we are not American; we are Australian first and foremost. That Australian character has been developed because of the wide background of the people who have settled in this nation. It is that tolerance, the way in which we are able to pay respect to whatever background people come from and the extent to which we are able to give people the opportunity to share with the wider community aspects of their culture that this unique Australian character has developed.

I find quite unbecoming comments such as that from the honourable member for Aston, who said that we are opportunistic in opposing this legislation. Certainly, it is a reflection on members from this side of the Parliament who over a long period have held consistent views strongly supportive of multiculturalism and the special role of the SBS.

I have quoted in debates in this Parliament before, and I would like to quote again, some of the comments of the Fraser Government about multiculturalism which embodied a long term commitment from the parties on this side of the House. I quote from a statement that I have previously quoted in this regard:

Australian society and culture has already been enriched by artistic, intellectual, lingual, culinary and other contributions of migrant cultures. The development of a multicultural society involves the recognition of the rights of ethnic groups to maintain and foster their ethnic languages and cultures, and requires efforts on the part of all Australians to adopt a multicultural perspective and to promote social harmony in cultural interaction.

It is that tolerance about which I have spoken which has been embodied in statements made by the former Government and by members on this side of the House over a long period. It does the Government no good service by trying to excuse its performance in this area by suggesting that our approach is in some way couched in opportunism. In fact, if one goes over the statements on the record by different spokesmen for the Opposition before the last election, one finds that the position that we have taken is a totally consistent one. The honourable member for Goldstein (Mr Macphee), in the time available to him, managed to put on the record a large number of those sorts of statements. I want to add another. It is a statement that was made by the former spokesman for the Opposition on communications, the honourable member for Ryan (Mr Moore). He was speaking on behalf of the Opposition to a number of people interested in the whole issue of ethnic broadcasting. He said:
I thank you for your invitation to be present here today and for the opportunity to discuss with you the Oppositions' policy on ethnic broadcasting.

I can state quite unequivocably that the Opposition totally supports multicultural broadcasting and in government would maintain and encourage ethnic broadcasting and the Opposition policy is as follows:
The value of the SBS is now recognised and the coalition parties will retain it as the primary source of multi-cultural television and radio programs. We will-
1. Provide an appropriate legislative structure for the SBS.
2. Extend the SBS to additional capital and other major metropolitan cities:
3. Investigate extending multicultural radio and TV programs to regional and rural areas by using the domestic satellites.
4. Consider the recommendations of the Review Committee when it reports in the near future.
I will come to that issue in a moment. He stated further:

As we are all now aware that since the drawing up of the Opposition's policy statement the Review Committee has submitted its recommendations to the Government and one can only assume that they are being considered.
The Opposition, in turn, is examining these recommendations with a view to developing and expanding its policy in relation to multicultural broadcasting.
He went on to say:

. . . I fully support the establishment of a new independent statutory body to replace the present SBS under its own Act of Parliament along the lines and with the powers as envisaged in the recommendations.
He further stated:
. . . one should also emphasise at this point that the Labor Party when in opposition was constantly critical of the SBS.

That is the situation as put by our former spokesman when we first went into opposition and when the whole issue of the future of SBS was being considered in the context of a review established by the Government to look at the Special Broadcasting Service. The Committee of Review of the Special Broadcasting Service, chaired by His Honour Mr Justice Xavier Connor and with Clare Dunne and Walter Lippmann serving with him, brought down a report entitled `Serving Multicultural Australia: The Role of Broadcasting'. That document was given to the Minister on 31 December 1984 and subsequently published. That document considered the whole issue of whether there was any basis upon which one could reasonably proceed to look at amalgamating the ABC and the SBS with a view to serving multiculturalism in a better way and, of course, in the context of the Government's budgetary difficulties. That review made it very clear that in the view of the reviewers it was not appropriate to amalgamate the ABC and the SBS at that time. The reviewers stated that it was a matter that might be looked at at a later point in time. I think they fixed 1990 as a point in time at which we might look at the whole question of whether the ABC and the SBS were two organisations that could be reasonably merged and whether the objective of serving multiculturalism could be reasonably maintained. Certainly, Justice Xavier Connor approached this question with an open mind. I have talked to him about it. He came to a genuine view, after hearing all of the evidence and surveying all of the available material. It is not a view that I would impugn in any way. It was a considered view and one worthy of respect.

The Government had that information before it and had further initiated an inquiry into the issue of multicultural programs and services generally. Only a matter of weeks ago it tabled in the Parliament a report of the Committee for Stage I of the Review of Migrant and Multicultural Programs and Services dated August 1986 and entitled `Don't Settle for Less'. That inquiry was also headed by a very distinguished Australian, James Jupp, and the Committee also included Concetta Benn, Steve Karas and Nina Skoroszewska. That report also considered the whole issue of the media, the ABC and the SBS. The Government did not receive any comfort from that report in terms of the implementation of this decision taken in the Budget to amalgamate the ABC and the SBS. The Government had the report before it at that time. It is pertinent to look at what the reviewers in that instance had to say. They stated:

The Federal Government funds both the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) and the Special Broadcasting Service (SBS), both of which are independent statutory authorities. As a result of the view of both in the past five years the Government decided earlier this year that:
The SBS will be upgraded to corporation status;
both the ABC and the SBS will continue as independent national broadcasters;
they will be required by legislation to co-operate in the future, including sharing resources, co-ordinating program planning and exchanging personnel;
each will be required by statute to report each six months to the Minister for Communications and the Parliament on the steps they have taken towards co-operation and co-ordination.

That report records that the report of the Dix Committee of Review of the Australian Broadcasting Commission, given to the former Government, was critical of the ABC for its failure to recognise that Australia is a multicultural society. Certain instructions were given to the ABC in 1981 as a consequence of the recommendations that the Dix report brought forward. Jupp noted that the Connor report recommended an upgrading of the SBS and that it should have its own charter. It suggested also that it have expanded obligations in relation to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities. The report from Mr Jupp canvassed other matters relating to extending the awareness of multicultural issues, language and cultural maintenance and the like, and of course if the Government had in mind that there was to be in the context of that report some amalgamation of the ABC and the SBS, that was a matter that could well have been canvassed at that time. That review did not contain any suggestion that amalgamation was the appropriate route to take, and it had before it many submissions which suggested that ethnic radio, particularly, had a crucial role in catering for the racial and cultural interests of people from non-English speaking backgrounds. The Jupp report said that some urged that the ABC and the SBS be more active in serving that objective. The Committee went on to say:

We believe it is essential for the two national broadcasters to give priority to the promotion of better community relations through their programming. Close consultation with each other and with AIMA-
another organisation abolished by this Government-
. . . and other appropriate bodies at Federal, State and local level should be beneficial to both the ABC and the SBS in fulfilling their charters.

There was no recommendation in that document that there be any amalgamation, and in fact the document itself was predicated on the basis that those two organisations would have a continuing role. That is the sort of advice that this Government has been receiving. It is pertinent that honourable members understand that there has been no clamour for this amalgamation to proceed; in fact, the reverse is the case. I have before me a great deal of information from a variety of organisations experienced in these matters which may have enabled the Minister to inform himself on this question. The Federation of Ethnic Communities Councils of Australia had some very strong views on this matter, and it considered the whole question in the context of the Connor report. It was violently opposed to any suggestions that there ought to be a merger of any form whatsoever, and it put that view over and over again. At the same time views were put by the Ethnic Communities Council of New South Wales, on which I put a great deal of weight, but of course since the Budget and the announcing of this decision the Government has had an opportunity to assess the views of a wide range of other people. One government body, the Ethnic Affairs Commission of New South Wales, made some comments about the Government's approach to ethnic affairs generally. I quote from its report, `Ethnos', of September 1986:

The 1986/87 Budget marks the end of the support by the Federal Government of multicultural programs and services. The fact that initiatives such as the English as a Second Language Program and the SBSTV have been either disproportionately cut, or virtually abolished in their present form, are signs of vanishing Federal commitment to multiculturalism.

We have statements also from the Ethnic Communities Council of New South Wales, which wrote an article entitled `Has Mr Hawke Burnt his Bridges'. Its comments provided a quite realistic assessment by ethnic communities generally of what the Government is doing. It had this to say:

You are abolishing the Special Broadcasting Service. Yes-abolishing it. How else can you explain your decision to amalgamate the SBS with the ABC. A saving of $2m cannot be worth all the anger generated among its viewers. There must be another explanation. You must, in fact, be saving much more. Perhaps thirty or forty million dollars. How? By effectively killing the SBS!

That is the sort of view of which Government members ought to be cognisant. It is certainly the way in which ethnic communities generally see the decisions of this Government. I make the point again, very strongly, that the Opposition is not putting this view as a result of any opportunistic approach. It is a view long held by members of the Opposition. I quoted former Prime Minister Fraser on the question of multiculturalism. The establishment of the SBS was an initiative of the Fraser Government. I quoted from the former spokesman on communications, the honourable member for Ryan, and I want to conclude by reading a statement I made when I had some responsibility in this area as Opposition spokesman for immigration and ethnic affairs. That statement, again, put on behalf on the Opposition a considered view. I issued a statement dated 27 May, in relation to the Connor report.
