SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jakobsen Ms C.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a pleasure to enter this debate on the Australian Broadcasting Commission/Special Broadcasting Service amalgamation. As an avid fan of both the ABC and the SBS I have a strong commitment to the continuance of what is original and necessary in both. I admit to having had some concerns in the beginning about the nature of the amalgamation, particularly the ability of the SBS to survive such a merger. However, having involved myself in discussions with the Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy) and the relevant parties to the amalgamation, I am convinced that services to the migrant communities in Australia will not only be preserved but also may actually be extended to areas which do not currently have multicultural television and/or radio services.

SPEECH.PARA: The people of Perth have only recently accessed SBS television programs and I thank the Minister for the extension of that service. I am sure the programs are very popular there, not only among members of the migrant community. However, one of the difficulties of the SBS is that it generally preaches to the converted-that is to say, many people who have no real interest in migrant issues never tune into SBS. This problem may well be overcome by the current amalgamation because people will have the opportunity of viewing SBS-type programs on a general ABC channel.

The people of Darwin and other areas in Australia still do not access that SBS service and would not conceivably be able to do so for many years because of the costs associated with expanding a separate television channel. However, the amalgamation should ensure that a more multicultural emphasis is given to television and radio broadcasts by the ABC. Accordingly, some of the non-English migrant communities in outlaying areas of Australia will soon have the opportunity to hear or view programs which do not have an Anglo-Saxon bias. In fact, bearing in mind the initiative and talent evident within the staff pool of the Special Broadcasting Service, the ABC will have to look to its laurels and change its entrenched attitudes on a great number of fronts in the future to keep up with the SBS. I have nothing but praise for the personnel of the Special Broadcasting Service. Like many other Australians I was fascinated by the ABC's screening of the SBS production `Women of the Sun', which was-as some honourable members would be aware-about Aboriginal women in Australia and the impact of white settlement on Aboriginal Australians. To my mind, the amalgamation simply means that more of these sorts of co-operative arrangements may occur in the future. Since we have had SBS transmission in Perth, my children have been regular viewers of its excellent teenage features, such as the Game of Life, which deals with the thorny question of drug abuse and other social problems confronting young people in Australia. This is the type of program that I would like to see the ABC picking up and carrying through. Also, like many other families, my family regularly watches the SBS news service and Vox Populi.

Nobody can doubt the multicultural nature of Australia. We enjoy a rich, cosmopolitan lifestyle as a result of the contribution made to this country by people from all over the world. Our nation is all the stronger for this diversity. The Government recognises the debt which every Australian owes to every new settler who decides to stay and contribute his or her efforts to the development of this country. None of this discussion precludes the contribution of the Anglo-Saxon, Anglo-Irish community now and in times past, does it, Minister?

TALK.START.PARA: —No.

—However, its communication, information and entertainment needs have been well and truly met by the existence of the ABC and the commercial television and radio networks. The Special Broadcasting Service has existed to redress the balance of broadcasting to take account of the requirements of the non-English speaking, non-English origin migrant community. It has done this well. This does not mean, however, that the service provided to date cannot be continued under the proposed amalgamation. On the contrary, I believe that funding for multicultural broadcasting will be much more secure under this new arrangement. No longer will the future of SBS be threatened by the Damocles sword of funding cuts. Its essence will be unassailable under the auspices of the ABC. Furthermore, I am sure that the alleged arrogance and ethnocentricity of some ABC programmers will not be permitted to dampen the ardour and the enthusiastic talent which many SBS staff members have traditionally brought to migrant broadcasting operations.

SPEECH.PARA: A revised ABC charter is to be inserted into the Australian Broadcasting Corporation Act. The new charter will expand the functions and powers of the ABC to reflect the multicultural and multilingual broadcasting responsibilities which the Corporation will have, following the amalgamation with the SBS. The revised charter makes it a function of the ABC to provide radio and television programs that contribute to the development of a multicultural society based on mutual understanding. In providing radio and television services, the ABC is to be required, under its new charter, to take account of the need to encourage and facilitate participation by persons whose first language is not English; the needs of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Island communities and persons of diverse cultural backgrounds; and the needs of persons from non-English speaking backgrounds, particularly in facilitating the learning of English.

In short, the ABC will be revitalised by this amalgamation. The service currently provided by the SBS will continue. Generally, Australians will benefit from this change, and a new understanding and tolerance may well result in the longer term. The new ABC board will not be dominated by traditional ABC directors. On the contrary, the maximum number of non-executive directors on the new board is to be increased from seven to 10, and a significant number of these will be people from non-English speaking backgrounds.

Many people on this side of the House have expressed concerns about the ability of the ABC to accommodate the diversity which is a hallmark of the SBS. That concern is a further guarantee that no dilution or diminution of the service to migrant communities will be countenanced. We are committed to a successful amalgamation and a continuance of a migrant broadcasting service of merit and significance. Furthermore, the Bill requires the ABC to include in its annual report particulars of multilingual and multicultural programming. This requirement will allow interested groups to monitor its performance in relation to its widened responsibilities. Certainly it is not my view that the screening of a foreign soccer game, noteworthy though that might be to some, should equate a commitment to multilingual or multicultural broadcasting. I am sure that will not be the result of the amalgamation with the ABC. To date, the ABC has had an excuse for not providing multicultural broadcasting services, and that is that the SBS has been in existence. I am sure this amalgamation will overcome that problem and that the ABC will now take its responsibilities more seriously.

While I sympathise with the comment of some on the other side of the House concerning the technical demise of the SBS, I cannot agree that there is a danger that it will be swallowed up by the ABC. To believe this is to ignore the ability of the ethnic communities to provide their communication needs through a poorly funded broadcasting service in the first place. It is also to ignore the vibrancy, commitment and diversity of the current SBS personnel. These qualities are our guarantee that the ABC will not subsume the operations of the SBS without a ripple; so also are the changes to the ABC's charter, which I mentioned earlier. Rather, we, as inhabitants of a truly multicultural country, can look forward to a stronger and more efficient national broadcaster with the charter and the capacity to provide a broad range of programs for all of the many groups which comprise our population. I am confident that the Minister has had the interests of the migrant communities at heart during all negotiations on the amalgamation. I am also absolutely confident of this Federal Government's commitment to the recognition and advancement of multiculturalism in Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cadman Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I quote:

SPEECH.PARA: The ABC is not ready for the merger, and there is certainly strong across-the-board opposition to it.

They are not the words of the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard), not the words of the shadow Minister for Communications, not the words of the president of an ethnic communities council somewhere in Australia, but the words of one of the Government's members, Senator Childs, quoted in the Sydney Morning Herald of 4 September. Senator Childs has put his finger on the reason that this amalgamation should not take place, and he has been supported by so many Government members who have now gone quiet under the force of numbers within the Government.

The Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy), who is at the table, has launched a series of attacks on the Special Broadcasting Service over a long period. If one looks at the report of the Connor Committee of Review of the Special Broadcasting Service, the report of the Dix Committee of Review of the Australian Broadcasting Commission and comments of the Minister in regard to the establishment of a corporation for multicultural broadcasting, one would have to conclude that he has at last succeeded in convincing his own Party to ditch the SBS. The Connor report is a Price Waterhouse report examining the financial aspects of the operation of such a proposed amalgamation. In the recommendations Price Waterhouse says:

The consultants believe that an immediate merger of the ABC and the SBS would be administratively difficult, requiring short term legislative solutions and producing only limited benefits. It would be difficult for the ABC to effectively absorb the SBS at this stage.

That is a report of a very competent financial group which independently assessed the processes that the Government has now undertaken. Those processes will not be successful, and financial advisers have advised the Government against embarking on the course of action which it has decided to take. Further, in regard to the amalgamation, the Connor report states:

We recommend that the Government should appoint a further inquiry in 1990 of both the ABC and the MBC with a view to considering their integration. In the meantime both organisations should be encouraged to work towards the aim of a single national broadcasting authority.

That is a process of moderation and careful planning, one that the Government has chosen to ignore. I think the Government has taken this course at its own peril because, in the same time frame in which this decision was made, it launched an attack against the migrant communities of Australia in very many significant areas. That is a tragedy because it has been grossly misunderstood by the community. The Government's stated good intentions cannot counter the fact that there has been a series of decisions which have set a group of Australians in a high state of concern and agitation over what the Government claimed at one stage was an economic decision.

The Minister's own thought processes followed a most curious train. Firstly, the Minister, on behalf of the Government, thought that he would amalgamate. He was unsuccessful due to pressure. Then he decided earlier this year to move SBS on to the ultra high frequency band, making it the only significant station to go on to UHF. We then found that it was not the Government's intention to move any other broadcasters to that wave length for another three years. The Minister selected this organisation alone to move to a less popular band, as a result of which people have to make modifications to their receivers in order to gain reception. What has been the result? It has been the reduction by roughly half of the viewing audience overnight. I think that is an indication of the way in which the Minister has sought to deal with SBS. Within three weeks of the Minister's appointment of the new Chairman of SBS, the Government decided to abandon the whole broadcasting service. These are not actions of rationality; they are actions signifying a determination to change and to abandon. Step after step has been taken.

The Government has done this at its own peril. The Opposition is opposed to this process. There is logic in the Connor report. There is logic in saying: `Let us get the ABC fixed up'. If the Minister wants to stupidly use some sort of philosophic argument against that, why does he downgrade-or run the risk of downgrading-after fine reports and sensible evaluation, the activities of SBS to the level of the ABC, in the hope that there will be a recovery at some later stage? The Connor report sets out a sensible administrative approach; it really does. There are other reasons why the Minister wants this amalgamation. He is bent to the wish for a two-channel national broadcaster. That was the objective. He was determined to achieve the services of a new chief executive, and that was part of the process, too. The objective was a larger organisation, a larger budget, the person whom the Minister wanted to run that organisation and, in that process the doing away with the commitment to SBS.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. One of the clearest Standing Orders in this place deals with reflections on honourable members. The honourable member for Mitchell has indicated that in some way I attempted to bring about the appointment of the chief executive of the ABC, which is clearly the role of the Board. I have said over and over again that I played no role in that appointment whatsoever. I find the suggestion totally offensive and I ask that it be withdrawn.
—Considering what the Minister has said, will the honourable member for Mitchell consider withdrawing those remarks?

—I am happy to withdraw if he finds offence in those remarks. I will pursue the matter not in that direction but in regard to the Minister's general attitude and approach to this matter. The move to UHF did halve the audience of the Special Broadcasting Service. There has been constant speculation about what the Government's intentions are in relation to SBS for over 12 months. The Government has got the message as to what the sensible and reasonable approach should be. Yet it has chosen to ignore it. I refer to the Government's own report of the Committee of Review of Migrant and Multicultural Programs and Services, by Dr James Jupp, released last week, on the services to migrant communities. Dr Jupp, while not finding on SBS, has set out the series of criticisms and comments and the conclusions he drew from what he expected the Government to do, based on the Minister's own announcements. Dr Jupp expected certain things to happen. I quote from his report, at page 267:

SPEECH.PARA: The SBS will be upgraded to corporation status-
in a ministerial statement the Minister made that commitment-
both the ABC and the SBS will continue as independent national broadcasters-
Government policy stated perfectly clearly-
they will be required by legislation to co-operate in the future, including sharing resources, co-ordinating program planning and exchanging personnel-
again, this was stated Government policy-
each will be required by statute to report each six months to the Minister for Communications and the Parliament on the steps they have taken towards co-operation and co-ordination.

There they are-four points of Government policy overturned with a flick of the pen. No wonder we have many disillusioned people around Australia. The continuation of the independence of the SBS and requirements for co-operation and sharing and for the reporting to the Minister on the way in which that was proceeding have all been overturned. That was the Jupp report.

What about the Dix report of the Committee of Review of the Australian Broadcasting Commission in 1981-another examination of the ABC? The Dix Committee in 1981 was critical of the ABC for its failure to recognise that Australia was a multicultural society. As a result, the Dix Committee's recommendation was that the ABC be given a statutory charter in 1984 to: Firstly, contribute to a sense of national identity and inform and entertain and reflect the cultural diversity of the Australian community; and, secondly, to take account of the multicultural character of the Australian community. We have amendments today reinforcing what was already the charter of the ABC. The Minister gives guarantees, with a track record of having broken commitment after commitment, of chopping and changing, of making a commitment to corporation status, of wanting to amalgamate, of moving to UHF, of appointing a chairman and then abandoning the Service. How many people does he expect to really take the Government's word that it will abide by and supervise the changed charter of the ABC? People will not believe it. They do not believe it because there have been so many changes over just a short period of 12 months. So the Minister wonders why he has problems.

The Government has to decide what it is going to do and set out its case clearly. It has not done that. The Minister threw in, ad hoc, a $2m cut on the eve of the Budget. He said that those organisations will be carrying a disproportionate share of those cuts. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) made some passing irrelevant comments about the process the Government has decided to adopt. Yet the Minister expects the community of Australia to accept his word. It will not do it. These people need something more significant than what the Government has decided to do. I know that the Government's own members have sought from the Minister some sort of statement of programming, a commitment by legislation to the fine thoughts in his second reading speech. The Government has refused to make those commitments. It sounds nice, but the facts of the law are not there. The facts on the change of the charter are also not there. So the Government has followed the pattern of its past behaviour by making claims and statements that people now come to regard with suspicion. That is a great shame. The attitude of the Minister is, I think, epitomised in this statement from the Federation of Ethnic Communities Councils of Australia, from which I will read briefly:

On July 10, 1986 at a meeting with FECCA Mr Duffy (Minister for Communications) stated that he considered there was no basis to any financial argument advocating the amalgamation of the SBS with the ABC since no one has yet identified any savings entailed. He indicated that there is a political perception that there would be a saving involved-but that this was not a serious obstacle. He agreed that the ABC was less than effective in carrying out its charter to respond to a multicultural society let alone other aspects of its charter.

There we have it. On 10 July, at a meeting of FECCA, the Minister again stated what was supposed to be the Government's view. Time and again we have this problem of change and uncertainty. Last year's attempts at amalgamation are clearly set out. I could quote from the Sydney Morning Herald in March this year, which refers to a previous attempt at amalgamation. According to the Sydney Morning Herald, the Minister has real trouble. In an article it said:

Any amalgamation would be a direct reversal of assurances Mr Duffy gave in March that he would introduce legislation next year to establish SBS as a corporation. Those assurances were in line with the recommendation of the Connor Report, tabled in May last year.
The Cabinet rejected a merger nine months ago.

There we have a demonstrated continuity of difficulties. What did the Minister say when he talked about a new corporation to replace the Special Broadcasting Service? Those were great words which he uttered in a Press release on 25 March this year. The Press release said:

`These decisions by the Government are in line with recommendations of the Connor report and underline the Government's commitment to ensuring a viable and progressive ethnic and multicultural broadcasting service', Mr Duffy said.
The Minister went on:
The Connor Committee found that there was a need for a considerable strengthening of the SBS administrative structure.

The Government has accepted that the best way to achieve this will be by replacing the SBS with a new statutory corporation having more flexibility over staffing matters, programming policies and administrative arrangements than the SBS has enjoyed.
That is the end of his Press release. So much for ministerial statements and Press releases. In the Government's 1983 policy speech, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) himself said:
We have no plans to abolish the Special Broadcasting Service.
Again, in the same section of the speech he said:
A Labor Government would be committed to increase funding of ethnic and multicultural broadcasting and develop these services as facilities controlled by ethnic communities themselves.
He also said:
On the other hand, a society united in a commitment to multiculturalism, equal opportunity and a `fair go'-
there we have it, the fair go of the Prime Minister-
for all is most likely to minimise social conflict.

So, we have the Prime Minister shot in the foot by his Minister, all promises broken and not understood by anybody because of the backing and filling. One ethnic newspaper, El Espanol, expresses it this way:
The Government did not dare to abolish the SBS. It is trying, however, to take away its identity by taking away its autonomy.
That is a pretty fair summary of what the Government has done.

Let us look at some of the economic facts relating to the SBS and the ABC. With an audience of 1.5 per cent, the SBS costs $47m. For more than $400m, the ABC has an audience of 10 per cent of the community. The SBS is at least 50 per cent more effective in gaining an audience than the ABC is, judging by those figures for cost outlaid. The ABC has other responsibilities; but the figures I am using are the half figures, after the SBS went on to UHF frequency. If the figures of like against like can be used, even allowing for the wider responsibilities of the ABC, the SBS is far more successful in attracting an audience than the ABC is. Mr Ron Brown, who is the executive officer of the SBS, was reported in an article in the Australian of 5 September in this way:

`The SBS runs a tight ship', he says, and points out its entire national staff, which produces all news, current affairs, in house production, sub-titles, et cetera, is smaller than the 240-strong ABC staff in Perth which puts to air half of the 7 p.m. news, half of The 7.30 Report and 45 minutes of magazine-style interviews each week.

That is a fair comparison of the relative merits of the two organisations. I am a supporter of the ABC and I want to see it get its shop in order. For the Minister to claim that the Opposition's process of opposing the merger will affect the bush is a bit of sleight of hand. It was a government organisation that put the scrambler on those in the outback who were receiving SBS broadcasting. I do not think the Government can now claim that because it is taking the scrambler away it has come up with a great initiative.
One only needs to refer to the report of the Auditor-General in regard to the ABC:
The audit indicated insufficient documentation of the policies and operating procedures of ABC Enterprises.
Another quote was:
. . . tenders were not invited . . . The Corporation's mail order bank account showed a discrepancy outstanding since March, 1984.
The conclusion of the Auditor-General was:

Audit is concerned that the Corporation is experiencing difficulties in meeting basic financial control requirements; in particular those relating to generation of information for accrual accounting financial statement presentation.

That is the statement of the Auditor-General. The Government is bent upon the process of trying to subsume an organisation that has proved its worth in one that has not demonstrated its worth. Why would it want to run the risk of downgrading the activities of the SBS? Why cannot the Government adopt a more moderate and measured approach?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mayer Ms H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I find the debate on the ABC/SBS Amalgamation Bill extremely interesting because the Opposition seems to have taken the opportunity that it offered once again to denigrate the Australian Broadcasting Corporation and to talk about the ABC as if it is in an impossible position and a very poor broadcasting service when we know what a job the ABC has done over the years that it has been established and continues to do every day. Certainly, the ABC is a large organisation and like any large organisation it has, from time to time, some problems. Chief amongst its problems would have to be the number of people who choose the ABC as their Aunt Sally. I think it is time we said that the ABC is something of which we can be proud. We can be proud of its reach, its history and its daily services to the people of Australia. I say that because in this debate we have heard far too much about the ABC not being an organisation which can handle what it already quite clearly handles every day.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to introduce my remarks by drawing a distinction between services provided by governments to overcome disadvantage and those which provide an absolute advantage. Programs such as the English as a second language program-which, I might say, remains fully funded with the States' agreement; there has been no diminution in the English as a second language program in Victoria, for example-are designed to overcome disadvantage. The provision of the Special Broadcasting Service provides an advantage-that is, it recognises differences and gives that difference time to be expressed. However, it should be recognised that providing a narrowly based advantaged can be justified only so long as we wish to separate groups from the mainstream of Australian culture. If we no longer want to separate our population into this, that and the other category, we need to recognise that by having a broadcasting service which reaches all Australians.

The amalgamation of the ABC and the SBS promises to provide at last a national broadcast system which will recognise the true nature of the Australian people. While I agree totally with the proposition that Australians of non-English speaking origin should have available broadcast programs in their languages and reflecting the culture of their home countries, it has always seemed to me to be wrong that these important programs are not part of the mainstream of broadcasting. The assumption behind the separation seems to be that Australians, either native born or from English speaking countries, have no interest in and need no knowledge of the languages and cultures of their fellow Australians, or maybe they need only a little so that they can have a little watch of SBS if they do not find anything satisfactory on the other channels. If we are to be a nation of one people understanding and appreciating the diverse strands of our developing Australian culture we need to dignify that diversity by making it part of our mainstream national broadcasting system. We need to make multicultural programs available to Australians outside the cities and to recognise the presence in our country and outback areas of people from all the strands of Australian culture; and I will come back to one important strand of that a little later.

I find it rather disconcerting that in many of the arguments used opposing the amalgamation the need has been ignored of native-born Australians to learn about, to value and to respect the cultures and languages brought to us by the people who have adopted our country as their own. Surely our major national broadcaster should not be party to the us and them notion which divides our society rather than unites it. We should celebrate our diversity. We should understand that we do not celebrate something of which we are either ignorant or afraid. For many years Australians, isolated from the rest of the world and instructed by the phobias of Victorian England, rejected for our wider society each cultural grouping as their people arrived in significant numbers. Even today each newly-arriving group suffers from the treatment given to those whom we do not understand. To overcome that understandable but undesirable characteristic the national broadcasting system should be able to acknowledge through its mainstream programming the values of a culturally diverse population in a united country. It is time that we recognised that Australia is a country in which there is still need for various groups to understand each other and that this separating of our people from the non-Anglo-Celtic origin and lumping them together as ethnic or multicultural is not the only way to achieve understanding. Of course, our national broadcaster should, as it does, provide material from the countries of origin of our people, but to continue to segregate that programming under arrangements which actually prevent some people from receiving the programs intended for them is not the most equitable way to go. Bringing the world back home is important to all Australians and the amalgamation of the two separate services into one service with diverse programs brings it home to us that we are one nation. Multiculturalism is a very nice term and it is paid a good deal of respect in what I believe to be the breach rather than the observance. True multiculturalism is surely bringing to the understanding of the majority the nature of participant groups while enhancing the maintenance of the cultural value for those groups. It means access to mainstream broadcasting so that information can truly be exchanged.

I find it difficult to understand the gloominess within the Opposition about the ABC and its ability to handle an amalgamated service while at the same time praising the SBS for its efficient operation. It seems to me that the addition to the ABC of SBS personnel would assist the ABC rather than pose a problem to it and there is a great deal to be said for the notion that, while changes are taking place, those changes should include any major changes which are signalled for some time in the future. That is why I take the greatest objection to this `some time, maybe 1988, maybe 1990, we will do it but we certainly cannot and will not do it now' attitude. It is a little like the prayer: `Please, Lord, make me pure but not tonight'.

I remind the House that the honourable member for Cowan (Ms Jakobsen) informed the House that the new charter will require the ABC to contribute to the development of a multicultural society or to encourage people whose first language is not English to participate in a number of parts of the life of Australia. This means, if it is taken seriously-I am sure that it will be-that we will see on ABC 1 and ABC 2, which are able to reach a much wider audience, programs which provide for all Australians entertainment, education, news and current affairs programs which do not exclude Australians of non-English-speaking origin. The new Board, expanded from seven members to 10, can be expected to take the charter provisions seriously as the Board will report to Parliament on the way it has carried out its charter provisions. While it is not a good idea to quote people out of context, it may be worth quoting more of Professor Zubrzycki's evidence to the Connor Committee of Review of the Special Broadcasting Service because the honourable member for Goldstein (Mr Macphee) certainly quoted some of his evidence.

TALK.START.PARA: —He missed a bit.
—Perhaps this is the bit that he missed. Speaking of the SBS, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . further extension . . . as a separate entity, is not really multiculturalism, while the ethnic languages, ethnic broadcasting and multicultural television remain outside the mainstream of electronic media. It is simply . . . a further example of separation, of segregation, a re-affirmation of separateness.

I think that that is a very serious statement to make about our broadcasting system. Have we reaffirmed the separateness of our ethnic communities rather than supported their right to be part of mainstream Australia, which they really are? Perhaps only those of us who have a different sort of background have failed to recognise it so far. I think that we should have no longer a reaffirmation of separateness but rather an affirmation of unity-an affirmation of our appreciation of the value of every member of our society and of our appreciation of our important cultural history. One of the ways in which the Bill can provide that for the new organisation is to have regard to the services provided by the holders of public radio licences and public television licences; and the amalgamated corporation may very well encourage the new National Program Packaging Unit to take advantage of programs made for Imparja, the recently licensed Aboriginal station in the Northern Territory, in the recognition that multiculturalism includes the original Australians as well as those of us who came or whose ancestors came here from other countries. I believe that the amalgamation of the ABC and the SBS will not be a destruction of anything which we value but rather will be a step into the future-the future of an Australia which is no longer divided into this, that or other ethnic group but an Australia which recognises its value as a country of very rich and interesting history and of a cultural diversity from which we will all gain strength.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sullivan Mrs K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I too have arrived late for the debate and I am grateful to the Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy) for having agreed to my having five minutes to speak, but I was unavoidably absent from the House earlier today. I rise to support the Opposition's decision to oppose the ABC/SBS Amalgamation Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer briefly to the history of the Special Broadcasting Service, which was set up in 1980. The Australian Labor Party, the then Opposition, proposed a motion in the Senate that the legislation be referred to a Senate committee for investigation and report. I was one of a number of then Government senators who crossed the floor and voted against my Party in order to enable the Senate committee to undertake that course. I did it because at the time, whilst the objectives of the Special Broadcasting Service were ones with which I agreed, I did not think that setting up a separate broadcasting service was the best way to do it. In the event, the Senate committee's report vindicated my view. However, in the meantime the Fraser Government had proceeded, under funding from the Advance to the Minister for Finance, to establish the Special Broadcasting Service without the enabling legislation.

We are now six years down the track and history has vindicated the wisdom of Prime Minister Fraser when deciding not to establish the Special Broadcasting Service within the then Australian Broadcasting Commission. In that time the Special Broadcasting Service has become a lean, efficient, effective and highly respected broadcasting organisation. With all due respect to the very dedicated staff who work at the Australian Broadcasting Corporation, the ABC has gone from bad to worse. There is no doubt at all that ethnic communities throughout Australia fear very much what could happen to the quality of ethnic broadcasting if the Special Broadcasting Service were to be swallowed up by the ABC-swallowed up it would be, because it would be an unequal amalgamation.

The Minister said in his second reading speech that this was a budgetary decision. It has been pointed out in debate that it is nothing of the sort. There is every reason to believe that if the present level of programming and services provided by the Special Broadcasting Service were to be provided by the Australian Broadcasting Corporation or some amalgamated organisation in the future, it would probably cost more in relation to the staffing of the ABC and the SBS and the method of commissioning and producing programs. As I said, the SBS has proved itself to be a lean and efficient organisation.

A report was commissioned by the Government, which came into this Parliament some time ago, specifically on this subject. That was the Report of the Committee of Review of the Special Broadcasting Service entitled `Serving Multicultural Australia-The Role of Broadcasting', known as the Connor report. That report did not recommend amalgamation of the Australian Broadcasting Commission and the Special Broadcasting Service. It foresaw that in the long term that would be a desirable objective, but it certainly did not foresee it in the short term. I refer honourable members to the recommendations of that report. I can refer only briefly to a couple because of the constraints of time. I refer to just three recommendations contained in paragraphs 5.75 to 5.76. They state:
We recommend that the first priority is to establish a statutory authority better designed than the SBS to develop a more effective ethnic radio and multicultural television service.
We recommend that the ABC and the new MBC-
that is, their recommended new Multicultural Broadcasting Corporation to replace the SBS-
should increase co-operation between them, sharing resources, co-ordinating program planning and exchanging personnel.

We recommend that the Government should appoint a further inquiry in 1990 of both the ABC and the MBC with a view to considering their integration. In the meantime both organisations should be encouraged to work towards the aim of a single national broadcasting authority.

The Opposition endorses those recommendations of the Connor report, as did the Government just a few months ago. There was no reason to expect this decision in the Budget context or in any other context; no reason to expect it at all, because the Government had indicated that it accepted the recommendations of the Connor report of working towards an amalgamation of the two organisations over time, with some modification of the Special Broadcasting Service in the meantime.

More recently the Jupp report of the Committee for Stage 1 of the Review of Migrant and Multicultural Programs and Services, entitled `Don't settle for less', was tabled in this House. The Jupp report assumed that the Connor report would be proceeded with in the manner indicated by the Government and did not travel down that track again. However, it saw what it called the ethnic and multicultural media as central and critical to the establishment of multicultural and migrant services in Australia. I recommend paragraphs 13.86 to 13.90 to honourable members. I quote briefly from paragraph 13.86, which states:

The ethnic media are an indispensable source of cultural support for ethnic communities. The Federal Government through the Special Broadcasting Service operates multicultural television services in major cities and ethnic radio stations in Sydney and Melbourne.

In addition, other cities now have that service. The Jupp report recognised the importance of multicultural programs on radio and television. It did not foresee the peremptory Government decision that has now come upon broadcasting.

In summary, I, along with other members of the Opposition, oppose this decision, not because in principle it would not be a good decision in some years time, as indicated by the Connor report, but because the manner in which it is being done undoubtedly would be to the detriment of multicultural broadcasting and the quality of programs that we have come to expect from the Special Broadcasting Service.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-In summing up, I would like to deal with the matters raised in debate this afternoon. Firstly, I indicate that the honourable member for Goldstein (Mr Macphee) seemed to be somewhat confused as to what the Government is about. The second reading speech, if people took time to read it, provides a comprehensive policy statement of the Government's objectives. The Government believes that amalgamation is desirable because multicultural services must be brought into the mainstream of national broadcasting in the interests of wide and equitable access. Nowhere else in the world do we have two separate government funded broadcasters. The new arrangements will be considerably more efficient. The honourable member for Goldstein quoted Professor Zubrzycki in relation to multiculturalism. One matter which ought to be brought to the attention of the House is that certain parts of those quotations should be very clearly understood. In giving evidence to the Connor Committee of Review of the Special Broadcasting Service, Professor Zubrzycki stated:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . further extension . . . as a separate entity, is not really multiculturalism, while the ethnic languages, ethnic broadcasting and multicultural television remain outside the mainstream of electronic media. It is simply . . . a further example of separation, of segregation, a reaffirmation of separateness.
I refer those honourable members opposite who are fond of quoting the professor when it suits them to paragraph 3.71 of the Connor report to see the view expressed on this issue.
The second point that I think is quite extraordinary is the insistence by the Opposition that this is not a Budget matter. I again refer honourable members to the second reading speech. It stated:

. . . the decision to amalgamate the two broadcasting organisations was announced by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in his Budget Speech. Accordingly, the Government sees the amalgamation as a Budget-related matter.

A decision was taken in relation to that but in the context of a difficult Budget. If members of the Opposition want to continue to pretend that it is not a Budget-related matter, so be it, but it is quite stupid of them to take that view. The honourable member for Goldstein said that there would be no savings, but it did not matter anyway. The fact is that the $2m saving on Appropriation Bill (No. 1) has already been passed. Members of the Opposition argue that the legislation is not a Budget matter. They can argue that if they want to, but in response I want people to understand quite clearly that if the amalgamation does not go ahead obviously there will not be any savings and consequently the $2m will need to be reappropriated in additional estimates to the ABC and SBS. This makes a nonsense of this argument.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Leader of the Opposition agrees with that.

—The honourable member for Dobell interjects and says that the Leader of the Opposition agrees with that. It is very difficult to understand what he is saying on this issue, but we will deal with that in a moment. Furthermore, the SBS and the ABC will have to ask for additional funds to cover the wasted costs of amalgamation planning. That is something which again those opposite have totally neglected in this debate-the enormous amount of work that has been done on getting this amalgamation together in a way which will be acceptable to both the ABC and SBS.

SPEECH.PARA: The other point that is made is that there will be no short term savings. I would like people to have a think about that. There will be immediate savings in various areas. ABC volume discounts will be available to SBS; rationalisation of the management structure will mean the SBS management floor, for example, in the Cliff Street premises will be able to be sub-let, the market value being about $350,000; spare ABC resources and facilities will be available at marginal costs rather than having the SBS hire them from outside groups at full commercial rates; and there will be a rationalisation of suppliers of duplicated goods and services. An example of that, to be specific, is that one major saving is that the SBS will no longer use the Australian Associated Press domestic wire service. These are matters which Opposition members just seemed to have ignored in this debate.

In the longer term there will be economies on program production and acquisition; availability of SBS sub-title facilities for the ABC closed caption service; reduction of administrative overheads; a comprehensive review of work practices in both organisations; rationalisation of accommodation, goods and service suppliers, staff resources, capital equipment and expenditure plans and a rationalisation of outside publicity expenditure through the availability of free publicity on other ABC services. It is in fact a nonsense to be suggesting that there will not be substantial savings.

It is very difficult to understand the Opposition's position. We have to go to a few things to try to ascertain that. One of the interesting aspects is that, again, there is some confusion of the position of the honourable member for Goldstein, but again we will go back to the Connor inquiry and have a look at what he said then. The Connor report cites the honourable member in evidence to the inquiry as `supportive of the proposition that there should, ideally, be one mainstream national broadcasting organisation catering for all Australians'. The reference is paragraph 3.74. I do not know whether that is really inconsistent with the reported current position of the Opposition as the honourable member for Goldstein has indicated; firstly, that circumstances are not now ideal and there is the need for two organisations. He says that the amalgamation will result in increased costs and the SBS will be swallowed up by the ABC and will inherit its problems. Circumstances can never be ideal, so I do not know when his amalgamation takes place. Secondly, savings are achievable. I assure the House that the autonomy of the existing SBS services will be maintained within the new organisation.

It is worth noting on that point that it is very difficult to ascertain what members of the Opposition are about. There were great complaints this afternoon about bad Press reporting-the Press saying that it did not know what members of the Opposition were doing or the short term political gain they were after and all the rest of it. It is very difficult to complain about the Press with this sort of statement. On 11 November 1986 on the World Today Mr Dodd, who was interviewing, said:
Well taking a step . . . sorry Mr Macphee.
The honourable member for Goldstein then stated:

I was just going to add I support, as far as one can see at the moment that there is a need for two separate broadcasters but ideally there ought to be one, but until we have the ideal circumstances to bring about one then we are committed to two.
It is unbelievable. It goes on further. There is then some discussion about 1990. The honourable member for Goldstein stated:
We may not by 1990 but a lot depends on the quality of management now. . . When we get into Government we'll examine the position of the ABC in particular then and see what ought to be done. . .

This sort of `not now, but it is a good idea', `maybe' and `however' really is an insult to the intelligence of people, particularly in ethnic communities, because the short term political gain, as mentioned by the honourable member for Wide Bay (Mr Millar), is very much in the minds of those opposite. The Leader of the Opposition in an interview with Mr Alan Jones on 12 November in answer to a question said:
What I'm saying is that the ideal is to have a single national broadcaster, but we don't believe at present . . .
I find it very difficult to understand what honourable members opposite are on about and, unfortunately, so do they.

Let us look at what has happened and the cost at this stage. What will the cost be if the decision does not go ahead? Firstly, the current Chief Executive of the SBS, Mr Ron Brown-I again repeat as I did the other day in fairness to him-is a person who has opposed the amalgamation very strongly. Once he realised it was Government policy he then co-operated as best he could to bring it about in the best way possible. He has publicly said that the SBS's position is the worst of both worlds. Nobody knows where these organisations are going now; nobody has any idea. The ABC cannot plan and the SBS cannot plan because those opposite are trying to pick up-no matter what their mealy-mouthed utterings may be-some short term political gain which they think they are going to get, which is an insult to the intelligence of the ethnic communities. If those opposite think that these organisations are going to tumble for that, they have got another think coming.

What if the amalgamation does not go ahead now? Substantial costs have already been incurred, such as management planning time, resources, redesign of television logos, station identification, and planning for program launches in January.

The other thing is that if the ABC is to proceed the potential audience includes some 660,000 people in major population centres, including Darwin, north-eastern Tasmania, the central tablelands of New South Wales and the Darling Downs in Queensland. In particular, the population of centres which have concentrations of people of non-English speaking backgrounds, including the La Trobe Valley, Townsville, Cairns and parts of Victoria and South Australia will miss out as a result of the fact that the ABC will not be running part of the multicultural programs on what is now the straight ABC.

The honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock) spent a long time on the Connor report as if we had just ignored it. Let me clarify that issue. In fact, the Connor report has not been discarded. The response of our decision has been to amalgamate now rather than later; that is the difference. The Connor report indicated that this matter should be reviewed in 1990 with a view to considering integration again. As I have indicated, I do not think that is good for the SBS or the ABC. They ought not to be left in that position. In effect, the Government has adopted, as its first priority, the establishment of a statutory authority better able than the current SBS to develop more ethnic radio and multicultural television services and that was the reference in paragraph 5.75 of the report. The Government approach is in accord with the Connor Committee in that it takes the view, as the Connor Committee did, that the dangers in maintaining indefinitely a separate entity to provide multicultural broadcasting-an entity which may be left isolated by a sudden change of policy or shifts in public opinion-is potentially very vulnerable. That reference is in paragraph 3.83 of the report. True multiculturalism will not be achieved in Australia until its objectives are reflected in the services of broadcasters in all sectors and that is the reference in paragraph 3.96.

We have noted the importance of other Connor recommendations and they have already been reflected in the operations of the SBS and are proposed to be adopted by the ABC as an integral part of the amalgamation. So honourable members opposite should not talk to me as though the Connor report had been left to one side. It has not. However, the fact of the matter is that honourable members opposite just pick out pieces of the Connor report which they like and adopt them and ignore the rest. The other matter that I would like to refer to today, to have a look at the reaction that this has had in some areas of ethnic communities in this country, is extracts from an editorial in Il Globo on Monday, 17 November-that is today-which is headed `SBS Corpse can no longer be propped up'. Unfortunately, I am unable to read the whole of it but I ask honourable members just to have a listen to this.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why not?
—Unfortunately, it is too long. I should have got the honourable member to do it earlier. The editorial states:

SPEECH.PARA: The decision by the federal Liberal-National party coalition to join the Democrats in the Senate in blocking government legislation on the merger of the ABC and SBS means the issue has been politicised by a small circle of people in a way that has no relevance to the everyday reality of public broadcasting or to the grass roots of the ethnic communities . . .

The Government and the ABC must obviously provide assurance, which if necessary must be extracted with every available political means, that not only will multicultural, multilingual broadcasting be maintained but also developed further. Above all they must-
The Il Globo editorial then sets out five points. Having set out those five points it then states:

Now that the above guarantees have been largely given by the government and others are equally negotiable, any indiscriminate opposition to the SBS-ABC merger, apart from being absurd is not in the interests of the ethnic community. We regret the Federal Opposition's hasty decision promoted by forces which do not reflect the true feelings or interests of the community. Liberal leader John Howard's position is obviously contradictory. He says the merger should go ahead but later, without specifying when or how. Nor is the stance taken by the shadow Minister for Communications, Ian Macphee-
the honourable member for Goldstein sitting in the chamber tonight-

morally defensible. Among other things he warns against the planned merger because SBS employees, many of which are underpaid and under-utilised, would then come to enjoy the same economic benefits as ABC employees. Liberals, Nationals, Australian Democrats and even certain sections of the Labor Party (worried about electoral repercussions) should calmly reflect on the whole issue. The current viewing audience of multicultural television is so small as not to constitute in itself a voting force, neither against the government nor the opposition.

The editorial goes on. In fact I commend that editorial to honourable members opposite because it points up their absolute hypocrisy on this issue. The other matter which was floated today in the Sydney Morning Herald was the possibility of Sir Nicholas Shehadie, who has been Chairman of the SBS and has served that organisation very well, becoming Chairman of the new organisation. I am able to say to honourable members opposite that those rumours in the Press today are correct. If this amalgamation takes place, as it should but for the stupidity of those opposite, the chairmanship of the new organisation will be offered by this Government-I am not speaking as the Minister; I am speaking on behalf of the Government-to Sir Nicholas Shehadie. Conversations that I had with him long before I knew about the stupidity that was going to come from honourable members opposite indicate clearly to me that, if the amalgamation takes place and that offer is made, Sir Nicholas will accept that offer.

Today the honourable member for Goldstein made a quite extraordinary suggestion which was taken up by the honourable member for Aston (Mr Saunderson) which I just want to repeat. He implied that radio stations 2EA and 3EA should be more multicultural as opposed to the existing multilingual approach. Honourable members opposite had better go and talk to the ethnic communities about that because if there is one thing that they do not want touched it is 2EA and 3EA and that is why we have said that they will not be touched. The lack of understanding of honourable members opposite on that issue is quite extraordinary.

Another matter that I want to deal with very quickly was raised by the honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Milton), who had a terrible concern about the position of the staff-elected director. He indicated that there may have been some reflection on the capacity of Mr Molomby. If there is any such reflection it is in the mind of the beholder. Certainly I have not received any indication from any person that Mr Molomby has not served the ABC very well during his period as a director. Any suggestion that the Act has not been amended in order to prevent Mr Molomby from serving another term is simply nonsense. Mr Molomby will be there for about 3 1/2 years, maybe four. I can assure my colleagues who have had some concerns about the suggestion that there has been some effort to bundle out Mr Molomby with any undue haste-based on what, I do not know-that there is no justification for that suggestion at all. The honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman) did not let facts get in the way of a good story in relation to UHF. He did not understand that the tremendous growth in broadcasting required the change to UHF. He did not understand that the SBS has not been switched to UHF. SBS television has been broadcasting on UHF since its inception and there was a temporary allocation of channel O for a parallel service, which was not properly used for that purpose.

In closing I would like to thank very much the members of my Department, the members of the ABC and the SBS who have worked so hard, the members of the infrastructure committee and my colleagues in this Parliament, but particularly in this instance the ABC and the SBS, which have worked so hard to bring about an amalgamation which would be better, which would bring about a great national broadcasting organisation that looks as if it will be stymied by the political expediency and stupidity of those opposite.

DEBATE.TITLE: BROADCASTING AMENDMENT BILL 1986[COGNATE BILL:TELEVISION LICENCE FEES AMENDMENT BILL 1986]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 12 November, on motion by Mr Duffy:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I wish to add to my remarks opening the second reading debate. I want briefly to provide the House with additional information that will assist honourable members to consider the Broadcasting Amendment Bill and the Television Licence Fees Amendment Bill. In accordance with my undertaking of last week, I table my Press release which summarises the Government's proposed indicative plan for the equalisation of regional commercial television. The plan will be published as soon as practicable in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette as required by the Broadcasting Amendment Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: As I stated last week, this plan is the basic strategic planning instrument for the process of equalisation. It specifies those regional licences to which the equalisation scheme is to apply; the areas that are to be approved markets, namely, in Queensland, the current service areas based on Cairns, Townsville, Mackay, Rockhampton, Maryborough, Toowoomba and Stanthorpe; in northern New South Wales, Lismore, Coffs Harbour, Tamworth, Taree and Newcastle; in southern New South Wales, Dubbo, Orange, Wollongong, Wagga and Canberra; in Victoria, Albury, Shepparton, Bendigo, Ballarat and Traralgon. The plan also designates the aggregation area for each licence in the relevant approved market, those licences eligible for consolidation, the aggregation completion date for multi-channel services in approved markets and certain other relevant information as required in the Bill. Copies are available from the Table Office.

Since I presented the Bill to the House, the industry body representing regional licensees, Regional Television Australia, has made representations to me and my Department concerning several aspects of the legislation as presently drafted. I have carefully examined these representations and am of the opinion that there is merit in several specific provisions of the Bill being amended. Accordingly I foreshadow that I will be moving several amendments on behalf of the Government. These amendments have been circulated to honourable members in my name. I will briefly explain the amendments I propose to move.
Extended Notice to Licensees on Variations to Indicative Plan

The first two amendments relate to the Minister's power to vary the indicative plan to specify new approved markets. The amendments I propose to move extend the obligation of the Minister to give personal notice to licensees whose service areas would form part of the new approved market. These licensees will be given 21 days in which to make representations to the Minister on the proposed variation. Consistent with other provisions in the Bill, and in the principal Act, the Minister will be required to have regard to these representations. The Bill, as it stands, provides for public notice in the Gazette with any interested person being able to make representations. This will remain unaltered. I propose to move these amendments as the representatives of regional licensees strongly put to me that they consider that the protection of personal notice is important to them. The extra administrative burden will be very small.
Specification of Aggregation Completion Dates Prior to 31 December 1996

Amendments (3) and (4) are in response to the RTA's problems with the Minister being empowered to determine a timetable for transition from MCS to aggregation in an approved market. As the Bill stands, the Minister appears to have the power to determine a timetable for transition at variance to one which may have been negotiated by all licensees within the approved market. The proposed Government amendments will specifically require the Minister to have regard to the desirability of giving effect to a common timetable proposed by all licensees in an approved market.
Relationship Between MCS Permits and Implementation Plans

Amendments (5), (6) and (8) through to (10) are to put in place consistent wording in relation to the word `consistent' in those provisions in the Bill dealing with the Minister's obligation to act consistently with licensees approved implementation plans. While the draftsman does not consider that the proposed amendments will alter the meaning of the affected sub-clauses, the amendments are proposed as the regional licensees' legal advisers are concerned about the variations in wording in the Bills as introduced.
Consultation on Technical Conditions

Proposed amendment (7) is also to tighten the drafting of the Bill. It relates to the alterations to a licensee's technical conditions which are made as a consequence of the extension of his `service area' into his `aggregation area'. The amendment is to ensure that the provisions relating to consultation in the principal Act continue to apply when the variation is made in the process of `aggregation'.
Restraint on Common Programming

As far as proposed amendments (11) and (12) are concerned, the Bill contains a provision, at proposed sub-section 94za, which is directed against regular simulcasting of programs on the head licence channel and on any MCS permit channels. The representatives of regional licensees have strongly pressed the view that the current provision would catch the normal broad- casting practice of repeat programming while the objective is to stop regular common programming. I have agreed to their request and propose to move an amendment to this sub-clause in the Bill to restrict the application of the provision to repetitive broadcasting within the preceding 24 hours. For the sake of the record I would point out that the provision in the Bill, as it now stands, is based upon an existing provision, in the principal Act, relating to supplementary licences.
Delegations Power

I now turn to my proposed amendments (13) and (14). It has been strongly put to me that the current provisions in the Bill relating to the delegation of ministerial powers are too widely drafted. The broadcasting industry contends that the ministerial powers specified in proposed section 94n (4) should not be able to be delegated. These are the powers of the Minister, following a second rejection of an implementation plan, to direct the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal to hold an inquiry in relation to the plan; to direct the licensee under existing section 125e of the principal Act; or to determine an implementation plan for a licensee. The regional licensees also consider that the Minister's power to vary an implementation plan should not be able to be delegated. These are very significant powers which I am prepared to reserve to the Minister by amending the Bill.
Other Contentious Issues

During consultation on the Bill some other issues have arisen which are of concern to the television broadcasters, and particularly to the regional broadcasters. I would like briefly to clarify some of these issues at this stage of the debate.
Need for Markets with New Additional Licence

Firstly, because of the content of the proposed indicative plan it is argued that there is no need for the Bill to provide for the indicative plan to specify approved markets in which an additional licence can be called for. While this type of market is a hangover from what was foreseen as necessary in the published draft indicative plan, it has been retained because it could possibly become useful in future years in, for example, Tasmania. I do not, however, have immediate plans to use this type of market. I think it should be retained, however, to allow for its use in future years.
MCS Election in South Australia and Western Australia

Secondly, it has been said that it is inequitable for regional licensees in approved markets which include a metropolitan service area, to be denied, in proposed sub-section 94g (3) (a), the option of the election process for MCS or aggregation as is available in other approved markets. This criticism is based upon a misconception. The markets to which this provision is likely to apply are future markets in South Australia and Western Australia. These markets will not be specified as approved markets for some years. Licensees within these areas will be free, at their option, to apply for an MCS permit or permits prior to them being included in an approved market. The election process will thus be redundant following the specification of these areas as approved markets. This is because MCS will already be operational in those areas at the option of the licensees.
Powers of Minister in Relation to Implementation Plan

It has been argued that proposed section 94n should provide for specific consecutive steps to be taken, by the Minister, following a second rejection of a licensee's implementation plan and before the Minister may determine a licensee's implementation plan. The flexibility provided for in the Bill is necessary to allow for efficiency in the processing of implementation plans and the very wide range of factors that might be at issue in relation to any particular plan. I would like to make it quite clear, however, that the power of the Minister to determine an implementation plan is seen as a last resort. I said this is my second reading speech and I re-emphasise it today.
Minister's Obligation to Grant an MCS Permit

It has also been argued that proposed sub-section 94v (2) should make it obligatory for the Minister to grant an MCS permit where a licensee applies for an MCS permit and its grant would be consistent with the licensee's implementation plan. To make such an amendment would conflict with other areas of the Bill. For instance, it would not be consistent with the ability of the Minister to revoke a permit on a recommendation of the ABT for breaches of programming requirements. This is because the licensee could immediately reapply and be entitled to the grant of another permit as long as such a grant was consistent with the relevant implementation plan. Also such a provision would be inconsistent with the structure of the Bill which does not provide for there to be any proprietary rights in an MCS permit. On the other hand it is relevant to draw honourable members' attention to clause 23 of the Bill which provides, in part, a duty on the Minister to carry out implementation plans. The Minister would thus not be acting in accordance with this duty if he were to refuse to issue an MCS permit without cause, if the application were to be made in accordance with the relevant implementation plan. The same argument applies in relation to the provision in proposed sub-section 94y (1) which provides for the suspension or revocation of an MCS permit. When exercising this power the Minister will be under the same duty to act in accordance with the approved implementation plan.

In conclusion, the amendments I have proposed will not change the substantive purpose of the Bill but will allay and clarify some concerns among regional licensees. The result will be a better Bill that the industry will be confident to work within.

TALK.START.PARA: — I understand it is the wish of the House to debate the Broadcasting Amendment Bill concurrently with the Television Licence Fees Amendment Bill. There being no objection, I shall allow that course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macphee The Hon I.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I disagree slightly with the final remarks of the Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy), but I am bound to say that, given that he does not accept the principal objectives of the Opposition's policy and therefore our objections to the Broadcasting Amendment Bill, he has been most courteous and helpful in the preparation of the statement which we just gave him leave to read. The Minister is, by nature, a courteous man. He is also basically concerned with delivering services to as many Australians as possible. We regret that he has not been successful in getting his policy through the Cabinet. As a reflection of our concern, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That all words after `That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

`whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House expresses its concern at the equalisation of regional television services by way of aggregation of viewing areas, especially the `one-in all-in' trigger mechanism and believes that equalisation would be best achieved by the immediate issue of supplementary licences to existing licensees subject to specified conditions'.

The Opposition is opposed utterly to the policy of aggregation of viewing areas which has been adopted by the Government. I spoke at length on this matter on two occasions in recent weeks. The first was on 16 September and appears in the House of Representatives Hansard at pages 745 to 748, and the second was on 18 September and appears at House of Representatives Hansard at pages 999 to 1002. I draw those references to the attention of the House and especially to the attention of our colleagues in the Senate where I suspect this will receive a rather more free-ranging debate than is possible here, given the state of this House.

We are committed to a policy of supplementary licences being issued immediately to existing licence holders and, as the amendment implies, subject to certain conditions. We will spell out those conditions in due course when we formally announce our policy on communications. We believe that, in providing a choice to regional viewers, by far the better way to go is to provide people with a supplementary licence in order that there can be at once alternative programming and that therefore the viewer may select an alternative program. If one wants evidence of that, the case of supplementary licences which has got farthest was in this city of Canberra. If the Australian Broadcasting Corporation had not chosen to take the Australian Open at the weekend, Capital 7 might not have shown the cricket, but it did show the cricket and forsook some other programs. If Capital 7 had been the recipient of a supplementary licence under what is the Opposition's policy, which was our policy in government, which remains our policy in Opposition and which was momentarily-an expensive moment, I think, for Capital 7-the policy of the Government, viewers would have been able to watch the usual programs plus the cricket which, if one really enjoys cricket, was not bad but which, if one is partisan, was not good. Such are the decisions that have to be made by the investors in Capital 7.

We believe very strongly that the real issue here is not the gimmick of so-called equalisation. What does equalisation really mean? If we look at the number of services provided for Australians living outside the capital cities, especially on the east coast, it is already substantial on a head of population basis, and it can be improved. No one questions that. One could argue that, if the Government is determined to provide three services to most of regional Australia it ought to be prepared to provide rather more services to the metropolitan cities, especially those on the east coast. In this debate we want the Government and the Senate to understand what we have been saying for some 12 months and what, indeed, members of the Government have been saying in the Caucus and the Minister's office. The path to his office has been well and truly worn by the honourable member for Bendigo (Mr Brumby), the honourable member for Ballarat (Mr Mildren) and others who understand the significance of this issue.

We in the Opposition want an improved range of viewing-that is, a greater choice for the viewers. We want not some gimmick called equality of programs but quality of programs. We want diversity, choice, a minimum of repeats and more localism. We want local production of advertising as well as news and current affairs, sports, entertainment and other programs of cultural significance. These are much easier to deliver under a policy of supplementary licences than under the tortuous propositions coming now from the Government. The Minister, as we know, has been rolled a couple of times. It is no reflection on his Irish tenacity, but he has been outvoted by other forces and influences upon which we can only speculate.

It is hard, if not impossible, under what the Minister has put to us tonight, to provide local programs. It is our firm view that if one of the Government's policies had been allowed to be enforced-that is, immediate aggregation everywhere-it would have been impossible to have local programs and, indeed, Australia would have been, as I said in one of the earlier debates, able to be run from any point in the world, particularly from the United States of America. Even according to the statement that the Minister has just read to us tonight, the cost of trying to provide diversity of programming, real choice and localism is prohibitive. In relation to the technology about which the Minister is asking people to make decisions now, the Government is most uncertain about what it wants. We have just had a debate, Mr Deputy Speaker-you were in the chair for some of it-in which we saw the changes of mind through which the Government has gone regarding the future of the ABC and the future of the Special Broadcasting Service, and now we have the contemplation of a merger of them. The Government is again uncertain.

I will read a couple of really penetrating Press releases that have been put out by the Minister. Because he is a sensitive man, he will be embarrassed to be reminded of the fact that in a statement to the House on 1 December 1983 he invited expressions of interest by March 1984 and formal supplementary licence applications by September 1984. In a Press release dated 8 March 1984 he congratulated the regional television industry on its reponse to his invitation for expressions of interest. What he said is worth reading, in part at least:

All thirty-six commercial television stations located outside mainland metroplitan cities or in Tasmania have formally expressed interest in obtaining an extra, or supplementary, licence . . . The reaction from all States and Territories is much better than expected and I congratulate the industry on its initiative . . . This is good news for listeners and viewers in regional areas wanting more diversity of choice in programming.
It certainly was good news and we in the Opposition applauded him because he was actually adopting our policy. Then, on 2 October 1984, the Minister said:

Exactly 100 formal applications for supplementary, or second, radio and television licences had been received by the cut-off date of 20 September 1984 . . . This is excellent news for viewers and listeners in regional areas and should lead in time to their having a wider choice of programming.
I am sure the words are coming back to the Minister. He went on to say:
In all, 69 radio and 31 television stations out of a possible 137 (101 radio, 36 television) have lodged applications.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who said this?
—The present Minister said that about implementing our policy, effectively, the one that he would like to continue. The Press release stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister said the Department of Communications had begun processing the supplementary licence applications and he hoped to be able to refer the first of them to the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal by the end of October 1984 . . . The Tribunal will publish the necessary particulars of applications referred to it and invite written submissions concerning the grant of licences . . . It will hold the first public inquiries into the grant of supplementary licences in February 1985.
That was on 2 October. I want you to focus on this, Mr Deputy Speaker, because, only eight days later what did the Minister say? He said:
I now wish to say a few words about the future.

We thought that that is what he said on 2 October. On 2 October 1984 we thought we were getting a pretty important statement about the future for choice in regional viewing areas. But here, eight days later, really is a statement about the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —They must have been reflections.
—I am just quoting the Minister. The Minister said:

SPEECH.PARA: In its SPS report, the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal provided a very useful analysis of strategic objectives regarding commercial television. It identified five major concerns of government:

a. To maximise diversity of choice in radio and television services, so that all Australians have access to as wide a range of services as possible; to bring a similar range of entertainment and information through broadcasting services to all Australians, especially those currently without any or with inadequate services;
b. To maintain the viability of the broadcasting system;
c. To encourage an Australian look for television and radio by maintenance of an appropriate Australian content level and the fostering of an Australian production industry;
d. To provide broadcasting services relevant and responsive to local needs; and
