These are worthy sentiments of a worthy Minister with which we would find great concurrence. But what has happened to the poor Minister and his policy since that day? The first worthy sentiments were expressed in December 1983; they were repeated in October and then, eight days later, they were totally reneged upon in terms of the forecasting of the method of change. All of the sentiments in terms of the Broadcasting Tribunal's objectives are important. What is wrong, as he goes on, is the focusing on the method of change. In the method of change he forecasts what I have since called, with some conviction, a gimmick. It is even swifter than the change of the Government in deciding, three weeks after it had appointed the SBS Board, that it wanted to amalgamate the SBS with the ABC Board, which it had appointed only eight weeks before that. Now we find that, eight days after he has said what a wonderful thing it was that 31 regional television stations out of 36 had lodged their applications for supplementary licences, he will have a new policy altogether to achieve what sounds remarkably like the same objectives that underlay the supplementary licence scheme.

As the two speeches that I referred to earlier-those that I gave in September-indicate, we went from that to the draft indicative plan. We know that the draft indicative plan prepared by the Department of Communications had a number of false assumptions. They were demonstrably false and they have not been repeated in this exercise before us now. There is a reference to a modest growth of advertising revenue in the order of 4 per cent, and it certainly is modest compared with the upper limit that was forecast in the draft indicative plan. I suspect it is still too high. We remember that the draft indicative plan was destroying the community of interest that has been naturally accruing since television was introduced in Australia, and we also are aware that this draft indicative plan opened the door for not only the destruction of that, but also the destruction of all community of interest within Australia itself because of the access it gave to networking. Today we have seen the final indicative plan which has been put before us. It is put before this Parliament in the absence of any plan regarding changes to the ownership and control rules. I know that they are promised imminently, in a few weeks time; but it is hard for the Parliament to decide what is best. I do not know what view the Senate will take of this situation.

We are also being asked to decide, in the absence of technical guidelines that are very important for major investment decisions, how people will draw up their requests for implementation plans. What we do know is that, under these now considerably revised approved markets, as they are called-which, by the way, are not natural markets; there is nothing natural about them; they are not natural markets in the sense that the world of commerce understands-there is a proposition about one in all in. That is to say, any one of the people who are affected in a given so-called approved market, can trigger off an aggregation of the others regardless of the opposition of the others. What are the consequences of that? Under the plan which the Minister has just made clear to us and tabled, we will see two different market formats. Many of them will proceed by what is called the multi-channel service. Others will take immediate aggregation. There will be different dates; there will be different regions.

The policy we have of supplementary licences issued immediately to existing licensees provides greater choice at once and uniformly throughout Australia-or throughout eastern Australia which is the only part we are now dealing with. But under the final indicative plan produced by the Government, one part will move virtually immediately to aggregation-that is, southern New South Wales-well ahead of the 1996 aggregation date produced by the Government. What a shambles that is. What will be the effect on production houses, on national advertisers and on investment in the industry generally? What will be the effect on employment and the aspirations for employment and for training of people in the various regions who now look forward to being employed in or in support of regional television? We have what can be called a patchwork quilt. It is a policy for everyone. Equalisation is the catchphrase; but that is not so, looking at the services. Tasmania is a special case. South Australia and Western Australia were always going to be special cases. The Northern Territory is always a special case. Now there is a special case for southern New South Wales, for northern New South Wales, for Griffith itself, for Mildura, for Wagga Wagga-every one is a special case. A lot rests, it seems, on where the sensitive electoral boundaries are drawn for the present Government. There is a policy for everyone here.

Studying the pattern of viewing markets, it is confusing beyond belief. Looking at the document which the Minister, obviously against his will, has been forced to bring forward on behalf of the Government, I would say to you, Mr Deputy Speaker-although we hear a lot of this sort of debate here-that there is more chance of the J-curve working than there is of regional viewers gaining early choice or eventual equity between regions under the proposal now before us. The year 1996 is the ultimate aggregation, whereas in fact under our proposition everyone can get a station on air now. In fact, not only the Government and the Opposition all say that they want a choice for viewers, but also Regional Television Australia, the organisation that represents the regional television licensees, put a table forward to the Government which would have produced stations already on the air over a year ago, so that there would have been a second channel in each of the areas covered by the Minister's plan.

Let us look at the Minister's timetable: Southern New South Wales, 1989; then do we go to northern New South Wales? Oh no, we go to Queensland, where the date is 1990; then we come back to northern New South Wales in 1991; Victoria in 1992 and, for good measure, Albury crosses the border and goes into Victoria. None of those machinations are necessary if one takes the path of supplementary licences or if the proposition put to the Minister by Regional Television Australia for multi-channel services is adopted. The RTA put to the Minister the proposition that by 1990 there could be three services. That proposition was put twice by the licensees of Regional Television Australia. They said that there could be aggregation-they did not want it, but the Government did-of three services by 1996. They were told that that was Sunday too far away, so they brought the date forward to 1993. Again they were told that it was Sunday too far away. Both 1993 and 1996 were too far away; yet now we find that it is not too far away after all because the Government has now adopted 1996.

As we have seen, 31 of the 36 members of that association already had a second service funded. They had put money aside from their profits to provide a second service, and this happened at least a year ago. Had the Minister proceeded down the path of those Press releases that I read out, a service would already have been operating and there would have been no argument about whether people in Canberra could choose the ordinary Channel 7 programs or the cricket. Other similar decisions could have been made around Australia. Regional viewers are the ones who suffer. There has been a delay. Why? We want to hear from the Minister why that is. All regional viewers will want to know the answer to that question. This is the most massive restructure of television in Australia since television began, but the service to regional viewers is being jeopardised.

If we look at the document that the Minister has just put before us, we see that there is a long lead time in opting for immediate aggregation or multi-channel services, whichever is decided. The Government will, of course, gazette the indicative plan and the licensees will respond within 28 days. About three months later the licensees will be required to submit an implementation plan. In some cases equalisation is not due to start for three to five years. Those who are going down the aggregation path have to burst their boilers doing a study and then wait a number of years before they can actually implement the program. That shows three things. It shows, first of all, that the Government is considering an early election because--

TALK.START.PARA: —No!

—The Minister says no, and he is wise, because he knows that he will lose. The people who made this policy against the Minister's will may be considering that, not because they can deliver services, as we and, indeed, the Minister could have done, but because they can say: `There you are; the services are there. We will provide you with the services. We have the timetable'. We will look soon at how satisfactory the services will be under this timetable. That is the first thing that occurs to me. SPEECH.PARA: I have already referred to the guidelines and the ownership and control rules, but there are other details that need to be made available. Even though some of those details are technical, they are of vital significance to regional licensees. There is no indication of the complexity of these guidelines and they could well involve licensees in a costly and time consuming exercise which could take three months or longer even to start to get to the first fundamental commercial consideration. The time allocated under the timetable given by the Government is far too inadequate to do the job. Talking of timetables, I point out that in Western Australia and South Australia there is reference to aggregation and one wonders what this really means. Does it mean that regional licensees will be able to broadcast in the metropolitan areas, or will the metropolitan stations simply expand in the regional areas? I ask the Minister to answer that question when we reach the Committee stage of this debate.

Why should someone meet this timetable in a rush and then repent at leisure? Most people will opt for multi-channel services, and that defeats the Government's intention in the short term. In the short term and even in the medium term, viewers in regional areas will be denied opportunities of choice. Australia already has more stations per capita than the United States of America. We now have in regional eastern Australia four million people served by 23 stations-that is about 174,000 people per station at present. Under the Government's policy there will be 69 stations for four million people-that is 58,000 people per station.

I read in the papers-I hope that it is not true-that certain people in the Government are influenced not by the wishes of regional viewers but by one or two networks in Australia. I know that that is not the Minister's view. I have looked at the figures. In the eastern capital cities nearly eight million people reside in Brisbane, Sydney and Melbourne, where there are nine stations. That means that there are about 890,000 people per station. When is the Government going to extend the number of stations in those three cities?

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister won't let him.

—It is not the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). I wonder who runs the Government in this regard. How does one provide viewer choice? These are the questions that the Parliament must face. Networking is what the Government is on about, but it has just become more confused.
—You had eight years.

—We were on the way to providing viewer choice by supplementary licences. The one defect of that was that we did not grant supplementary licences immediately. The question now is networking. Even though this is a more cumbersome version of it, we believe that the ultimate outcome will be control, if not ownership, and the destruction of localism by the people who make programs, and the people who make programs or sell them are essentially the networks. We do not think that that will provide quality or diversity or choice.

SPEECH.PARA: Another option for the Parliament is to look at the multi-channel service or the supplementary licence approach. We know that regional stations have been highly profitable. We also know that, pursuant to the previous Government's policy and the announced policy of the Minister, the stations set aside a lot of money in order to set up a supplementary licence and to provide for a second supplementary licence and to cope with eventual aggregation. They can do that, remain viable and provide choice; but they cannot survive under the policy announced today. That is bad for local employment and local advertising as well.

As well as that, the Minister has confused the issue further because in a separate statement he said that there would be a moratorium on pay television for four years. It will not be introduced until 1990 at the earliest. The wild card is: Will it be introduced then or will it come a little later? This Government will not be in government at the time, but, just the same, those who want to invest their capital must consider that it might be. It is a wild card because, under the final indicative plan produced today, some people--

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a good way of viewing the ABC and the SBS.

—The Minister sees a parallel there. Some people are looking at 1991 and some at 1992 before they must aggregate under the plan before us. Yet they could find that they are obliged to make decisions early about the kind of technology they must adopt. In fact, they must decide that in three or four months. Yet after they have made the decision, the Government could introduce pay television in its various forms.

SPEECH.PARA: We are in an era in which satellites and fibre optics will be the technological route to go. Some licensees are now obliged to commit themselves to an implementation plan virtually straight away. Three or four months is virtually straight away. That will almost inevitably force them to make technological decisions which will involve outmoded technology, although by the time they actually come to implement the plan they would have preferred to go by way of satellite or fibre optics. Telecom will have linked the capital cities and several provincial cities by 1992 by fibre optics. All these choices are a hard and confusing route for regional proprietors to go down. Then they will be confined instead to obsolete technology.

Also, the Minister made much of licensees being able to get sales tax exemptions. I put it to him that these should be extended beyond just the transmitters used for aggregation so that exemption embraces expenditures on the feeder lines and antennas and on the translators. The are all essential parts of an overall transmission system and, in a broad sense, are included as parts of transmitters. The cost of these feeder lines and antennas, together with the cost of translators, is in the order of $36m, which adds 75 per cent to the cost of transmitters which would otherwise attract a sales tax of some $7m. The exemption of sales tax is justified not only--

—Yes, Mr Deputy Speaker, I second the amendment and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brumby Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is my pleasure to rise to support the Broadcasting Amendment Bill and the Television Licence Fees Amendment Bill. I do that because in no uncertain way are these important Bills. Equally, they are historic Bills in terms of broadcasting policy in Australia. We have heard already an interesting debate on these Bills and a legitimate contribution from the honourable member for Goldstein (Mr Macphee), but I think it is important to bear in mind that what we are trying to do with this legislation is to provide a cast iron framework, if you like, for expanding the range of broadcasting services throughout country Australia. In simple terms, this legislation is about ending the discrimination which has occurred in the range of television services which can be enjoyed by city and country viewers.

SPEECH.PARA: This legislation gives effect to a commitment that this Government has held since we were elected in March 1983, that is, to provide equal services to the many millions of Australians who live outside the capital cities. When we came to government and when the Minister for Communication (Mr Duffy), who has made a number of statements to the Parliament on this issue, stated very clearly what the Government's goals were, he said that this Government was determined to seek to meet its joint objectives of equalisation and competition in regional television in Australia. We sought to do that because, as I have said, We want to ensure that regional viewers in Australia get the same range and choice of television services as do their city cousins.

In looking at providing increased services to country people a range of options was obviously available to the Government. As has been mentioned already in the debate, technology would allow a government to make decisions to simply allow 100 per cent networking of programs via satellite from the capital cities. That would probably be the cheapest and the quickest way to provide choice to people in regional areas, but the Government is not interested in that course of action because it would destroy regional television as we know it, would destroy localism and would put all control of television policy into the hands of a few owners of the major city networks. That was one option we did not pursue.

We basically came down to looking at two options-what is known as aggregation and what is known as the multi-channel services system. I am on the public record as supporting the view that an expanded range of services should be provided to country people through the multi-channel services option and I put forward certain arguments in support of that proposal, but I have always of course acknowledged that there are legitimate views on both sides about how best to provide that increased range of choice and eventually competition to country people. When the draft indicative plan on aggregation was released by the Minister some weeks ago I was not happy with it, and it has now been changed. The Press release which the Minister tabled in the House tonight provides significant changes to the original draft indicative plan. I have to say that I am pleased with the final outcome. There has been considerable consultation by the Minister and by Government members with all involved in this industry, ranging from the regional stations themselves to their representative body, Regional Television Australia; and of course the interests of viewers has also been paramount. The Minister said, when announcing the draft plan, that it would be just that-a draft plan-and that it would always be subject to consultations and amendment. I am pleased that that process has been undertaken by this Government and that, as a result, significant changes have been made to the draft indicative plan.

Importantly, because of those changes, we now have a plan which guarantees choice and competition and which still provides that, where all licensees agree, they can move to competition via the multi-channel services system. It ensures that there is a steady timetable for the introduction of choice and competition throughout Australia. Most importantly from my point of view, it ensures that in the longer term the vital role of regional television will survive and indeed, in my view, will prosper in the future. That outcome may not have been guaranteed. It certainly would not have been guaranteed had any government decided simply to go down the satellite networking route.

I want to make a few points about aggregation because it has been the Government's preferred method of achieving choice and competition. It is the vehicle which Cabinet has now decided on and which this legislation gives effect to for giving country people the same range of services as city people. I think aggregation has some advantages over other forms of introducing choice and competition into regional television. The first of those is that the framework we have before us tonight provides for much less regulation in the industry than would be the case under a system of supplementary licences or multi-channel services, as we could call them. Regulation for regulation's sake I certainly never support and I support any case where government can reduce regulation if it is in the long term interests of business in the market and of viewers; and I think in this case that is so.

The second advantage of this framework before us tonight is that it is market driven, and that again is important in an industry which is imaginative, which is competitive and which needs, I think, more opportunities for entrepreneurs. This framework will ensure that it is more market driven. I also have to emphasise that, in my view, as one looks around the four markets that have been created in Australia one can see that there will be opportunities for imaginative entrepreneurs to provide improved television services.

The plan which the Minister has tabled tonight and which has been approved by Cabinet provides for competition in the Victorian situation by 1992. I mention that area because it is the one in which I have an interest. It has been put publicly that the plan that has been approved provides for the majority of people in country Victoria, but omits the 47,000 viewers of Mildura. Similarly, in the New South Wales market Griffith has been excluded. I want to make a few points about why that has occurred. If the Government could have done so, it would have provided competition and choice to those people, but it simply has not been possible under this arrangement to do that. I will make a few points about that. The first is that under our policy of equalisation we have tried as far as possible throughout Australia to provide that range of choice and competition, but some areas, because of their small population and because of their isolation, we simply have not been able to fit into that broader plan. There is nothing new about that. In the draft indicative plan places such as Mount Isa, Broken Hill, Darwin and so on were not included because of those issues of isolation and small population. Similarly, when we looked at the final indicative plan, we had to exclude Mildura and Griffith for exactly the same reasons. It also has to be said that Mildura and Griffith were the smallest markets included in the draft indicative plan. There is no doubt that if three competitive services had proceeded with those two smallest markets they would have been in many ways big winners under the plan, whereas the larger regional stations such as Bendigo and Ballarat would have been financial losers, having to outlay significant sums to service those small, isolated markets and getting back a very small return.

When the Government looked at the draft indicative plan, it consulted the industry and got the views of regional television. On that basis the Government has excluded those areas from the larger approved markets. In this legislation we will be providing those two areas with the option of providing multi-channel services. We finally reached a fair decision there. It is worth bearing in mind that under this plan well over 90 per cent of people in regional areas will have three television services in the not too distant future.

I want to touch on another point raised by the honourable member for Goldstein-that is, the network argument. It is alleged that the Government has pandered to the networks in favouring its method of achieving equalisation-in other words, aggregation. I restate that the easiest way for any government to have ensured competitive choice into regional Australia would have been simply to allow the networks to have beamed directly off the satellite. We did not do that because we believed there is a vital role for regional television and we want to see that sustained in the future. This Government has always refused permission to the networks to broadcast directly to viewers in regional areas because we value localism and because, if we did that, the local news, current affairs, weather and sport would have simply disappeared off local stations.

It is worth emphasising, in response to the honourable member for Goldstein, that the Government cannot be accused of simultaneously pandering to the networks and favouring regional licensees, as has been put by some commentators on this decision. Under the final indicative plan some licensees will do well, some not quite so well and some very well. We have tried to bring together a policy which meets all the competing interests in this industry in a way which will guarantee eventual choice and competition.

Another issue on which I have touched briefly, but which is fundamental to this debate, is localism. I have mentioned that the simplest way of providing choice and competition would have been simply to use the satellite, but that would not have done anything for localism in regional Australia, which this Government wants to see protected. Some stations have a fine record of providing local content. Most regional stations have about 7 per cent local content and take, in one form or another, about 93 per cent of their programs from the major networks.

Localism is important. It is crucial in my area of Bendigo in the service provided by TV8. There is a very strong local following of TV8 because it provides local news, current affairs, access and so on. I point out that if one looks at the resources which stations such as TV8 put into their local content, it is something which is worth preserving at all costs. This year TV8 won the Penguin awards of the Television Society of Australia for the best regional news, the best regional news story and the best regional personality; received a commendation for another regional news story; and received special recognition in an open category for its community service announcements. That is no mean set of achievements for one regional station. This year TV8 also won the Logie for the outstanding contribution to regional television, which was won by the TV8 news presentation, News Hour. In 1985 TV8 won further awards for its news and current affairs programs and it has also won sporting awards for what it has done in film, videos and documentaries on harness racing in Victoria. Those things are worth preserving and I am confident that the policy we have announced tonight will ensure that there is a long-standing and long term role for regional television in Australia.

It has been argued that aggregation may reduce local content, but I am firmly of the belief that aggregation will not destroy local content. In fact, there will be every incentive in larger aggregated markets for television stations to continue to put their resources and money into producing local programs, because by doing that they will keep local viewers. There are American examples which show that television station licensees which provide the greatest proportion and best quality of local content achieve the highest ratings. In a commercial operation it is ratings which are all important because they determine advertising revenue. I am confident that in the markets of Victoria, southern and northern New South Wales and Queensland regional television stations will have an inbuilt incentive to maintain and perhaps even increase their level of localism in terms of sporting coverage, cultural coverage, news and current affairs. By doing that they will retain viewer patronage, which will keep advertising revenue coming through. I am confident on that issue of localism.

It is fair to say that this issue has been a contentious one for the Government over time. It evokes, depending on whom one talks to, some heated views about providing choice and competition in regional areas. It is also a complex issue. A wide range of competing interests is involved in this industry-the interests of networks, regionals, viewers and of the big regionals versus the small regionals. One could probably throw in a few other competing interests.

In the legislation before the House tonight the Minister and the Cabinet have found a formula and a framework which meet most of the concerns. We will never meet all the concerns, but the legislation meets most of the concerns of all those competing interest groups and provides a formula which will provide competition and choice to the five million Australians who do not live in capital cities. It is also an historic piece of legislation because it provides, in my view, an iron clad time-table for introducing choice and competition in Australia. We will have competition and choice of three stations in southern New South Wales by 1989, Queensland by 1990, in northern New South Wales by 1991 and in Victoria by 1992. Even if in some of those markets all the licensees agree to move to competition via the multi-channel service, we will still be guaranteed competition and three services in Australia by 1996.

The honourable member for Goldstein said that the Government had neglected to take account of the main players in this whole issue-as he put it, the viewers. I reject totally his assertion. We have put the interests of viewers in country Australia to the forefront of our considerations. It was this Government and this Government alone which talked three years ago of equalisation and which has been determined to provide country people with the same range and quality of services as their city cousins. Clearly the Opposition, which was in government between 1975 and 1983, had every opportunity to provide increased choice to country viewers if it had so wanted and if it genuinely intended to do that. The fact is that in eight years of government members of the Opposition did nothing about providing increased choice to those viewers whom tonight they say are so fundamental to this whole issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —We brought in supplementary licences legislation.-

—There is an interjection about supplementary licences. The fact is that those opposite were in government pre-1975 as well. Pre-1972 we had regional television, but the fact is that those opposite were in government for eight years between 1975 and 1983 and they did not provide any additional choice to the five million country people who live throughout Australia. I daresay that if those opposite were in government for another 10 years they still would not. The reason they did not was that certain interests were on their side. The fact is that we are providing additional choice in services. This Government has put into place the remote commercial television service. We have put into place an expansion of the ABC radio network. We are now putting into place an expansion of choice in competition in regional television. This Government is determined to give country people the fair go that they have deserved for the best part of a decade. We have got that now with legislation which is iron-clad. It will guarantee that. I have pleasure in supporting this legislation.

It was some three years ago that the Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy) outlined his desire for equalisation. In the second reading speech in introducing this Bill he said that he was proud to commend the Bill. I remind the Minister of his own words. He said:
. . . we always have to be constrained by consideration of cost and good management . . .

That is partly why our amendment is concerned with good management and cost. If one looks at the end of his second reading speech-it is interesting to highlight the costs associated with this Bill-there are three broad areas. Firstly, the licensees proceed to aggregation and are to be exempt from sales tax on UHF transmitters purchased prior to 1991. The estimated cost is about $30m in 1986 prices. I ask the Minister: Does that apply to those who opt for the multi-channel services option initially? I suppose that it does. The honourable member for Goldstein made the point that if we are going to pursue this route for sales tax exemption, we ought to go the whole gamut of the material and items that have to be purchased and take in feeder lines and antennae. Really the basic question that must be asked is whether or not this pursuit of providing choice which we have heard so much about in the method proposed is worth the cost. I suspect that when the final accounting comes in it will certainly not be. There is no doubt that a policy of equalisation-that of providing three commercial services to all Australians-is a massive task and equivalent to the work of the introduction of television itself.

There are many issues to be considered. There are the financial issues, which I have mentioned; there is program production which other speakers have mentioned; there is the effect on advertising revenues; and there are also diversity aspects and the localism aspects to which the honourable member for Bendigo alluded. I, like him, come from a rural seat, although mine is in Tasmania, and we will certainly be concerned about the maintenance of continuation of localism within television. I do not want to see us progress down that path with not only satelliting but also networking because I think that would be to the detriment of the continuation of localism and letting regions develop their own character. I fear that this aggregation policy even though it has been watered down will, in time, affect localism because of the financial issues that will arise to force greater control by the networks over regional stations, whether they be small or medium sized.

The detailed discussion of the two possible routes to equalisation, either aggregation or MCS, has provoked much discussion publicly. Most of it has been on the government side. The change in attitudes has indeed been interesting to watch. The Minister quaintly describes it as `a flexibility in debate which can only be admired'. The flexibility has not been the sole province of the industry; it has certainly been within the Government's ranks. When one goes back to the Forward Development Unit report, the threshold question is posed that in determining which approach to take the conflict exists between considerations of competition and viability. The FDU acknowledged that the Government is in a hurry for equalisation and thus some long term options have been discarded. Why then is there this hurry? The Government has adopted the aggregation route with an option MCS phase in arrangement. The needs or desires for competition were over viability. Only time will reveal whether this has been sensible. However, it was the major networks that wanted it this way and it seems that they have won the day.

It must be acknowledged that the original indicative plan has been substantially reworked which does give more attention to the more absurd aspects of the original proposal. Viability is at least given as one of the essential criteria in the determination of aggregated and approved markets. In my view the safest way to create greater choice was the MCS route. Under MCS existing licences would expand to two transmissions in their respective markets immediately and then by 1991 expand to three transmissions in their own market. After these had been consolidated there would be a move to the competitive circumstances of aggregation.

This Bill does have a hook in it regarding MCS. In my view the 28 days period is hardly adequate time for the television stations to make up their minds whether or not they wish to go down the immediate aggregation route or the MCS route. I wonder whether or not there might be an opportunity to extend that period to a more reasonable period. The hook in it is the one-in all-in rule on the MCS option. If one of the three licences chooses the aggregation route instead of the MCS, the other two licences must follow suit. David Astley, Chairman of Regional Television Australia, said as long ago as August of this year:
This decision making process, not by majority, but by minority, is undemocratic and against all principles of natural justice.

As a lawyer the concept of natural justice ought to be something the Minister is well acquainted with. I wonder how he answers that very valid criticism. If one looks at our amendment, we draw attention in the amendment to the one-in all-in trigger mechanism because we believe it to be wrong and contrary to natural justice.

The flexibility of argument over the Bill is interesting if one looks back over the last months. As long ago as 16 December 1985 in an article in the Australian Financial Review we see that the differences between the Prime Minister and the Minister for Communications surfaced and, lo and behold, a committee was formed. In that article it is stated:

In light of the considerable Government in-fighting and some unflattering media coverage last week concerning his attitude to various media groups, the climate was not good for a considered solution to the ticklish problem . . .
Essentially, it is a hung committee as Mr Keating so far has largely supported Mr Hawke.

The members of the committee were the Minister for Communications, Minister Button, the Treasurer and, I believe, the Prime Minister. There are previous articles with headlines on this issue. This is going right back to late 1985. We saw headlines such as `Duffy braces for regional T.V. showdown' and `Duffy's regional T.V. plan gains support from unexpected quarters'. That article talks of the connection between Senator Button, the Minister for Communications and the independents. Then there was an article by Gregory Hywood in the Australian Financial Review of 13 December 1985 headed `Mates and others: Hawke's view of the media groups'. It is interesting to have a look at that article. It states:

On Monday during the heated Cabinet discussions over revamped television ownership provisions-the biggest proposed changes to broadcasting rules in 30 years-the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, is authoritatively said to have referred to the Packer and Murdoch organisations as `the only mates we've got' in the media.

That is interesting. I repeat that the article stated `the only mates we've got in the media'. If we look also at the National Times we see another interesting article by Alan Ramsey. That article, which went into some detail, reads:

The Prime Minister is being forced to re-think his new grant design for Australia's commercial TV industry that overtly benefits the broadcasting interests of two of the country's most powerful media figures, Rupert Murdoch and Kerry Packer.

Where did Mr Peter Barron end up? He was the one who was actively involved in all the television activity and policy formulation. I understand that he is now gone. Where else should he end up but, as I understand it, working for Mr Packer. The interesting move in this legislation is that the vital ownership and control decisions on changes are not yet final. We are told in the second reading speech that the two-station rule is under consideration. It is my strong view that the legislation is deficient in that the whole change requires the vital second leg of ownership to be made known. All the Minister has said is that it is being reviewed and that there `could' be a change. It is my view that this statement is more a recognition of the deep divide that still exists in the Government over this whole issue.

By 13 October 1986 the Duffy-Button concern for regional seats began to manifest itself in newspaper headlines. In the Australian Financial Review of 13 October this year was a headline `Government pushes modified plan for television aggregation'. I would just like to quote from that article as well. It states:

In an attempt to take some of the sting out of the regional industry opposition and in response to the Caucus, the Government is considering enlarging the aggregated markets so the regionals will have a greater revenue base to fund aggregation.

This was a clear response to the threatened Caucus revolt led by the honourable member for Bendigo (Mr Brumby), who, in a moment of rational thinking, pointed out that aggregation would require massive purchases of equipment overseas to provide the necessary services at a time when our balance of payments was bad. After last week's announcements of $1.78 billion in terms of the current account deficit I would say it is now worse. Indeed, the ministerial ambitions of some honourable members on the other side of the House might be a little sick after this protracted debate. I understand that the Caucus committee of infrastructure and primary industry voted 15:1 to urge a slower pace on aggregation. The Australian Financial Review reported:
. . . Mr Hawke was said to be furious yesterday that the entire commercial television question was unravelling, with the potential to strain his relations with some major media group.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not a pretty sight.

—Indeed, not a pretty sight. No one knows what relations or agreements of understanding exist. Of course, one hopes that there are none but Australia is not alone in being concerned. It is interesting that the former Prime Minister of Papua New Guinea, Michael Somare, said in Port Moresby on 18 September, according to an Australian Associated Press wire:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . it would be morally wrong to allow Kerry Packer's media organisation to broadcast . . . in . . . New Guinea while blocking another intending Australian operator, Newcastle Broadcasting Network.
He said he did not know whether there were secret arrangements on the future of television but the matter was a subject of speculation.
He referred to a reported meeting recently between a senior Packer executive and Prime Minister . . . Wingti.

It should also be of interest to honourable members that the Newcastle Broadcasting Network, owned by Kevin Parry, sought a writ of mandamus in September this year requesting the Government of Australia to show why it is not continuing with the existing supplementary licence system. I ask the Minister, when he sums up, to explain how this legislation affects that court proceeding. Does it have the effect of annulling the proceeding if the legislation passes? If that organisation wins that proceeding what will be the situation? Will honourable members opposite come into this House and try to amend the Act as it applies to that application for a supplementary licence? The honourable member for Goldstein, in postulating why the Government was in such a hurry to pass this legislation, said that it could be because there was an election around the corner. It could also be that the Government was worried that the successful litigation proposed by NBN would have forced its hand in any event.

Finally, I wish to refer to Division 8 of the Bill, which relates to the special provisions affecting Tasmania. The need to recognise Tasmania as a special case was always apparent to those who really thought about it. It is a relief to see that the legislation recognises this fact. A total population of 450,000 in a State could never support three commercial licences. A population of one million is seen as the viable figure and that is not likely to happen in Tasmania in the short term. The lack of any decision on ownership and control is such that a Tasmanian operator is not really in a position to make decisions as to the options provided by the Bill. This is so right around the country.

It is a fatal flaw in this plan for the Government not to present the whole package together so that industry can make clear decisions as to its future. It again raises questions as to why there is such a rush to put this Bill through, leaving, as it does, a major, unresolved issue vital to industry's future decision making. I believe that reasons can be explained in part in the recent views expressed by the Treasurer, who, as we know, was appointed to a special television committee as long as ago as 1985 and who has been seen as the stalking horse for the Prime Minister on this issue. But a recent headline in the Australian Financial Review of Monday 10 November sums it up quite well. It states: `Keating muddies waters of TV issue now in too-hard basket'. Let me quote from that article to find out what Mr Keating has done to muddy the waters. I quote from the article written by Greg Earl:

. . . Mr Keating has now muddied the waters by proposing a ban on any new common ownership of newspapers and television stations in the same market' but no overall limit on commercial television ownership.
It would appear to disadvantage the Herald and Weekly Times and John Fairfax media groups. It would appear to advantage the Consolidated Press Nine Group . . .

Perhaps there we have the solution. I will leave it to honourable members to draw their own conclusions about what has really become a sordid affair to try to get to the truth of what has been happening on this issue. In effect, as it relates to Tasmania we would certainly be pleased with what the Government has decided. It gives effect to what is really a common-sense approach. But, as was pointed out by the honourable member for Goldstein, as we have one exception-we have one in Tasmania and now there are other exceptions as a result of the new indicative plan-how can we ever say that we have equalisation? It might be a lesson to the Government that, when it follows some recommendations that are put to it that are designed to advantage particular groups-that would seem to be the reason it wants to pursue full aggregation-there are always traps. Any government, when it makes a decision such as this of a vital nature, which is the biggest change to broadcasting in 30 years, has to remember that it governs for us all and not, as outlined in the headline I quoted from earlier, just for the mates of the Prime Minister. I support the amendment.

I do not think that the regional operators have helped themselves much over the years. SPEECH.PARA: To summarise, the Bill equalises the bringing of three services to all of Australia. It provides more viable and larger markets for regional Australia. We will not have a situation of two or three people controlling television in Australia. Ownership must be as diverse as possible in the most powerful medium in the world. DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: British Travel Agents Conference-Gull Force-Fringe Benefits Tax-Australian Made Campaign-Remote Area Television-Marine Council Inquiry-Queensland Election-International Year of Peace-Tasmania

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.15 p.m., I propose the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the House do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jull Mr D.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last week on the Gold Coast of Queensland 4,000 British travel agents met for their annual international conference. It was the first time that a major international conference of this type had been held in Australia and in terms of the future of the travel industry it was probably the most important conference ever to be held in Australia. Having spoken to a number of the travel agents who attended the conference, it would seem that the majority of them were quite surprised at the attractions that Australia has to offer, and in fact gave every indication that Australia would be a most attractive place for British tourists to visit. In fact we have seen a great increase in the number of international visitors coming to Australia in the last few years, particularly in the number of British tourists. I understand the projected figure for British holidaymakers this year is around 178,000.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the most telling points that came out of the conference was a statement by Mr Jack Smith, the Chairman of the Association of British Travel Agents, that the only thing standing between Australia doing very well out of the tourist industry from Britain was the high cost of air fares to Australia and indeed the high cost of domestic travel within Australia. He suggested that, because of the present regime in terms of international air rights into Australia, the average cost of a holiday in this country for a British holidaymaker would be something in excess of seven times what is normally paid now. Mr Smith suggested that the only way we could overcome this and obtain an even greater share of the British travel business was to look for the introduction of charter flights both to Australia and within Australia. I was interested to see that he suggested that the price available for charter operations from Britain to Australia would probably be in the vicinity of $850 return. That is not bad; $425 each way between London and Australia for a return flight. That figure is probably right because it is not so many years ago that Sir Freddie Laker, when making an application to the then Government to introduce charter flights into Australia, was quoting a return fare of some $680. The way inflation is at the moment, that $850 figure is probably not a bad base to work on.

My suggestion would be that we overcome some of the bias that seems to exist in all levels of government in relation to the introduction of charter flights and ask both Qantas Airways Ltd and British Airways, which are the prime operators on that route, to have a look at the prospect of generating their respective charter companies and introducing a fare that may be in the vicinity of $850 return. We know, for example, that British Airways has a holiday packaging outfit called British Air Tours. British Air Tours is the charter subsidiary of British Airways. In the early 1970s when Sir Freddie Laker first made his application to Australia, Qantas itself started up a charter company. It put that company, called Qantair, on its books but it has never been generated. My suggestion tonight is that the Minister for Aviation (Mr Peter Morris) go to Qantas and British Airways and look at the prospects of opening up that charter market between Great Britain and Australia. With a base holiday fare of some $850 return we would be more able to tap into that British market, worth more than $10m a year.

Of course we have to look beyond charter flights. There is a tremendous growth in the number of Japanese tourists coming into Australia. The fact is that the air fare between Tokyo and Australia is still one of the most expensive in the world. If one looks at the formulas used by the Japanese charter operators when they were looking at coming into Australia, one sees that they quoted a fare of about $640 return between Tokyo and Australia. That compares with anything between $900 and $1,700 which are the tour base fares on which we operate at the moment. Tourism is one of the few growth industries in Australia. It is one of the few industries that have the capacity to provide long term employment for our young people. Every time we can bring an additional 25,000 international holidaymakers into Australia we have the chance of creating another 1,400 jobs for young Australians. Therefore it makes a lot of sense for the Government to start to forget some of its bias towards charter operators and have a very real look at that proposition that has been put up by Mr Jack Smith, the Chairman of the Association of British Travel Agents. A fare of $850 between the United Kingdom and Australia would be a tremendous base for us to start feeding into that traffic. The one thing that it can do, apart from improving our balance of payments deficit, is to provide real and long term employment for young Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hand Mr G.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I wish to bring to the attention of the House an event which, for symbolic reasons, would obviously have been more appropriate to raise during last week's adjournment debate. Unfortunately, I was unable to be present for the adjournment debate on Remembrance Day 1986. My colleague the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis) made a fine contribution on the significance of that date. I take the opportunity to congratulate him and to congratulate his friends, the students from the Kiama High School, who talked to a number of members of the House on that day.

SPEECH.PARA: I, too, wish to raise issues of war and peace, of sacrifice and remembrance. The story that I will relate is about men who, like so many others, gave their lives in the defence of Australia during World War II. They are the men of the 2/21 Battalion, known as Gull Force. They were sent to the tiny but strategic island of Ambon which is located in the Banda Sea between New Guinea and Timor. The battle for Ambon took place in January 1942. It was all over in a week, with the inadequately manned and underequipped Gull Force isolated without either air or sea support, unable to stave off the enemy whose strength and superiority were so self-evident yet so underestimated. Although the defeat was swift, the existence of the Defence Force on Ambon was a strategic factor in halting the Japanese advance on Darwin and shifting its direction towards New Guinea.

What happened after the surrender is not perfectly clear either in relation to the number of prisoners of war involved or in relation to their fate. The facts appear to be these: Of the 900 to 1,100 soldiers who constituted the Gull Force, it is confirmed that only 305 returned to Australia after the war. One account that I have read suggests that only 15 soldiers were killed directly in the fall of Ambon while another 40-odd were able to escape before the Japanese had completely secured the island. It is therefore to be assumed that between 500 and 700 young Australians lost their lives at the hands of the Japanese while serving as POWs. Of these, it is confirmed that 312 officers and men were the victims of a massacre carried out by the Japanese at Laha on 6 February 1942 and between 15 and 20 February 1942. The official record cites the reason for these atrocities as being in response to heavy Japanese losses incurred when a mine sweeper struck a Dutch mine in the Bay of Ambon on 1 February. A number of Japanese officers were brought before the war crimes trial in 1947 for the massacre, and one was executed for his part. A further 263 men were relocated to the island of Hainan off south China following these executions. A total of 182 survived the Hainan experience whilst only 121 reached Australia from Ambon. The Australian War Crimes Commission said of Ambon that the death toll was 87 per cent of POWs, rating it as the worst prisoner of war camp in the Pacific. Despite the fact that the official record recognises the existence of the massacre at Laha, on Ambon, the circumstances and numbers involved have never been fully clarified. Following the war the truth was hidden from many of the relatives who lost sons, husbands and fathers. They were told that their kin had been killed in action or were missing presumed dead.

This incident has been brought to my attention by a constituent who lost his brother at Ambon. He alleges that a conspiracy of silence has surrounded the events since the war. Even the Victorian President of the Returned Services League, Bruce Ruxton, was unaware of the massacre until it was recently brought to his attention. I do not know why this conspiracy of silence exists. My intention in relating these events is not to rekindle the fires of hatred but merely to ensure that the real story of Ambon comes to light so that my constituent and the relatives of all those who died and, indeed, all Australians may know what happened.

To set the record straight, I believe the Government should carry out an investigation into the Laha massacre. ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) Yes. In US Fiscal Year (FY) 1982 (1 October 1981-30 September 1982).
(b) to (d) Yes. Details are given in the accompanying table.

(e) to (f) The primary function of GEOSAT is, as part of the long-standing US program of research in satellite geodesy, to provide precise information on the shape of the Earth and on its gravity field. Like all scientific data, GEOSAT data will have a wide range of potential civilian and military uses. GEOSAT data will be made available to the general public for commercial and scientific applications. The US Department of Defence has advised that while data derived from GEOSAT will be used by the Trident II program, along with much other data, GEOSAT data has only indirect application to the TRIDENT II program and that the TRIDENT II program is not the primary user of that data. The principal objectives of GEOSAT are:

(i) To provide an accurate map of the topography and roughness of the sea surface. It does this by means of a radar altimeter. The measurements give the height to the satellite which is then related to the surface of the earth by tracking the satellite from ground stations.
(ii) To improve the earth gravity-model by measuring gravitational accelerations imparted to GEOSAT, and by analysing the data on the shape of the sea surface.
A secondary objective is to provide oceanographic data on ocean thermal boundaries.

(g) There has been no change in responsibility in the US for GEOSAT, which since its inception has been a US Navy responsibility. As a matter of budgetary convenience, GEOSAT was originally funded under the TRIDENT program, but in keeping with GEOSAT's broad multifaceted nature, funding for the project has been provided under the Defence Meteorological Satellite Program (DMSP) since 1 October 1985. Other changes, shown in the answer to parts (b)-(d) of the question, derive from administrative considerations and not from changes in the mission or purpose of GEOSAT, and underscore the multiple applications of GEOSAT data. The GEOSAT project is to be funded under the DMSP, until FY 1989.

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Sub-section 135tc (2) permits a pension, benefit or allowance payable to a person under the Social Security Act to be paid to another person on behalf of the first mentioned person. Some institutions such as nursing homes and sheltered workshops receive payment on behalf of eligible persons through this mechanism; a single cheque payment is made to the institution with details of individual entitlement supplied. These payments are known as group cheques. There are currently 985 institutions which receive payment on behalf of residents by this means.

Additionally, a number of institutions receive comparable payment through the direct credit method. National statistics are not available but there are 86 such payments in NSW.
